PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 1.45 p.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) left Australia this morning to attend the Commowealth Heads of Government Regional Meeting in Fiji.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —I can fully understand that, because of the Prime Minister's leadership in CHOGRM, honourable senators would want to say 'Hear, hear'. The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade and Resources (Mr Anthony) will act as Prime Minister until the Prime Minister returns on Monday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIBRAA

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 65 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate of Australia in Parliament Assembled. This petition of certain citizens of Australia concerned with continuing cuts in Federal Government funding of higher education respectfully showeth that the Federal Government cut-backs in funding have:
Made it increasingly difficult for many Australians to contemplate study at a university or college of advanced education.
Reduced the resources available to groups with particular needs such as our Aboriginal and ethnic communities.
Seriously jeopardised Australia's ability to keep pace with and contribute to technological developments in a whole range of areas.
Reduced the quantity and quality of community education programs offered, especially in rural colleges.

Forced universities and colleges of advanced education to cut back on the numbers of staff available to teach existing courses endangering the quality of education offering and narrowing the range of courses available.
Your petitioners, therefore humbly pray that your Honourable Senate:

Ensure that levels of government funding for education are at a level that will enable all Australians to undertake the higher education of their choice regardless of their personal financial circumstances.
Provide all students, present and future, with adequate financial assistance by way of allowances and scholarships.
Will make a firm commitment to oppose the re-introduction of any tertiary fees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BJELKE-PETERSEN

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 20 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That citizens of Queensland view with great alarm the removal of the Director of the Office of Child Care and fear for the future of that office and the children's services programme which it administers.

We believe the Office of Child Care to be inappropriately placed within the Department of Social Security, where children's services are in competition with welfare services for the aged, disabled, and other such groups.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled , should take every step as necessary to obtain immediate withdrawal of the Office of Child Care from the Department of Social Security and the establishment of a Children's Commission.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: REID

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 175 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. That we are concerned for the welfare of Mr Mart Niklus, a leading Estonian and Baltic human rights activist presently imprisoned in the Soviet Union in Perm Labour Camp No. 389/36, and in ill-health.

2. The Australian Government has approved the sponsored entry of Mr Mart Niklus into Australia and we urge that the Government use its good offices to make representations to the Government of the Soviet Union to promptly facilitate his release and grant him a passport and exit visa.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Church of Mary Queen of Peace, Lithuania

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WATSON

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 87 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
(1) That the Church of Mary Queen of Peace located in Klaipeda, Lithuania, was the only Church built in Lithuania after World War II;
(2) This Church was closed by the Soviet authorities on 15 August, 1960 and confiscated in 1961 under the direct order of Mr Kruschev.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should request the Australian Minister for Foreign Affairs to raise with its counterpart in the USSR the great concern of many Australians that the Church of Mary Queen of Peace be restored to the religious worshippers of Klaipeda in Lithuania.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BOLKUS

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 134 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth:

1. The successive promises of the Federal Government to introduce ethnic television into Australia have only been carried out in respect to Sydney and Melbourne, ignoring other centres with large ethnic populations such as Adelaide .
2. The large proportion of the population of Adelaide is denied certain cultural rights including the viewing of television programmes broadcast in languages other than English.

3. The enormous benefits which arise from ethnic television in a multicultural society such as Australia, especially in respect to the exchange of ideas and exposing people to different views and cultures.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will request the Government to extend the operations of the Special Broadcasting Service's television service, Channel 0/28, to Adelaide without delay.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COLSTON

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 576 citizens of Australia :

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
The Great Barrier Reef is unique and is included on the World Heritage List.

Although the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act was to create a marine park to provide for the proper protection and management of The Reef, only 14 per cent of the total area defined in this Act as the Great Barrier Reef Region has been declared marine park.
The only insurance against an oil drilling blowout in Reef waters is to prohibit oil drilling in the Region and its vicinity.
This can only be effected by declaring the whole area of the Region a marine park under the above legislation.

Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government to take action to hold a referendum together with the next Federal Elections on the question that, 'The entire area of the Great Barrier Reef and its surrounding waters, defined as the Great Barrier Reef Region in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975 as amended 1978, be immediately declared a marine park under the provisions of that Act.'
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GRIMES

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 26 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) that US, Australian and allied forces used huge amounts of toxic chemicals for military purposes, such as Agents Orange, Blue and White, in Vietnam during the war there;
(2) many of these chemicals were, and are, known to be highly dangerous to human health;
(3) Australia's Vietnam veterans and their families are suffering many severe problems which may be due to their exposure to these chemicals; and
(4) the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia has been seeking a Royal Commission for well over two years to ensure an independent investigation of these matters.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will:
(a) express its support for the Royal Commission; and
(b) urge the Federal Government to establish the Royal Commission immediately.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

That the continuing high level of tax avoidance and evasion is the cause of grave concern for honest Australian taxpayers, and demands stringent and immediate action by the Commonwealth, noting in particular:
(1) The latest estimate by the Australian Taxpayers' Association is that $7 000m a year is being lost in taxation revenue;
(2) This figure can only continue to rise because of the timid approach by the Government in closing off tax loopholes; and
(3) No effective inroads can be made until a comprehensive policy is adopted of levying tax from the date on which a scheme of tax avoidance is first used.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telegram Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of New South Wales respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Telecommunications Commission to withdraw public telegram facilities and downgrade telegram standards by:
1. planning to withdraw the 24 hour telegraph service at the Chief Telegraph Office in each capital city and in Canberra and Darwin;
2. closing country telegraph offices;
3. increasing telegram charges whilst downgrading the service;
4. withdrawing telegram operating facilities from a large number of suburban and country post offices;
5. generating serious delays in telegram delivery by reducing standards of service through centralisation of the network and reduction of operating and delivery staff

will reduce an available means of communications in commercial enterprise, deny the opportunity for people of Australia to make contact with family and friends in times of emergency, and civil or natural disasters, particularly for the 30 per cent of Australians who are not telephone subscribers.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will take measures to ensure the maintenance of an efficient, effective public telegram service to meet the needs of the Australian people socially, publicly, commercially and in times of emergencies and civil or natural disasters.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from 237 citizens), Bjelke-Petersen (from 6 citizens) and Martin (from 42 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia concerned about the high and increasing rate of divorce and family breakdown, convinced that the Family Law Act has weakened marriage by making divorce a trivial matter, the present Act paying scant regard to its own definition of marriage as a life-long union; and believing that the legal bond of marriage should be strengthened, humbly petition for the Family Law Act and the Marriage Act to be amended in order to:
1. Reject any moves towards divorce by post
2. Restore the former prohibition of marriages between close relatives by blood or marriage
3. Protect the rights and welfare of aggrieved partners of a marriage who are threatened with being divorced against their will
4. Ensure that in divorce judgments paramount attention be given to whatever course will best serve the welfare of dependent children of the marriage
5. Encourage counselling towards reconciliation
6. Restore objective tests to irretrievable breakdown of marriage in terms of:
i. intolerable behaviour;
ii. desertion for two years;
iii. separation for three years.
And we pray that you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation .

PETITION.TITLE: Postal Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth:

That the response of Dulwich, Toorak Gardens and Rose Park and other members of the community who use the Dulwich Post Office would like Australia Post to reverse its decision to close this local Post Office on July 1, 1982. They request permission that the local Post Office remain open to the public for at least a further twelve months. Before any further decisions are made by Australia Post to close this local facility the following factors should be considered:
1. Most people reliant upon the local Post Office are elderly and mothers of young families who find commuting to a major shopping complex a disadvantage.
2. The Burnside needs analysis study determined the higher proportion of elderly and mothers of young families in the area.
3. Small neighbourhood businesses along Stuart Road would be adversely affected by the closure of the Post Office.
4. Consider the location of the Post Office and its access to the public being away from main roads yet on a public transport route.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to a question I asked him on 16 February this year in which I asked what were the three essential elements of the Fraser Government's wages policy, to which the Minister replied that I should be patient and await a statement that he would make later that day. I now refer to that statement made on 16 February and to the speech given to the American Chamber of Commerce by the present Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Macphee, eight days ago. I now ask the Minister: What are the central elements of the Government's wages policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Government spokesmen have been at pains to point out over the last half year and, indeed, over a longer period that they see it as essential that there be wage restraint in the community generally if jobs are not to be destroyed. In saying that they have been echoing a view which I would have thought would have the broad support of the community. It certainly had the support of the Labor Treasurer, Mr Crean, when he used words which have often been re-quoted; namely, that one man's wage rise can mean another man's job.

ANSWER.PARA: As recently as a few days ago Mr Macphee referred to the fact that wage rises in excess of productivity, and in excess of the current inflation rate would certainly make the employment situation even more difficult. The Government has put its position with respect to wage rises before a number of tribunals. It has had a degree of success in that. With respect to its own tribunal-that which looks at the wages paid to members of this Parliament-there was a scaling down of the sort of increase that might have been expected. There have been similar successes with respect to decisions relating to the wages of academics and public servants, the returns to medical practitioners and so on. In other words, the Government, across a range of wages and salaries, and not merely those which affect people normally described as wage earners, has sought to urge wage restraint on the part of tribunals and the community. That is a very central element of the Government's attitude to wages policy. I will ask the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to provide a fuller statement for the Leader of the Opposition but I would have hoped that in the present circumstances, when disemployment is such a problem for Australia, there would be broad agreement on the very real need for wage restraint on the part of those who are in employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. I understand that the Government is against wage increases and I think it is common ground between the major parties that wage restraint is desirable. What I am asking, in case he is not clear about the question, is: Is this Government in favour of a centralised wage fixation system, or not?

—I believe that there are on the record plenty of statements by Government spokesmen, including the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations himself. The Government has encouraged a much greater degree of wage fixation through the reaching of agreement on an industry basis and has supported a number of important agreements. However, I will refer the question to Mr Macphee for further reply.

—I preface my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer by referring her to a very serious situation which has arisen as a result of the 20 per cent sales tax that the Government has imposed on the boat building industry. I wish to detail specifically the case of the Norman Wright shipyard in Brisbane, which has been the centre of the nation's boat building industry since late last century. The yard's last order will be launched in December--
—Order! I suggest that the honourable senator is giving a lot of information. She should be asking a question.

—Thank you, Mr President. I wanted to mention that at the Millkraft shipyard, which is also in Brisbane, four tradesmen have been dismissed and seven apprentices stood down, while at the Norman Wright shipyard five tradesmen have been sacked. Is the Minister aware that, because of the 20 per cent sales tax, the nation is losing its wooden boat craftsmen and consequently the Federal Government is receiving 20 per cent of nothing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — In the Budget of last year the Government amended the sales tax exemption that was applicable to ships and other vessels in order to ensure equity in the sales tax treatment of boats and other vessels used exclusively or principally for purposes of pleasure, sport or recreation. Prior to that action, boats hired out on a bare boat basis for pleasure or sporting purposes were taxable, whereas boats hired out with a crew for similar purposes were exempt. The amendment corrected that position by making both classes of boat taxable. Boats used for purposes other than pleasure, sport or recreation remain exempt from tax. Senator Bjelke-Petersen mentioned difficulties in the boat building industry. I know of no evidence that directly connects any recession in that industry in Queensland with the broadened sales tax liability. However, I will see that her question is referred to the Treasurer for any response that he may wish to make. But, as I say, that amendment in the Budget of last year was designed to establish equity between the different usages of the boats. I think that was understood at the time. If there are other difficulties that were referred to in the question I will see that some response is given to them.

—My question is to the Minister for Social Security and refers to the fact that moneys paid in pensions and benefits are not considered as income when loss of income is calculated for determining sickness benefit. What is the basis for this action by the Government? If such moneys are not income according to the Department of Social Security, in future will the Australian Taxation Office take the same attitude and consider such moneys as being not taxable?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter raised by Senator Grimes involves an interpretation of , I think, section 108 of the Social Services Act. That section provides for the payment of sickness benefit when there is a loss of earnings due to sickness. I do not have the section in front of me but there is a requirement in the Act as to the form of income lost which gives rise to an entitlement to sickness benefit. In about the middle of the current calendar year a specific case came before the Department in which this arose. A legal ruling was sought from the Attorney-General's Department and that legal ruling indicated that under the existing section there were limitations on when sickness benefit could be paid. Clearly, it can be paid where a person is working, becomes sick and loses income because of the illness. There is a difficulty where a person is receiving some form of social security income and ceases to be eligible for that. That person is then in a position where sickness might prevent employment.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of the ruling or advice from the Attorney-General's Department, my Department revised the instruction to officers as to the administration of sickness benefit. It is important to note that the revised instruction which was circulated in June made it clear that under the changed interpretation-which I emphasise was not a change in the law or a change in policy by the Government or the Department but a response to advice as to what the law in fact means-an alternative benefit could be available in appropriate cases, namely, a special benefit. What is not yet clear is whether that gives rise to circumstances of hardship and difficulty which would warrant an amendment to section 108 of the Act. That is a matter which I have asked my Department to examine and to report to me on.

The Director-General of the Department has also been in touch with regional officers of the Department to ascertain the extent to which there is an actual difficulty for claimants because of the re-interpretation, on the advice of the Attorney-General's Department, of section 108. That information is presently being collected to assist in the consideration of the policy question which arises. I would like to make it quite clear to the Senate that in no sense was the change of interpretation the result of any wish on the part of the Government, or indeed of the Department, to limit the payment of benefits. Rather, of course, the Department is bound by the requirement that it must administer the Act according to law. It has discovered that the law is not quite what it was thought to be and as a result follow-up action is being taken. But I also stress that in cases of hardship-that is, in cases where a person who is not eligible for sickness benefit is without means-of course the possibility is available for the payment of special benefit. My wish and that of the Government is to ensure that hardship will not occur because of these provisions. I will examine the Act and see whether some amendment should be made.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. In view of the fact that for many years the Act has been interpreted in the way that it was previously, whereby these moneys were considered as income, why was a legal opinion sought at this stage concerning the definition of the Act? What reason could there have been other than to limit the amount of money paid out in sickness benefit?

—My understanding is that in a particular case it was thought by an officer of the Department, after examination of the provisions of the Act governing the sickness benefit, that the sickness benefit was not payable. Because there was past practice which made that view doubtful, the legal opinion of the Attorney-General's Department was sought. So in the normal course of administration of this provision, a particular case gave rise to a query. That query was dealt with in the appropriate way-namely, by getting clarification as to the meaning of the law.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. I believe three new members are to be appointed to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. Can the Minister give me an assurance that at last Tasmania will be represented on that Tribunal by the appointment of a Tasmanian as one of the three members?

—I understand that Senator Walters is correct; there are to be some appointments made to the Tribunal. I understand the point she makes in her question, that the State she represents should have its own representation on the Tribunal. There is no reason why this should not be possible. I understand that the Minister is quite prepared to give his earnest attention to any applicants or nominees from Tasmania. Of course, anyone appointed to the Tribunal would need to be suitably qualified and the Minister would want to examine and vet any nominations in the appropriate way. Nevertheless, the honourable senator can be assured that there is no reason a priori why a Tasmanian should not be appointed and, as she said, why Tasmania should not at last have its place on the Tribunal.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PHILIPPINES: DETENTION OF FATHER BRIAN GORE

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs what representations the Government has made to the Government of the Philippines to protect the interests of an Australian citizen, Father Brian Gore of the Columban Fathers, who has been charged with subversion and the illegal possession of arms in the Philippines. Does the Minister know that Father Gore is considered within his order as a peace-loving, useful and highly regarded person who has worked diligently for 13 years in a village region with acute problems of landlessness, economic disproportion and suppression of civil liberties by the Marcos military junta? Is the Minister aware that Father Gore claims that the first time he saw the hand grenade and other weapons he is said to have possessed was in the police station after his arrest-in other words, he was framed-and that the so-called subversive documents he is said to have had were merely his parish magazine? Will the Government take urgent action to see that Father Gore has proper and independent legal representation and immediate effective oversight of his affairs from our embassy in Manila and especially that the actions of a Lieutenant Gallo of the Philippines Army at the Oringao Church compound and in the town on 23 and 24 September last will be investigated ? Finally, will the Minister make some further statement later in the session as to how effective steps taken in Father Gore's interest have been?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have some information on this matter and I will see that the other points to which I am unable to refer at present are dealt with at a later time. My information is that an Australian Columban priest , Father Gore, aged 38 years, was detained on 24 September 1982 in his parish on charges relating to the alleged discovery of explosives and anti-government documents following a raid on his residence by military authorities. Two lay followers were detained with Father Gore but all were released on the same day, after questioning. To date a warrant of arrest has not been served on Father Gore, although our embassy in Manila understands that one was issued by a local judge on 28 September. There is no indication yet of when the warrant might be served or when Father Gore will be asked to appear in court. On 1 October an officer from the embassy travelled to speak with Father Gore and to offer him appropriate assistance. The Department of Foreign Affairs is maintaining a close watch on developments and is in contact with Philippines officials both here and in Manila and with church authorities. As soon as I have any further information I will see that the Senate is advised.

—Has the Minister for Education noted the Press release dated 10 September of the New South Wales Minister for Education, Mr Mulock, in which the Minister alleges that the Commonwealth Government has been diverting funds from government schools to the non-government sector? Can the Minister inform the Senate whether it is true, as alleged by the New South Wales Minister, that funds were diverted from government to non-government schools? It is further a fact, as alleged by the Minister, that additional resources are being provided by the Federal Government to the non-government sector at the expense of government schools, and that government schools are being disadvantaged by the Federal Government's policy of funding both the government and non-government sector?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not record all of the parts of Senator Lajovic's question but I think I can answer it. It is interesting that in this year, while Commonwealth funding for government schools increased by 2 per cent, recurrent support by New South Wales for its own government schools diminished by 2 per cent. I should have thought that Mr Mulock was in no position to preach to the Commonwealth when this year he has cut recurrent funding by 2 per cent for his own schools and when he has cut capital funding for schools in New South Wales by 20 per cent. The fact is that the New South Wales Budget, brought down by a Labor government, has cut education for its own government schools at the same time as we have been increasing, in our Budget, support for the government school system.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course it is nonsense to say that at Commonwealth level there has been a diversion of funds from government to non-government schools. It is nonsense. The extra funds that we have applied are new money. We are supplying this year, as we supplied last year and shall supply next year, for recurrent funding of government schools more than was made available in the last year of Labor's Budget. We are supplying more for the recurrent support of government schools than Labor did in 1976.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I invite honourable senators who are interjecting so much to look at the figures. It does not befit Mr Mulock this year, when he has cut education in the way he has, to preach to the Commonwealth.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the Minister aware that a former Minister, Mr Staley, has asked the Victoria Police to investigate serious allegations in regard to aircraft and possible fraud against Commonwealth revenue? Is it a fact that the aircraft involved is a 1124 Westwind aircraft imported from Israel? Has the Minister or the Prime Minister called for a full report on these allegations from the Fraud Squad? Is it a fact that the Government's interest in this matter has been activated by the implication of a prominent businessman who sits on Government bodies? Is it a fact that as a result of the information given to police in respect of this tax racket, Sir Andrew Grimwade has resigned from all Government appointments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, since the matter raised concerns the Prime Minister, I think I should respond. There was a report yesterday in the Press that Mr Staley had given certain information to the police. That matter must now lie with the police and be a matter that will emerge following police investigations. I cannot add further to that. I shall refer the matter to the Acting Prime Minister and see whether there is any further information. As a separate matter, Senator Robert Ray has asked about the resignation of a businessman, Sir Andrew Grimwade. I have a copy of Sir Andrew Grimwade's letter of resignation to the Prime Minister. Mr President, I ask that the text of it be incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Sir Andrew Grimwade, C.B.E.
4th Floor, 320 St Kilda Road, Melbourne, Victoria, Australia 3004
PRIVATE & CONFIDENTIAL
12 October 1982
The Rt Hon. J. Malcolm Fraser, C.H., M.P.,
Prime Minister,
Parliament House,
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600.
Dear Prime Minister,

You are aware that, for some months, I have been considering reducing my outside commitments and, in fact, have already reduced some of my business activities. This is because of an increasing workload for the next year or so in my primary business interest and because of my involvement in a major public company reorganisation.

I regret to advise you that it is therefore no longer possible for me to give the time and application necessary to continue my membership of the Official Establishments Trust, the Remuneration Tribunal and the Council of the Order of Australia.

In the case of the former, I have served the Official Establishments since 1976 and the basis has now been laid for their proper future operations. In the case of the Remuneration Tribunal and the Order of Australia, my appointments date from the time of the Whitlam Government, 1974 and 1975 respectively, and it is now time to make way for others with more time available.

Please accept my retirement from these bodies forthwith, particularly because of my likely departure overseas in the near future. This should enable my successors to be appointed in time for the next busy period.
It has been a privilege to have had the opportunity to have served on these bodies.
With kind regards,
Yours sincerely,
Andrew Grimwade

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to genuine differences of opinion between the taxpayer and the Commissioner of Taxation resulting in the raising of an objection, when under the new arrangements the taxpayer has to pay 100 per cent of the tax on the item in dispute. Is the Minister aware that there is no mechanism for the Commissioner to expedite the resolution of such differences? Has the Government given consideration to expediting the Board of Review mechanisms or to increasing the number of boards because of an increase in workload due partly to the inexperience of staff as a result of transferring assessing staff to tax evasion areas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am aware that at the time the change was made with regard to the objection procedures it was understood that the changes would result in people requiring early settlement of disputes. I am not able to say at this stage what mechanisms or changes have been made with regard to staffing structure to enable that to occur. If the question were placed on notice, I could have the various parts of it responded to by the Treasurer. I think we would all agree that what has been outlined by Senator Watson is desirable-that an early determination of the objection be made so that the matter can be satisfactorily dealt with from the point of view of the taxpayer. As soon I have some response from the Treasurer I shall advise Senator Watson.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PROPOSED IRRIGATION SCHEME: SOUTH EAST TASMANIA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for National Development and Energy and it refers to a feasibility study proposed by Tasmania into a major irrigation scheme for that area of south east Tasmania which has rich soil suitable for labour intensive vegetable production and floriculture but which is often drought affected. Has the Minister given consideration to Tasmania's request for this feasibility study to be funded through the national water resources program? If so, what has been the result?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this moment the Government is in the process of receiving submissions from various States for the program. I am aware that a suggestion has come forward regarding the feasibility study. In the past it has not been normal for that to come under the water resources program but I can assure the honourable senator that it will be given very close attention.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and concerns the imprisonment of Mr Lech Walesa. He has now been in prison for 10 months. Mr Walesa is, of course, the leader of the Polish Solidarity movement which was recently disbanded by the Polish Government, itself an outrageous act. Is the Minister aware of widespread concern among the Polish community here and elsewhere that Mr Walesa is being treated with drugs and brainwashed? Does the Minister have any information on these allegations and will he endeavour to arrange for Mr Walesa to be visited by the International Red Cross to check on his condition of imprisonment so as to reassure his many friends and admirers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister is aware of the allegations that Solidarity leader, Lech Walesa, detained since martial law was imposed on 13 December, has been treated with drugs and brainwashed. As far as the Minister is aware there is no credible evidence to support these allegations. Mr Walesa is visited regularly by representatives of the International Red Cross. The most recent visit took place in August. According to Western media reports, on 26 September his wife, on return from spending three days with her husband at his place of detention, described as vulgar lies reports that he had been forced to take drugs. Mrs Walesa is reported to have said that her husband felt fine. Despite the recent announcement that some more of those who have been detained would be released, it is a matter of continuing concern to the Government that Mr Walesa, other Solidarity leaders and many other persons remain in detention in Poland.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government, in conjunction with Western allies, has repeatedly called on the Polish authorities to lift martial law, release all those who have been detained since its imposition and allow the Polish people to find a solution to their economic and political difficulties on the basis of consensus and conciliation. If there is further or later information I will see that the Senate is advised.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Commerce. During the recently held discussions on the tin quota agreement, what consideration was given to and what provisions were made for workers in the industry whose employment has been and will be seriously affected ? If the answer is none, could the Minister tell me what can be done for the very serious social implications to the families in that area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some weeks ago I responded to the broad question of the tin quota agreement and the interest of concerned people who were in the tin mining industry in a small way. Because Senator Hearn is seeking more up to date information than my previous response I will seek from the Minister in another place the most up to date information and let her know. The Government has been concerned that, due to the decline in tin demand in the world, there is, of course, an adverse impact upon employment, particularly employment of those who were in a small way in the tin mining and dredging industry. I will seek the latest information and let Senator Hearn know.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Is it true that the Royal Canberra Hospital has said that residents for the hospital for 1983 will be chosen only from New South Wales students? If this is the policy of the hospital, when was the decision made? Does the Minister agree that as Canberra students who want to study medicine must leave Canberra to attend a medical school they are, by such a policy, discriminated against and as a result precluded from returning to their homes to live and to practise medicine?

—I understand Senator Reid's concern. There is not an undergraduate school of medicine in the Australian Capital Territory although there is, of course, a very distinguished graduate school, the John Curtin School of Medicine. The information given to Senator Reid is incorrect and the basis on which the question is asked is not correct. The Capital Territory Health Commission is currently considering the matter of the placement of residents in its two public hospitals for 1983. It has not indicated that they will be chosen only from New South Wales students. Because of that, I think the other parts of the question are not applicable. Neither has the Government advised students in the Australian Capital Territory that such a situation will apply.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Is the Minister aware that senior public servants in the Northern Territory have been advised that the Federal Government has decided to withdraw support for the Darwin-Alice Springs rail link? Will the Minister reassure the people of the Northern Territory that this is not the case and that the project will proceed as promised by the Prime Minister in 1980?

—Senator Robertson gets his information on this matter from an unknown source. What he says seems to be one of those canards which occasionally float around this place. I will, of course, refer the question immediately to the Minister for Transport and obtain the assurance that Senator Robertson seeks .

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, refers to a joint statement by the Attorney-General and the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment on 12 October on a proposed Sex Discrimination (Commonwealth Employees) Bill, in which statement, in reference to the need for a co-operative approach with the States for anti-discrimination legislation, the Ministers stated:

QUESTION.PARA: The same co-operative approach has been taken with regard to the discussions on the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women, which we hope will be ratified soon.
How soon does the Government envisage that the ratification of the Convention will be?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Convention to which Senator Martin refers is regarded by the Government as a most important one and one to which it would hope to give ratification at an early date. Honourable senators will be aware that at a meeting of Ministers on human rights held at Alice Springs in November 1980 it was agreed that the Commonwealth and State governments would work actively towards ratification. Commonwealth and State officials have been examining the various laws and practices within their jurisdictions in order to ensure consistency with the principles and objectives set out in the Convention. Not all States have yet notified the Commonwealth that they have completed that task . It is thought appropriate that all States should notify the Commonwealth before final ratification takes place. Good progress has been made and it is hoped that the Government will be able to ratify the Convention in 1982. What is required is that the States which are yet to respond should do so. I understand that the Minister and the relevant State representatives are to meet later this month to discuss the matter and to see whether they can progress it.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister, refers to persons involved in tax avoidance and evasion in Australia who transfer assets out of the country before they can be properly dealt with in the courts. In asking this question, I refer to a question asked by my colleague in another place, the honourable member for Hawker. On 9 September, Mr Jacobi asked the Prime Minister about the use of the ministerial discretion in sections 7 and 9 of the Passports Act 1938 to stop these people from leaving Australia with assets which may well be liable to taxation. The Prime Minister in reply said that he hoped that the situation would not develop where people would have their normal rights taken away from them before a prosecution was launched. Is the Government aware that on Friday, 8 October the Western Australian Supreme Court was told that a Perth property developer, Henry Chapple, was alleged to have taken $2m out of Australia to Great Britain at a time when the Taxation Office has outstanding assessments against Mr Chapple, his family and a number of companies totalling $3m? Is the Government also aware that Mr Chapple was a director of companies which were transferred to tax consultant Brian Maher? Does the Government consider that Mr Chapple's ' normal rights' are in this instance more important than the $3m owed to the Tax Office or more important than the $2m this man took out of the country? Finally , will the Government now take appropriate action under the Passports Act to ensure that persons like Mr Chapple and against whom there is substantial evidence are not able to transfer assets out of Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have information about the specific case of Mr Henry Chapple as quoted by Senator McLaren, but I accept what the honourable senator says, that there is a liability established. As I have understood it, the general situation has been that where the Taxation Office has made an assessment and has sought to obtain satisfaction, it has, I think, proceeded in the legal way to get a restraint upon transfer of assets. That is my recollection; it may or may not be wholly right. I believe that that has been the normal practice in the past. I do not think there has been any movement away from it at present. I do not know why Mr Chapple has been able to transfer assets, if he has. The Commonwealth Government is determined that the debts due to the Commonwealth from the taxpayers of Australia shall be paid and we will take all the steps that are available to us within the law to collect those taxes. That is what we are trying to do right at this moment. But I will look at the matter regarding Mr Chapple and also the matters raised in the early part of the question regarding statements on passports. If there is any further information I will let Senator McLaren have it.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: BROKEN HILL PROPRIETARY CO. LTD: MERCHANT SHIPPING FLEET

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Construction, concerns the reduction of the merchant shipping fleet of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. Is the Minister aware that in the past 12 months BHP has laid up seven of its ships in Sydney and Geelong and has announced the possibility of further reductions? Will the Government ensure that any companies which lay up ships do not then use Government subsidies to build more ships in overseas shipyards which would result in more ships on the Australian register also being laid up? In the light of the announced laying up by BHP, can the Minister explain the purpose of the shipbuilding subsidy to expand the number of Australian ships carrying Australian cargoes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true, as Senator Lewis outlined in his question, that the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd has in fact laid up a number of vessels as a result of a fall-off in its trade. The result of that, of course, is some unemployment in that area. I would need to check whether the exact number of ships laid up is seven. However, I understand that it is a very considerable number. Of course, to find the reasons for that we would need to look at the steel trade generally. The fact has been evidenced in this place and in the other place recently that clearly there has been a downturn in the world steel industry as a result of falling markets overseas and that, of course, has particularly affected BHP's exports and has led to an increase of imported steel into this country. The Government's assistance in respect of BHP generally has been announced recently. The Leader of the Government in this place has often mentioned particularly the assistance given to BHP by virtue of its ability to offset losses of one group of companies against profits of another within the same company group. That will be of considerable assistance to BHP in retrieving its situation and redeveloping its trade and opportunities here and overseas.

ANSWER.PARA: As regards the second part of the question, clearly Senator Lewis has a misunderstanding about the nature of the shipbuilding subsidy insofar as this subsidy is not available for ships which are built overseas and is, in fact, allowable only in respect of those ships which are built within Australia. Whether they are used on overseas trade or within the coastal trade of Australia is not a question for consideration. The subsidy relates only to the actual building of the vessel within the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to a question which Senator Button asked her on 9 September. It concerned a statement by the New South Wales Attorney-General that the New South Wales Government had made many approaches over the years putting tax avoidance schemes to the Australian Taxation Office for prosecution, but nothing was done. On that occasion the Minister said that she would seek a response from the Treasurer and the Commissioner of Taxation. When can we expect that response?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not know whether any response has been made to the earlier question. I will refer the subsequent question also to the Treasurer and seek some response on it.

—Mr President, my question is addressed to you. It relates to the long-delayed consideration of the televising of the proceedings of Parliament. Are you aware of debates which have taken place in the House of Commons in London relating to the introduction of television to that House as reported in The Parliamentarian in the issue of April 1982 and in the reported statement of the proposer, the Right Honourable Jack Ashley, that, apart from the Republic of Ireland and Great Britain, every country in the Western world now televises its parliamentary proceedings and that none is experiencing the catastrophic or comical consequences which the opponents of television fear? If so, will you, Mr President, now take action to expedite the televising of the proceedings of the Senate, at least, so that the relevance of parliament to government can be reaffirmed and the public properly informed as to its proceedings?

—I must inform both Senator Missen and the Senate that the matter of televising the proceedings of both the Senate and its committees has been before the Standing Orders Committee for some time. The matter was discussed at length at the last meeting of the Standing Orders Committee, which was attended by a representative of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. He has supplied further information for us which will be looked at further at the next meeting, which is to take place next week.

—The Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations will be aware that there are well in excess of three times as many days lost from the work place because of industrial accidents as there are because of industrial disputes and that, in 1981, 500,000 workers were injured in industrial accidents resulting in 2.2 million lost work days and $4, 500m paid out in compensation. In the light of these staggering figures, why has the Government not established a uniform national collection of data relating to industrial accidents? Is it a fact that there is a Government proposal to publish a national bulletin on industrial accidents and that it is hoped to have it by late 1984? Will the Minister have this wasteful procrastination halted and set up the bulletin immediately so that accident prevention can be properly tackled?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge the repeated interest of Senator McIntosh in this subject. He does raise it at Question Time from time to time and elsewhere. This subject was considered at some length by the Senate back in the middle 1970s when a committee of which the present Leader of the Opposition and I, amongst others, were members was looking at a national compensation scheme. There is no doubt that industrial accidents are a significant cause of loss both to the individuals and the businesses concerned, and hence to the total community. The question of accident prevention generally is quite complicated. The National Advisory Council for the Handicapped is grappling with the question of how one can get a better co-ordinated national overall approach to accident prevention. There is a series of bodies which concern themselves with accident prevention. The National Safety Council of Australia, the Child Accident Prevention Foundation of Australia, and other bodies, including many in private industry, are concerned to reduce the losses to which the honourable senator has referred.

ANSWER.PARA: The proposal that there be an industrial bulletin is not one with which I am immediately familiar. I will have to refer that part of the question to the appropriate Minister whom I represent in this place for a considered reply, along with the request for information about the need for a uniform national collection of data. The field is one in which there is room for a great deal of initiative, not merely at the Commonwealth level but also, indeed, at the State level. In such areas as the imposition of differential premiums for workers compensation, and so on, action could be taken by a number of governments to tackle the problem to which the honourable senator has referred. I will ask Mr Macphee to consider the questions raised and let the honourable senator have a considered reply.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would the Minister for National Development and Energy not agree that the fundamental reason for conservation of liquid hydrocarbon transport fuels still exists as these are a finite resource? Would the Minister also not agree that there is a possibility that the present liquid hydrocarbon surplus could be replaced by a scarcity later in this decade? If these statements are true, why does the Commonwealth not institute a policy to attain national self-sufficiency with respect to fuels and lubricants over, say, an eight or 10-year period so that Australia will not be held to ransom by a future scarcity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In reply to the first two parts of the question, no doubt Senator MacGibbon will have seen newspaper reports in, I think, today's Press of the International Energy Agency's publication-it is available if he would like to borrow it-on the world energy outlook. That received widespread publication and, indeed, the IEA reflected the answer to the two parts of the question. First of all, there is a strong insistence that the present glut and low pricing of oil is very temporary and that there is a likelihood that in the second half of the decade, unless proper measures are taken, the surplus could turn to scarcity and prices could rise sharply. That is the keynote of the study. It is a thesis my Government and I support entirely. It is true that the question of what will happen in the second part of this decade will depend very largely on how individual nations comport themselves in regard to alternative energy and conservation.

ANSWER.PARA: The whole thrust of the Government's energy policy is to aim at self- sufficiency. I am happy to say that in a wide range of matters, for instance in conservation, in substitution away from oil to coal, to gas, to electricity, in the development of more energy-efficient vehicles, in the switching to liquefied petroleum gas, in the building of pipelines, and in a dozen other matters, progress is being well made. Perhaps the most interesting thing is that import parity pricing has produced a great uplift in exploration. This year twice as many wells will be drilled as were drilled last year. One in every four of the wells drilled recently as wildcat wells has produced petroleum products. It looks as though we can now move more optimistically through this decade. Whilst I would always be cautious of undue optimism, my Department and I believe that we can look forward with confidence over the decade and beyond to getting a national self-sufficiency balance, that is, being able to withstand any threat of cut-off of supply from overseas, which is always likely if a disruption occurs in the Middle East. The chance of developing self-sufficiency in the 1990s is, I think I can say cautiously, one which we ought to be able to achieve in Australia. But we will have to work on it. Above all else, we will have to work to ensure that conservation, whether in industry or the home, is pursued to the fullest extent.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. What proportion of the work force does the Government expect will be unemployed by 30 June 1983? Will this level of unemployment be in excess of the Budget estimates for that period? Will the projected expenditure on unemployment benefits during this financial year be in excess of the planned Budget expenditure? What effect will this have on the domestic surplus planned by the Government? What effect does the Government expect the drought to have on tax receipts?
—Order! I suggest, Senator, that you are asking a lot of very detailed questions and expecting a Minister to give you a great deal of information without notice. You may proceed.

—Thank you, Mr President. I would have expected that the questions I have asked would relate to very pertinent matters which would be before the Government in the course of economic management on every day of its working week. Finally, I ask: Based on the current information, including any projected shortfall in tax revenue, additional planned expenditure on drought relief and unemployment benefits, what does the Government now expect the domestic surplus to be by 30 June 1983?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, for a brief and glorious moment I felt quite flattered. I felt that that was a question that might have been addressed to the Treasurer. I regard it as something of a tribute that I should be expected to sort out the estimate of the deficit from my particular chair dealing with social security. In fact, the honourable senator has raised questions about expenditure in a number of areas in regard to which there is, of course, a degree of uncertainty. As to the proportion of the work force that might be unemployed and hence how many might be receiving unemployment benefits, the Budget Papers were predicated on a figure of 400,000, or certainly close to it. That has been the subject of some discussion in the Senate. I believe it was based on the estimate of the Treasury at the time the Budget was prepared, given the information then available. It may require revision in light of the fact that the figures have gone substantially above that level at a time when, seasonally, one would not have expected that to happen. It is a matter that will require further consideration.

ANSWER.PARA: I would emphasise that, if there were to be any reconsideration of the Budget figure, that again would be, by definition, an estimate. The actual number will be affected by factors that are not entirely within the control of the Government, including international factors such as world economic activity. Also, it will be affected by domestic aspects such as the drought itself, which the honourable senator mentions in his question. In other words, if there is to be a revision of the figure already established as the basis for the Budget calculations that revision, in itself, will by definition depend upon estimates and uncertain future events. However, I will refer the question to the Treasurer , since it is the Treasury which makes these estimates for the Government.

Perhaps I could just add that, with respect to the effect of the drought on tax receipts, again there is of necessity some uncertainty because of the unpredictability of seasonal conditions. We have all been a little cheered by the fact that there have been this past week reasonable falls of rain in some parts of New South Wales. Those falls certainly have not been general. They are not falls such as would enable one to say that the drought had broken in some of the extensive areas of New South Wales that are drought prone, but if they are not merely isolated, and are followed by further falls, some of the worries which the Senate could properly have about the amount required for drought relief may be eased. So with respect to both unemployment and drought relief, which even more is subject to seasonal conditions, we are dealing with areas of some uncertainty. I will refer the question to the Treasurer and seek a considered reply.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Leader of the Government in the Senate inform the Parliament whether the Government is planning a massive advertising campaign to popularise some of the alleged vote catching items in the 1982-83 Budget? Who directed that the advertising campaign be carried out? What will be the cost of the campaign to the Australian taxpayer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As all governments have done in the past, from time to time the Government undertakes a certain amount of advertising to bring to the attention of electors the benefits of particular policies. Of course, the Whitlam Government did that extensively in its day. I am not aware of the nature of any advertising campaign, if there is to be one in the future. But there are certain obvious characteristics of the Budget which provide benefits for people. It would be a very real pity if the people of Australia did not know of the availability of those benefits. Therefore, obviously, there is a real need to bring to their attention those benefits. I will look at the quantum concerned, that is, what size of campaign, if any, is being contemplated and who has directed it.
—The fistful of dollars was a good one! It was a waste of money.
—Since the interjection has been made, I repeat that the best example of using taxpayers' money for advertising is to be found in the days of the previous Labor Government.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. At the peak of hostilities during the Israeli occupation of Beirut it was reported that the Israelis had captured a terrorist training camp and that international terrorist organisations such as the Irish Republician Army, the Red Army, et cetera, were involved in terrorist training activities there. Can the Minister advise whether this report has been confirmed? If it has , what countries and organisations were involved, and how many people from each country were participating? Can the Minister also comment on the significance of international terrorist organisations training in liaison? What effect will the discovery of the camp have on minimising world terrorist activities, or is it likely that the activities of this terrorist training unit have been transferred elsewhere?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Government has seen a number of reports to the effect that, during Israel's invasion of Lebanon in June, the Israeli defence force captured nationals of about 14 countries who were alleged to have links with a number of international terrorist groups. We have no official confirmation of these reports. Training camps are a product of terrorist campaigns, not their source. It must be regretted, therefore, that in the long term the capture of individuals, weapons and armaments will not have much impact on the activities of such groups. Australia, of course, deplores terrorism in all its manifestations wherever it may occur. We have had no official confirmation of some of the reports to which Senator Kilgariff has referred. I am not able to say any more than I have just stated on behalf of the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Communications whether, in the International Year of Disabled Persons, the Government announced an expenditure of $650,000 to provide closed captions on television for the hearing impaired. I refer to the Minister's statement of 26 September this year on the adoption of Teletext as the standard for providing caption services for the hearing impaired. In that statement he said that the Government was not prepared to allow the postponement of a decision on the Teletext standard to stand in the way of closed captioning for the hearing impaired. In view of this determination, why has the Government now set up yet another inquiry to look at the provision of this service? Why did the Government not consult with the parties involved, such as the telecasters and the Australian Caption Centre, and make a decision about this matter? Is the inquiry to commence in 1983? How many years is it expected to be before the report will be available and the Government will make a decision on this matter?

—I trust that the thrust of Senator Button's question goes not towards the determination of the Government to try to assist those who are hearing impaired by means of closed captioning of television, but towards the way in which the inquiry has been set up and how long it will take. I think they are matters which must properly be referred to the Minister whom I represent. I will seek to do that and obtain an early answer for the honourable senator.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CLOSER ECONOMIC RELATIONS WITH NEW ZEALAND: DAIRY INDUSTRY

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. In the closer economic relations discussions with the New Zealand dairy industry, has it been stated or implied that the specialty cheese area is available for increased exports by New Zealand beyond the overall average increment agreed upon? Are there any undertakings that would preclude the existing New Zealand cheddar quota being transferred to put extra pressure on the specialty cheese area, which surely is the only sector of the Australian dairy industry with real growth potential?

—The arrangements for dairy products under the proposed closer economic relationship embrace an understanding agreed to by the representatives of the Australian and New Zealand dairy industries. My advice is that the understanding does not actually make any reference to specialty cheeses. The Memorandum of Understanding between the dairy industries in the two countries provides that the current understanding on New Zealand's level of cheese imports into Australia will continue, with New Zealand sales being related to the growth in the Australian market. For example, if domestic consumption of cheese in Australia is estimated to increase by 5 per cent in the next year, New Zealand can expect to increase its sales of cheese to Australia by an equivalent percentage. The understanding also provides for the cheddar quota of 1,220 tonnes per annum, operating under the present New Zealand-Australia Free Trade Agreement, to be abolished and for future sales of New Zealand cheddar cheese to Australia to be related to market growth. Normally there will be consultation between representatives of the two dairy industries twice a year on matters of mutual interest, including trends in cheese consumption in the Australian market . It is expected, as a normal commercial matter, that New Zealand's marketing strategy will have regard to the preference among consumers for different cheese varieties. If there are difficulties, the understanding provides for consultation between the two industries with the mutual objective of not undermining returns to cheese producers in Australia and not undermining the established price structure in the Australian domestic market. So there does not appear to be anything which would preclude the existing cheese quota being transferred, but it is subject to the safeguard which I have just outlined.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce. Is it a fact that the Government has been seeking a release of some $300m from the Reserve Bank of Australia for home lending purposes since the presentation of the Budget on 17 August? Is it a fact that the Reserve Bank has so far refused to accede to the Government's request and that in this it is supported by the trading banks and buildings societies? What effect has this rejection of the Government's proposal had on housing for Australians and a generation of employment in the housing industry? With the collapse of this strategy over the last two months, what steps has the Federal Government taken to ensure an increasing flow of funds to the housing sector of the magnitude so rashly indicated as being available from the Reserve Bank?

—This is a question which might more properly be addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, who is responsible for that aspect of the housing policy matters announced in the Budget. It is true that in the Budget one of the announcements relevant to housing was that we would be seeking a further release of statutory reserve deposits of $300m for the purpose indicated by the honourable senator in his question. My understanding is that that matter has not yet been responded to by the Reserve Bank, but I will refer the totality of the question to the Treasurer for his consideration and reply, unless my colleague the Minister for Finance wishes to take the matter further.

— Mr President, I wish to add to what Senator Chaney said in reply to the question. As the question from Senator Tate implied, the Government did request in the Budget a release equivalent to one percentage point from the statutory reserve deposits. Of course, the matter is one for consideration by the Board of the Reserve Bank. The terms and conditions on which the banks would make any such funds available would require subsequent discussion with the banks. At this stage it is not possible to indicate any timing of when this matter might be concluded. I can only say that it is the Government's wish to see that the matter is brought to fruition as soon as possible. As Senator Chaney said, we will seek the latest advice on this matter from the Treasurer.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on notice.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. Yesterday Senator Sir John Carrick promised to tell the Senate whether the Prime Minister had asked Mr Costigan to conduct an inquiry into Mr Horgan's affairs, and he has not done so. Apparently he is not going to do so at the end of Question Time.
—Order! Senator, you need not pre-empt any situation in this place . That was not a point of order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I undertook to find out. I did not undertake to find out by any specific time. I will find out, and I will let the Senate know. It is, of course , quite improper, as always, of Senator Walsh to draw quite wrong conclusions from the matter. I will let him know.

—Earlier today Senator Robertson asked me a question in connection with the Alice Springs-Darwin railway. I now have a response from the Minister for Transport and Construction, who indicates that the Commonwealth has not withdrawn any support for the railway.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matters of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matters of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Button proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need for a system of public funding of election campaigns and full disclosure of donations, or other assistance, to political parties and candidates.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Approximately 18 months ago the Prime Minister of Australia (Mr Malcolm Fraser) was going overseas and before he went he described systems of public funding of elections as corrupt. In the course of his overseas visit, he visited eight countries, including the United States of America, where he saw President Reagan. All of those countries have systems of public funding of election campaigns. It is quite extraordinary that the Australian situation should be so different from that of many other countries in which public funding systems have been introduced. Mr President, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a document entitled 'Public Subsidies to Parties and Candidates in Selected Democratic Countries, 1979' which is taken from the book Democracy at the Polls-a Comparative Study of Competitive National Elections edited by David Butler and others.

A column has been left blank where the stated feature is not present in a given country, where the author was unable to ascertain whether it is present, or where an entry might be more misleading than useful ( thus, through the penalties on the books for infringement of financing rules in France includes fines, cuts in subsidies, and imprisonment, the 'Sanctions' column has been left blank for France since these penalties are not generally enforced).

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion is brought forward at this particular time because for the first time in the history of the Liberal Party of Australia we were hopeful that there might be some bipartisan approach on this important issue. The reason for that is quite clear. Recent events in Australia have raised an urgent need for public funding of political parties. For example, the release of the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union is enough to make arguments for public funding conclusive. It would not be necessary for the Liberal Party of Australia to have its fund raising committees chaired by known tax evaders if there were a system of public funding of political parties in existence. We have learnt in this Parliament of hundreds of millions of dollars of avoided tax through bottom-of- the-harbour schemes and other schemes. It used to be a slogan at election times, when parties put forward their programs for the election, 'Where is the money coming from?' People are now asking in relation to the Liberal Party and some of its very prominent members: 'Where is the money going to, and where is the money which the Liberal Party is able to spend at elections coming from?'
—Many Liberal members also support public funding.

—I understand that. Many members of the Liberal Party support public funding. The classic example is the New South Wales branch of the Liberal Party, which supported public funding after having opposed it in the context of the last New South Wales election.
—Except that Mr Wran tried--

—Not at all. Senator Walters should get her facts right. That party is now a recipient of very substantial sums of public money to finance the election campaigns of the Liberal Party in New South Wales. It is likely that some people might assume, in this community, where hundreds of millions of dollars have been obtained by people through tax evasion, that much of that money has found its way into the coffers of the Liberal Party. Let us take the case of Mr Horgan in Western Australia, who is said by the financial editor of the Sydney Morning Herald, amongst others, having conducted an analysis, to have evaded $7m in tax in four years. As Chairman of the fund raising committee of the Western Australia Liberal Party, it is fair to assume that he would set an example to his colleagues in the Liberal Party in Western Australia and make some of that $7m available to the Liberal Party.

SPEECH.PARA: This motion is brought forward in this context because it might be now, at this particular point in history, that the Liberal Party would be seen, in terms of its public image and esteem, to be advantaged by these sorts of allegations not being capable of being made against it, as indeed would the Australian Labor Party in similar situations. The Labor Party, for example, in the last Victorian election, received-I think it is common knowledge-$100,000 from the teachers unions in Victoria. That was a matter which was publicly disclosed. It ought to be disclosed so that people can make a judgment about the Government in terms of its subsequent decision-making as to where the money it got came from.

What we are advocating here is a system of public funding of the kind which exists in many countries throughout the world, and particularly more locally in New South Wales. Enormous levels of expenditure are involved in election campaigns by major political parties. Those levels of expenditure place great demands on the party systems, which are essential, by common agreement, in this Parliament for the proper working of a democratic system. So it is not just a question of having political parties funded in order that they can operate correctly and with propriety. It is a question of political parties being above suspicion in respect of the sources of their donations and in respect of the decisions which they make which might favour particular interest groups in the community and which might be related to the sources of those donations. Governments will not escape the odium of that sort of charge, that they are open to pressure of a particular kind, while there is no public disclosure and no public funding to make parties independent of outside sponsorship.

The fact is that in Australia manipulation of political parties remains a constant threat to the democratic system because funds are channelled in secret to political parties and to such shonky outfits as the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation in Queensland. New South Wales has presented something of an example to Australia on the question of public funding. After a great deal of breast beating by the Liberal Party, it came round to the view that public funding was desirable; this last thing being the greatest treason in the Liberal Party-to do the right thing for the wrong reason.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did Mr Wran do? He tried to stop it.
—No, he set up a committee, which gave the party the money.
—Oh!
—Did the Liberal Party get the money or not? Tell us that.
—He did his best to stop them getting the money.

—The fact is that within weeks of the election the Liberal Party had put its hands out for $484,000, which it ultimately got. Since I am needled about the Liberal Party in New South Wales, lest the suspicion of tax avoidance money reaching the coffers of the Liberal Party be not raised in the context of this debate, let me just mention in passing the whole question of the so-called Liberal Party access clubs in New South Wales, which makes it quite clear that tax avoidance is not a new thing to the Liberal Party in that State. Let me also mention the extraordinary remark of the Liberal Party's principal fund raiser in New South Wales, Mr Valder, who said that the money that he collected for the New South Wales branch of the Liberal Party would be laundered through other States in order to avoid the legislation in New South Wales.
