What an extraordinary statement for a prominent official of the Liberal Party to make.

SPEECH.PARA: In the context of this debate I want to direct my remarks to two issues, although my colleagues will be speaking on particular aspects of public funding. One issue is the desirability of public funding of political parties for election campaigns, and public funding according to the votes obtained by a political party at the last election. The other issue of importance in the context of this debate is the need for the disclosure of the financial interests of Ministers of a government and members of parliament. Integrity, honesty and adherence to proper standards in public life are matters that increasingly concern the electorate in Australia. They could not have concerned an electorate more at any time in the history of Australian government than they do now, after seven years of Malcolm Fraser's Government in this country. People are right to look at this Government and think that for many of its Ministers integrity is a long way down the line of priorities.

Only in the last fortnight the Prime Minister has talked a lot about what he calls the importance of the principle of fairness in Liberal Party philosophy. The principle of fairness means nothing unless it can be seen to operate and can be seen by the public to be operating. If the public can see a principle of fairness operating, whether it be in relation to taxation matters or whether it be related to the sources of funds of political parties, there is no better beneficiary in Australia than the Liberal Party, from which the words 'the principle of fairness' sound like hypocrisy to most members of the Australian community. There is no better illustration of the need for disclosure by Ministers and members of parliament of their own financial interests.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I draw attention to standing Order 419. I note that Senator Button is referring to public disclosure of ministerial interests and items of that kind, but that has absolutely no relevance to the point under discussion by the Senate.
—What are you coming at?
—I think there is some relationship in the matters raised by Senator Button. There is no point of order.

—What I am talking about is the importance of disclosure, not only of donations but also of financial interests. I think that that is a matter which ought not to be avoided by a responsible Minister in the Fraser Government .
—Did I say I was avoiding it?

—What was the point of the point of order? On this question of disclosure, the Labor Party is committed to a system of public funding of political parties in order that spurious donations may not flow into its coffers or the coffers of the Liberal Party and in order that the public might see that the political parties which are the mainstay of the parliamentary system are operating in a fair and honest manner. We are also concerned to see that the principle of public declaration of pecuniary interests by members of parliament and others holding office is implemented as a matter of government policy. In office a Labor Government would legislate for public funding and for a public register of pecuniary interests of members of parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer the Senate to what has happened under this Government in relation to that question. In 1975 the Joint Committee on Pecuniary Interests of Members of Parliament was established to report on the declaration of interests of members of parliament and Ministers. It is extraordinary to see what happened to the members of that Committee. Some of them were Liberal, some National Country Party and some Labor members. Their report was unanimous. The members of that Committee included Senator Marriott, who subsequently lost pre-selection in Tasmania; Mr E. L. Robinson, who subsequently resigned from the Ministry; Senator Sheil, who was in the ministry for 24 hours, was sacked, and subsequently left this place in the context of an election; and Senator Webster, who was sent overseas to fill the post of High Commissioner in New Zealand. What an unhappy record for the members of that Committee. Of course, as in all matters, the other member who still remains is the Minister for Primary Industry , Mr Peter Nixon, the great survivor in this Parliament. Mr Nixon is still here. Let us look at what that Committee recommended to the Parliament on the sorts of decisions which ought to be taken in relation to this matter. First, the Committee recommended that members of parliament should disclose the names of all companies in which they had a beneficial interest in shares, no matter how insignificant.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has that to do with the matter of public importance?

—I know that what I am saying is a source of great pain to Senator Walters, but she should let me finish. Secondly, the Committee recommended that members should disclose the location of any real property in which they have a beneficial interest. Thirdly, it recommended that members should declare the names of all companies of which they are members, and fourthly, that members of parliament should provide all this information on a public parliamentary register. Nothing came of any of these recommendations. They were brought into the Parliament in 1976 with the support of--

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I know that a similar point of order has already been taken, but could you point out to me what relevance this has to the matter of public importance which is before the Senate?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The letter before the Chair which is being discussed as a matter of public importance states:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need for a system of public funding of election campaigns and full disclosure of donations, or other assistance, to political parties and candidates.
I believe that for the purpose of this debate it has to be read in the broadest possible terms. Therefore there is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was saying that the Joint Committee of this Parliament, which included Mr Nixon and others, recommended a system of disclosure of financial interests of members of parliament, and particularly Ministers. When the Fraser Government came to power it did nothing about that report. When Fraser came to power in 1975 he said that under him there would be the highest standards of government in this country and nothing but the highest standards would do. At the same time he ignored this report of parliamentarians. He shelved it and appointed another committee, which was headed by Sir Nigel Bowen, a former Attorney-General, to devise a code of conduct for members of parliament. That was the Bowen Committee of Inquiry concerning Public Duty and Private Interest, and its report was tabled in Parliament on 22 November 1979. By any measure it was a mild report. Its recommendations would have imposed no great burdens on Ministers. They did not have to disclose anything publicly. All they had to do was disclose their interests to the Prime Minister. The suggestion that interests should be disclosed in secret to the Prime Minister was a typical example, if I might borrow an expression, of putting Dracula in charge of a blood bank. The report also recommended that the Prime Minister should take certain action in relation to Ministers if they did disclose such an interest. It said that a Minister should not hold shares in a company which deals with his Department. It also recommended, of course, that members of parliament also should disclose interests.

SPEECH.PARA: On 22 September 1981 I asked Senator Sir John Carrick what the Government was doing about the Bowen report recommendations, which were tabled on 22 November 1979. In reply to that question, Senator Carrick said that the Government was moving to bring into the Parliament recommendations for the implementation of the Bowen report in relation to members of parliament. That indicates a glacier- like speed in dealing with this important issue, surpassed only by the speed with which this Government has dealt with the question of tax evasion. It took seven years to deal with that issue, and it has taken four years to deal with the disclosure of pecuniary interests of members of parliament. Why the great haste? It is because members of this Government, members of the Liberal Party in Australia, do not want these things disclosed, and for very obvious reasons. None of the recommendations of that report, other than this half-hearted soppy thing about a Minister reporting his financial interests to the Prime Minister, have ever been implemented. But we find Mr Nixon, the signatory of the original report, making recommendations about Murray-Goulburn Co-operative Ltd, a company in which he was a shareholder, and dealing with that matter without declaring his interest to the Prime Minister. There are numerous other examples of similar conduct by Ministers in this Government. All of these points go to the question of the integrity of the political process in Australia.

One of the first tasks of a Labor government, when it is elected, will be to try to restore credibility and honesty to government in Australia. That will be its very first task, because no government in this country can do anything while it is so lacking in credibility, while it is so incredible as the Fraser Government is in relation to the behaviour of its officials in respect of moneys which are raised and donated to the political party and in respect of the behaviour of its Ministers. So the first task of a Labor government will be to try to restore credibility to the whole system of government.

On the question of public funding of political parties, I have said that we are similarly committed to the introduction of a system of public funding. In introducing such a system, we will be joining most of the major democracies of the Western world who do not find anything particularly offensive about public funding and about public disclosure of where the donations made to a political party come from. Australia will be well served if such a system is introduced in this country and it is not run away from by people like members of the Fraser Government who are concerned to protect their private financial interests rather than developing a good process of government in Australia which has the respect of the people because of its intrinsic integrity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, I should point out for the information of honourable senators that, at the request of the President, the level of oxygen flow within the Senate is being checked. Two officers of the Senate are now carrying out that check. I call the Minister for Veterans' Affairs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I rise in an attempt to draw the debate back to the issue that really is before the Senate. The Australian Labor Party, in its matter of public importance, is proposing in the first place to discuss the public funding of election campaigns and the full disclosure of donations or other assistance to political parties and candidates. While I understand your decision, Mr Deputy President, in respect of the broader point that you made in regard to assistance to candidates, I believe that the essential thrust of the matter as it is spelled out relates more importantly to the public funding area and also to the disclosure of donations. It will be upon those matters that I will be concentrating most of my remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button sought, in the course of his remarks, to denigrate the Liberal Party in various ways. He drew attention to matters which have occurred recently and sought to link those in some way to the electoral benefit flowing directly to the Liberal Party. One can only refute that kind of allegation. One has only to state quite clearly the code that all Liberal Party members of Parliament are bound to, that is, that no Liberal Party parliamentary member has any knowledge whatsoever of the amounts contributed to Liberal Party campaigns by any person whatsoever. It is a firm requirement that that information be not disclosed in any way to any Liberal candidate who stands for public office. That system has been laid down for a number of years. It has applied ever since I have been a member of Parliament. Certainly I have no understanding or any knowledge whatsoever of the campaign donations received by my party in South Australia or, for that matter, in Canberra, at the Federal level. I have no knowledge of funds provided by any donor, whether in my own State or anywhere else. It is certainly a clear understanding of all Liberal members of Parliament that that is the situation. It is something to which the party maintains rigid adherence.

TALK.START.PARA: —It also applies to the National Country Party.

—As my colleague Senator Collard mentions, the same requirement applies to the National Country Party and its various branches throughout the Commonwealth. It is a total canard and is totally misrepresentative of the facts for Senator Button to make the kind of allegation that he has been making. I resent it, as does any member of the Liberal-National Country Party Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us turn to the real issues that are before us in terms of this matter of public importance. First of all, there is the matter of public funding and how that is to be developed in any system. No information on the development of this system is provided in the statement of the matter of public importance, and no details are provided as to how it can be achieved. But let us just consider one or two of the philosophical points that are connected with this matter. First of all, it represents a direct charge on all taxpayers who may be contributing to the benefit of political parties. This means that--

TALK.START.PARA: —So does tax evasion.

—Of course. But those people also get the benefit of it. But when people are bound to make contributions for purposes over which they have no control, about which they have no understanding, no knowledge, no sense of spiritual relationship or whatever, it seems to me to be denying them their freedom of choice in the most fundamental way. They have no opportunity properly to express their freedom of choice.
—Mr Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I do not know whether lack of oxygen is involved or what, but the clock has not moved since the speaker for the Government began.
—The Minister started at 3.38 p.m.

—I was making the point that freedom of choice is the fundamental issue in any democracy. That is what is under challenge when funds are being provided by the taxpayer direct to political parties. Senator Button sought to make the point that this was a well recognised practice in other countries. He did not give us any examples by which we might be able to compare Australia with those other nations. But let us take one example. Let us take the United States and the question of public funding for the election of the President. That is probably the most significant election on the world scene. The amount of money that was provided in 1980 for the election involving Mr Carter and Mr Reagan was, I think, in the order of something like $US50m. I think that a different set of circumstances applies there than in the case of parliamentary elections. It is clear that in the United States, while there have been demands for public funding of both congressional and state legislature elections, that has not come to pass for the very simple reason that in the United States a prospective president seeks to command the popular vote right across all State boundaries, right across the country. That means that he is seeking, perhaps, a plurality of something like 50 million votes. He needs a far greater appeal than a party organisation can sustain right across the nation. When we relate that to a population of something approaching 250 million people, that is a very significant consideration. It is noted that in the United States the Government has not extended public funding to parliamentary, that is congressional, or other state elections. I think it is important to draw attention to that difference. Clearly, a different set of circumstances applies there. In our country our government is formed within the Parliament, within both Houses of Parliament, and the Leader of the Government depends on the existence of a majority in his favour in the House of Representatives. That clearly is a different issue. The circumstances are different. I draw the attention of honourable senators to that because I believe it really thrusts at the heart of the very point that Senator Button was seeking to make.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us consider some of the other alternatives that have been developed for the Australian circumstances. First of all is the kind of indirect assistance that is given to political parties in the way of-

TALK.START.PARA: —What about all the Buicks on Kangaroo Island?

—If Senator McLaren would only shut up for a little while we might be able to get some facts before us. The fact is that various indirect public assistance measures are provided for political parties. We all know of the availability of free time offered by an independent broadcasting organisation, the Australian Broadcasting Commission, for each political party. Time is made available to parties which already have seats within the Parliament . That seems to be well accepted on all sides. There is, of course, the provision-without too much scrutiny-of offices and electoral assistance for senators and members of parliament, researchers, secretaries and people of that kind. There is the provision at public expense of the VIP flight for the leaders of all parties during election campaigns. Of course, there is the opportunity for people to listen to the radio and hear a public broadcast of parliamentary proceedings. We all know how much benefit that is to us, as members of parliament, in getting our message across.

SPEECH.PARA: Another very important point in this indirect area is the very real contribution of taxpayers via the tax deduction applicable to contributions to trade unions by their members, portion of which ends up as a political levy payable to the Australian Labor Party. In that sense the ALP has a very strong advantage compared with any other political party in this country. There is a tax benefit for contributions to the ALP. There is no like provision which assists any member of the Liberal Party, the National Country Party or, as far as I know, the Australian Democrats. I think that point needs to to be made very strongly in this place. The Australian Labor Party is the only party which receives a direct contribution from the taxpayer in that sense as the law exists today. This is achieved through the indirect method-a very surreptitious method, some people might say-of a levy made on a front organisation in the form of the trade union movement. In that way the Labor Party is already benefiting. I resent strongly the kind of allegation made by Senator Button that the Liberal Party is somehow getting a benefit from funds on which tax has been avoided or which have been through some kind of laundering when the system to which I have referred operates and is known to have operated over a long time.

There are many arguments against public funding of political parties and my colleagues will develop them as time goes on. However, some other points mentioned by Senator Button need to be answered as well. First and foremost, he said that an information service developed within the Government would somehow seek to assist the election of Liberal and National Country Party candidates. He referred particularly to the disclosure recently that $1.5 will be made available to the Australian Taxation Office to inform members of the public about the new taxation benefits that will be flowing to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was made available to Mr Howard.

—There is no secret about this. As long ago as 3 February of this year the Minister for Administrative Services, the Honourable Kevin Newman, laid down a statement in Parliament which spelt out quite clearly the Government 's intention to upgrade its information services.
—A propaganda machine.

—That does not deserve any kind of answer. This flowed directly from a paper laid on the table of the House of Representatives, and I believe also this place, which clearly spelt out the need for improved information services. It highlighted the problems and difficulties that government-and I am talking of government in the generic sense, not of a particular government in the narrow sense of the word-has in getting full value for money spent on advertising and getting quality information services for the money committed to staff and other resources. Various suggestions were made in respect of the ways in which those services could be upgraded. The Government fully disclosed its reasons for taking up those suggestions which it adopted. The initiative involving the Taxation Office to which Senator Button referred is just one part of a total commitment to an improvement and upgrading information service right across the board.

SPEECH.PARA: Last financial year the total expenditure for departmental advertising arranged through the Australian Government Advertising Service was of the order of $17.5m . Among the major items in this total were $5.3m for Defence Force recruiting, $ 2.8m for loans and Australian savings bonds promotions, $700,000 for the census of 1981, $1.3m for petrol conservation campaigns-and who could deny that that is not a very logical and reasonable objective in these times of rising fuel prices ?-and $601,000 for advertising health insurance changes. That, of course, is a most reasonable thing, given the degree of change that has occurred in recent times. Roughly $700,000 was spent in respect of plant and animal quarantine, which is so vital to our primary industry, particularly at this time when it is under such pressing difficulty because of the drought. In addition, $1m was spent on campaigns connected with the International Year of Disabled Persons. Do any members of the Opposition oppose any of those expenditures? Do they say right here and now that they would campaign against those kinds of expenditures which bring to the attention of the people the most important programs of this Government relating to the welfare of the nation as a whole and the individuals who constitute it? I particularly mention that another $4m has been used in respect of Press displays and classified advertising of notices, tenders, auctions and vacant positions. I do not think that any senator or any government would disagree with that kind of expenditure. I challenge Senator Button to come back in here and claim that he would knock out all of that expenditure if, unfortunately for the people of Australia, his party became the next Government.

The kind of money that is being spent on advertising at the national level will , it is hoped, achieve a far more effective result in terms of getting the message across to people. I instance again the taxation advantages that will start on 1 November. Although the Labor Party has sought to impute some sinister motive to this activity, the fact is that many fairly complicated moves are involved in these new taxation measures. There is a new eligibility for home loan interest rebates. That is a most important benefit for Australians, but it is also quite complicated. It is important that Australians understand how it will work. It is important that we allocate moneys in order to educate people as to their eligibility. Would the Labor Party deny that that ought to be done? Is it not important that these things are brought to the attention of Australians so that they properly understand what their entitlements are under the law? There are other more complicated items as well which affect the taxation system. Health insurance payments will now be tax rebatable. Other items relate to investment incentives for industry. We have spoken in this place on previous occasions about other measures, all of which are of very considerable importance .

Let us just compare some of the expenditure on advertising made by the Labor Government to see how relevant Senator Button's argument really is. I have made my calculations rather quickly and I acknowledge that there might be some small discrepancies. But I believe them to be fundamentally sound. Let us compare in real terms the expenditure on advertising. The Labor Government in 1974-75, which was its last full year of office, spent the equivalent of $20.4m on advertising. The expenditure in 1980-81 by this Government in the same terms was $21.07m. That means there has been a very marginal rise in real terms of the order of $600,000-a very small sum when one compares the amounts of expenditures overall. However, I hasten to add that there are other issues as well. For instance, during the period of the Labor Government there was a very considerable expenditure on Press secretaries and other information systems. When this Government came to office there was a very significant decrease in the number of people employed in ministerial offices for the purposes of propagandising, as Senator Childs would have us believe. There have been considerable offsets to that $600,000 advertising rise of which we have just spoken in lower staff costs for ministerial offices than existed under Labor. It is of very significant importance for us to recall those matters when we compare the kinds arguments that are put in this place by Senator Button which seek, by way of smear, unsubstantiated rumour and allegation, to undermine the integrity of the Liberal Party and this Government. Those allegations are not justified by proper argument; colourful langauge is used to illustrate what Senator Button claims is the lack of integrity of honourable senators on this side of the chamber. That the Opposition should conduct itself in that way is resented by members on this side of the chamber.

One or two other points do need to be made following the honourable senator's very tiresome speech which did not touch at all on the matter of public importance in relation to the disclosure of donations to political parties. An argument is going around that there is some major advantage in a government providing funds to political parties for election purposes as opposed to private persons providing funds. I mention the point that people may see their money going into causes which offend their consciences, in fact, they would be contributing to help causes to which they had direct opposition. I believe that is a fundamental denial of democracy and the freedom of choice in this country. One has only to consider some of the issues that arise in this place upon which no doubt members of the Opposition hold very clear views in their consciences and to compare those views with the views held this side of the chamber. Would honourable senators on either side of the chamber like to see their money used in an election campaign to advance an issue in which they did not believe? This is the test of democracy and freedom of choice. This is the ultimate point at which democracy functions in this country. We need to consider that point most closely.

Senator Button referred to loopholes being found in the system and, by that means, people avoiding disclosures. There is the question of all kinds of anonymous donations, provisions of assistance in kind and so on which can avoid the system altogether. I think that what is needed more in this country is not so much regulation as such but rather a different attitude to the question of integrity in government, in political parties and so on. (Quorum formed).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —One wondered what the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) was discussing because it was not until the last few minutes of his 20-minute oration that he dealt with the subject matter which is before the Senate today; that is, the need to establish a system of public funding of election campaigns. The Minister spent most of his time defending the Government's own publicity activities rather than addressing himself to what we believe are the corrupting influences of private funding of political parties. The events and revelations of the last six weeks which have surrounded the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union have shaken the foundations of the Fraser Government and undermined any confidence which the millions of ordinary taxpayers of Australia have had in the justice and fairness of our taxation system.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen scandal after scandal, indiscretion heaped upon indiscretion and arrogant and unethical behaviour develop into a cynical abuse of power. There is a direct relationship between what has happened and the way in which the Liberal and National Country parties are funded in respect of election campaigns. The matters concerning the meat substitution racket, the Australian Dairy Corporation, medifraud, Customs impropriety and tax evasion are relevant. My intention is to make some connection between all of these factors-all of these revelations-and the nature of the conservation parties, their supporters, their ethics and their policies because the way in which the conservative parties finance their massive election campaigns is related to these matters. The leader of the conservative parties, the Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, is now strutting about as the conscience of the business world. It is as if the sins of his followers will be absolved by the purity of his utterances if only we will believe in him.

Let us look at the facts about the Liberal and National Country parties and how they are funded by their big business friends, their spivs, in the business world and in turn by the Australian taxpayer. That is what this debate is about. The great tenet of Liberal Party funding-it has been repeated somewhat by Senator Messner today-is that parliamentarians remain aloof from and in blissful ignorance of any donors and donations. Mr Menzies insisted on this. Eggleton and other Liberal Party bureacrats enjoy repeating it often in these sorts of debates. What absolute balderdash! Does anyone believe that large amounts of money are invested for political purposes by businesses or businessmen without the expectation of some return? Public funding, after all, is about honest funding of election campaigns. Recently in my area-in the electorate of Cook- supporters of the Liberal Party organised what they quaintly called the access club. One paid one's money, received a tax rebate and access to a couple of Ministers of the Fraser Government. No doubt that access would not be confined just to discussing personal pleasantries. Mr Tom Burrell, the Chairman of the Assembly of Australian Business Organisations, accepts the view of the Cook access club that donors to the Liberal Party should not be seen as neutral philanthropists, always ready to dip into their pockets for the cause without any desire for favours. Soon after the 1980 election Mr Burrell said:

If political parties are to truly represent the interests of their members and establish policies that are acceptable to them then any outside funding will significantly reduce the party's responsiveness to their members' desires.

Mr Burrell is under no such illusions about the connection between members of the Liberal and National Country parties and the policies of their Ministers. Ironically, the outside funding to which he referred concerned public funding, the one method by which corrupting influences can actually be removed from our political institutions. That has become an urgent consideration. No one should live in a fantasy land of disbelief that the same connections are not currently being activated. the Western Australian branch of the Liberal Party is in a state of excitement more akin to panic over the Costigan revelations. It is clear that that branch of the Liberal Party has been taken over by a bunch of corporate crooks. The stable door stunt of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and Mr Fraser's recently aquired sense of ethics regarding retrospectivity for tax criminals has prompted some calling in of the accounts. It is well known that enormous pressure has been applied based on past generosities and future promises. It seems that this has had some effect. We have seen the reverberations go through the Liberal Party as those who have been its supporters and its financial backers are now expressing great concern about the attempts to overcome the problems associated with tax evasion.

What are the identities of those donors and the nature of their donations? Of course the Liberal and National Country parties do not like the names of their benefactors to get out, but it does not take an intellectual leviathan or a Philip Marlowe to know who they are. For starters, in the mid-1970s the same Mr Fraser caused the then leader of the Liberal Party, Mr Snedden, some heartburn when he did a little fund raising of his own and for his own aggrandisement. Another ex-Prime Minister, Mr William McMahon is know to have raised half a million dollars in 1972 in a last-ditch effort to stem the tide. One wonders what the interest on that investment might have cost had the Australian Labor Party not won government then. So much for distancing Ministers from donors, benefactors and supporters, as this Government's contribution to the debate suggests!

A great deal of money itself comes from the taxpayers, care of the taxation system and the ethics of the business world so beloved by Mr Fraser. One old and well tried method is to inflate the advertising bill to cover political donations and then claim it as a tax concession. Multi-National Rip-offs Incorporated, tells its advertising agency to increase its bill by, say, $100, 000. The agency then does $100,000 worth of free advertising for the Conservative parties and claims that as a tax deduction and, what is more, gets it-not the lousy $50 or $60 that Senator Messner suggested ordinary wage and salary earners receive in their returns. The taxpayer, therefore, is de facto funding the conservatives' election campaign.

Another use of the tax deductible advertising technique is apparent with the infamous Bjelke-Petersen Foundation of Queensland, soon to be joined by a new fund called the National Free Foundation in New South Wales; both instruments of the National Party and its bagmen. By paying for an advertisement in the Foundation's bulletin at an exorbitant rate a company can claim such a donation as advertising expenditure and hence as a tax deduction. The Bjelke-Petersen Foundation has become one of the ugliest blots on the whole Australian democratic scene. It has reached the stage of being an embarrassment even to the Liberal Party in Queensland. The current President of that organisation, Mr Herron, has gone on record as saying that the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation is blatantly corrupt and corruptible. When I asked a question of Mr O'Reilly at the Senate Estimates Committee C hearing on Monday night he had to admit that these expenses and advertising accounts are being paid in respect of a whole number of activities of businesses and are accepted as tax deductions without question by the Australian Taxation Office. What gall then do these same people, who oppose what the Labor Party is suggesting, have in accusing the fairest, most open and most accountable of political funding procedures-public funding-of being in some way a denial of justice and democracy. It is a case of telling the biggest lie and telling it so often in the hope that eventually it will be believed. Because of the secrecy which surrounds these fund raising instruments it is impossible to ascertain how much money has been funnelled into the Liberal and National Country Parties' coffers for political purposes through these means. This also accounts for the ferocity of the conservative opposition to the public disclosure of donations. Of course it explains how the Liberal and National Country Parties are able to spend twice as much as the Labor Party in their election campaigns. Can we ascertain that these parties can therefore outspend the ALP during these elections by that ratio? That difference, using the tax deductibility system described above, is in fact made up by the taxpayers of Australia and that is de facto public funding.

A measure of the conservatives' ethics and respect for the law-electoral or taxation-can be gauged by their response to the new public disclosure and funding legislation in New South Wales. The Leader of the New South Wales Country Party, in attacking the legislation, listed the ways in which the law could be circumvented. These included businessmen calling donations 'public relations' and the funnelling of donations through interstate connections. What did we find a year after the New South Wales State election when that funding legislation was in operation? The New South Wales Liberal Party received most of its funding from its federal secretariat here in Canberra and, along with other methods as previewed by Mr Punch, managed to keep its donors cloaked in secrecy. I wonder how much advertising money was supplied by the taxpayer in that recent election.

The long-suffering taxpayer has now also been treated to the relevations about sales tax evasion being perpetrated by various crooks around Australia. As the automotive industry said through in its own spokesmen: 'Some of these people pay tax according to their level of morality'. Mr Fraser will have to have a talk to them. Yet the industry has been urging the Treasurer, Mr Howard, for many months to do something about this fraud which has cost the Australian taxpayer an estimated $250m. So far this Government has reacted in a tortoise-like fashion. Again, who are the beneficiaries of this evasion? They are accountants, lawyers, businessmen-typical Liberal Party backers; the very same people who believe that their positions are protected by supporting a Liberal Party Government. How naive one must be expected to be to think that there are not strings attached to the money that reaches the Liberal Party coffers and that those strings are not now unravelling before our eyes as a result of the actions within the Liberal- National Country Party Government.

The latest in this litany of abuse and deception is the emerging story of Medibank fraud. For years these unscrupulous members of the medical profession, who are placed to take advantage of our tax system, have been doing just that. The Australian Medical Association official report states that over $100m a year could well have been stolen from ordinary taxpayers and, like the painters and dockers, most members of the medical profession are supporters of the Liberal Party. In 1975, for example, before the election of that year, the Executive Secretary of the Australian Association of Surgeons wrote to 700 surgeons in Victoria and told them that they had to give large sums of money to the Liberal Party to protect their interests. Just to prove nothing has changed, a few weeks ago the Executive Secretary of the Australian College of Opthalmologists wrote to his colleagues in New South Wales asking for big money, again to protect what he saw as their interests, lodged as they are with the Liberal Party, with the Fraser Government. Similarly, who are the beneficiaries of the missing money of the outrageous Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd affair, where millions of dollars have been lost in a Singapore bank account?

These sorts of things that are happening surely point out to this Government the need to re-examine its attitude to public funding to remove once and for all such influences from the way in which governments are elected. These are the people and organisations who finance the conservative parties of this country using taxpayers' money, unknown and unseen; the multinational companies, unethical businessmen, unscrupulous doctors, the rich and the powerful and the old boys network, all working to misuse the spoils by supporting and helping to elect a government of their choice.

During an Estimates committee hearing a few weeks ago we were given some insight into how this Government puts aside something like $15m just for the purpose of selling its own electoral policies. Honourable senators ought to have no illusions at all that the Fraser Government, with all of its powerful and rich supporters, with all the bad smell of tax evasion and political patronage, has still to set aside in the current Estimates $1.5m to spend during November for the purpose of popularising the so-called 1982-83 Budget. I urge consideration of public funding.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I can certainly understand the Opposition seeking to force on all Australians increased taxation in order to fund its election campaigns. It has been forcing certain sections of the community to do so for many years. It finds that it is on to a good thing and now wants to force all Australians, through the payment of additional taxation, to fund its election campaigns. In Australia we have a system of compulsory unionism, and many unions are affiliated with the Australian Labor Party. Thus, there is a certain compulsion upon union members, whether they be supporters of the Labor Party or not, to fund that party. Under compulsory unionism the union forces employers to agree to employ only union members, who must then pay into the Labor Party's coffers. How many parents struggling to bring up their children are now forced, whether they be socialist-minded or not, to pay for Labor Party election campaigns? I can assure the Opposition that it is completely repulsive to those who have strong anti-socialist and anti- communist feelings to be forced to fund Labor's campaigns.

—I wish to raise a point of order. What Senator Walters is saying is completely untruthful. No trade union is forced to contribute to the Labor Party; it is all done by way of voluntary affiliation. There is no compulsion. The honourable senator is misleading the Parliament.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—It is not a voluntary contribution at all. Members of affiliated unions are forced to contribute to the Labor Party. There is no voluntary unionism or contribution to the party in that regard; it is all compulsory. In Australia particularly, with its two parties-Labor, with its philosophy of complete socialism, and Liberal, with its philosophy of true, free democracy-we find that certain sections of the community will not under any circumstances agree to having taxes put aside in order to fund a socialist government. At what cost to the taxpayers is this to take place? The likely cost has not been mentioned by the Opposition. If we examine the only experience of the system available in Australia, that of New South Wales, we find that in the year prior to the last election $6.3m of the taxpayers' money was put aside to fund publicly that campaign. What would be the cost of a Federal campaign, conducted throughout Australia? How many extra millions would be added to the tax burden of Australians in order to fund a Federal campaign? I can assure honourable senators opposite that people who earn their money feel that they can spend it far more wisely than by putting it towards any party's campaign. If they have any doubt on that score they should ask the people. Why does it not carry out a few surveys, as certainly happened in New South Wales? A gallup poll conducted in New South Wales in November 1980 revealed that 71 per cent of those polled objected strongly to public funding, to their tax payments being used to fund any election. Again, a Sydney Morning Herald poll of May 1979 indicated that 75 per cent of the people of that State were completely opposed to the use of their money to fund a party in whose philosophy they did not believe. If the Opposition believes that it is on to such a good thing I suggest that it ask the people generally. Labor Party supporters may well go for it, but I can assure the Opposition that the swinging voters, upon whose support both it and honourable senators on this side of the chamber depend, do not go for it at all. The 75 per cent poll figure proves that.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the question of the disclosure of interest. Senator Button seemed to devote his whole speech to a discussion of the personal interests of members of parliament. Of course, that has nothing to do with the matter before us, which refers to 'disclosure of donations, or other assistance, to political parties and candidates'. Dr Ernie Chaples, who was perhaps one of the most ardent supporters of public funding in New South Wales, following the New South Wales election presented a paper to the 24th Annual Conference of the Australasian Political Studies Association and was reported in the Australian Financial Review of 26 August, just a couple of months ago, as saying that this type of legislation is wide open to abuse; that it is not able to be implemented in a correct fashion. This is substantiated in the headlines that Senator Button so cleverly tried to avoid mentioning. I refer to the headlines in the Sydney Morning Herald following the New South Wales election which read: 'Wran vows to block Liberals' $480,000'. The accompanying article states:

The Premier, Mr Wran, vowed yesterday to prevent the New South Wales Liberal Party receiving $484,000 for last year's election campaign, despite a decision by the Election Funding Authority clearing the way for payment.
It is that sort of abuse to which this kind of legislation is open. Another article, a couple of months later, read:

A series of letters leaked to the Herald yesterday show the State Government had made a concerted effort to prevent the New South Wales Liberal Party receiving almost $500,000 in public funding for last year's State election campaign.

So we have the New South Wales Government saying that elections ought to be publicly funded and then the Premier trying to deny public funding being passed to the party in opposition. That is the sort of abuse that we have learnt to expect from the Labor Party.

The disclosure of financial support for a party is against the privacy of interests that this Government supports. No one should be forced in this regard. That is why we have a secret election. No one should be forced to say publicly for which party he or she has voted. The secret ballot of this country is jealously guarded, yet the Opposition seeks to remove that element of secrecy. It is trying to make the people of Australia come out and say: 'We voted Liberal . We donated X dollars to the Liberal Party'. What would happen then? The unions affiliated with the Labor Party would boycott them and we would have a disgraceful situation in this country. There is no way in which honourable senators on this side of the chamber would go along with that kind of procedure. If the Leader of the Opposition believes that no discrimination would be shown towards a business that stated publicly that it supported the Liberal Party, he should think again. The unions affiliated with his party would make sure that discrimination was shown.

As far as the disclosure portion of the matter of public importance is concerned, I say that there is no reason in the wide world why the Australian Labor Party should not make disclosure. If it is so keen on the idea, why does it not go ahead and do so? Why does not Labor disclose who supports its party? There is nothing in the wide world to stop it from providing a list. People might be interested in it. Of course, some of its supporters might be very angry and might withdraw their support, but there is nothing in the wide world to stop it from making such disclosures. If it is so keen on the idea, I ask it please to do so, there is nothing to stop it from doing that.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are stopping us. You are preventing us from having a clean system.

—Nothing is stopping the Opposition from making disclosure, but the Government believes in privacy, in the true, free democratic right to support and vote for the party of one's choice. I repeat, there is nothing in the world to stop the Opposition from destroying that principle. It certainly will not be done on our side. The following appeared in an editorial in The Australian:

SPEECH.PARA: No system of public funding can be organised without denying genuine democracry .

I believe that those words really describe what this matter of public importance is about. No system of public funding can be organised without denying genuine democracy. Why should individual voters be denied the right and opportunity to vote with their pockets as well as their pencils? In a democratic society people should be entitled to decide how much, how little or if at all they wish to donate to a party of their choice. I believe that is the crux of the matter. As the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) said earlier, the difference between the Labor Party organisation and the Liberal Party organisation is that the Labor Party's financial arrangements are run by its leader, the leader of the parliamentary wing. That is not so in the Liberal Party. The parliamentary wing of the Liberal Party has no knowledge whatsoever of donations or where they come from. That is the vital difference between the organisation of the two parties.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the joke of the year.
—It is said that that is the joke of the year. I do not expect Senator Ray to understand that.
—I just don't believe it.

—Of course he does not. He would not understand that sort of honesty from this side. I understand that he cannot accept that and that he does not understand that sort of honesty. But that has been the policy of this Government for many years. I have never had any knowledge of where any donation has come from. I have no knowledge of any donations given to the Liberal Party. Senator Messner has mentioned that today. I can understand the Labor Party's not believing us. It would not understand that sort of principle because it does not have it. But on this side we do have it, and it is a very genuine and very well adhered to principle. Australians live in a very jealously guarded democracy of which there are too few in the world. As I have already pointed out, apart from those members of unions affiliated with the Labor Party who are forced to contribute to Labor Party election funds, Australians have the right financially to support or otherwise the party of their political philsophy. If the Opposition wants parties and people to fund its election campaigns, I suggest that it change its policies. It should give up its socialist policies, its communist sympathies, and instead follow policies designed to strengthen a free democracy and so have greater appeal to electors. It might then find that the funds come in a little easier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have always wondered why the Liberal Party opposed so vehemently public funding. In the Canberra Times in March 1981 the Prime Minister of this country (Mr Malcolm Fraser) was reported as saying that public funding was corrupt. I wondered when Vice President Bush, a recipient of public funding, visited this country whether Mr Fraser admonished Mr Bush for being corrupt when he feted him around the countryside, at dinners at the Hilton, et cetera. I do not think he did. When Mr Fraser tours countries and lectures them on tariff policy, when he goes to the United States, Japan, West Germany, Austria, Sweden or Canada, does he also lecture them about having corrupt systems because they use public funding? Of course he does not. In 30 years' time this debate will be regarded in the same way as we regard the great Reform Bill debate of 1832 that swept away the rotten boroughs. In 30 years' time this subject will be regarded as a ridiculous thing to debate because it will be a fact of life in the next 20 or 30 years.

SPEECH.PARA: I am interested that Mr Fraser has said that he will sweep the tax evaders out of the Liberal Party, especially in Western Australia. When is he going to take on the corrupt New South Wales Branch of the Liberal Party, the branch of the Liberal Party that has accepted public funding? I am sure that Senator Walters would join with Mr Fraser in a great crusade-what a fearsome duo they would be- into New South Wales to clean up that branch. It has accepted over $400,000. I ask Senator Walters whether those people are corrupt. Are they or are they not? Of course they are not. They are just opportunists. Before the last New South Wales State election we heard comments from the New South Wales Liberal Party similar to those heard today. Firstly, we heard Mr Mason, the then leader of the Liberal Party in New South Wales-he was the fifth of the seven they have had in the last seven years-describe public funding as 'one of the most cold-blooded predetermined acts of a socialist party to destroy the Westminster system of government'. That is what Mr Mason said. Now, several months later, his party comes out and accepts public funding. One can draw only two conclusions: Either members of the New South Wales Liberal Party are opportunists or they are closet socialists out to destroy the Westminster system. One can choose between the two . What it really means is that the New South Wales Liberal Party never really opposed political funding but just jumped on a bandwagon, desperately trying to win some votes. A desperately unpopular party in New South Wales hoped to bolster its votes on this issue. The electors spoke; Labor won 69 seats, the Liberal Party won 14 seats and its colleagues in the National Country Party won 14 seats. The Liberal Party could not even outpoll the National Country Party in New South Wales when it campaigned on that issue.

The second argument-Senator Walters brought it up today-is that it is wrong to dip into the public purse; that to subsidise political campaigns and political parties is almost a form of stealing. This already occurs in many instances. The first person I would like to quote on this is the treasurer of the Victorian Liberal Party. He said that being out of State government cost the Liberal Party $2m. He said:

For years the State director has been seeking the financial resources to strengthen the secretariat's services in research, intelligence and communications. The funds have not been available to do this.
Sir Peter Derham said:
Whilst we were in Government in Victoria, the Party placed its reliance in these areas in the parliamentary party. This of course is no longer possible.

So they were using the Victorian taxpayers' money to subsidise the Liberal Party in that State. One has only to look at the Federal Government, at the way it dips into the public purse to subsidise its party and its campaigns. This year the Government Information Unit will cost $1m of taxpayers' money in political propaganda. As has already been mentioned, $1.5m has been set aside in the Treasury for shonky publicity campaigns leading up to an election. Another $300, 000 is being spent on surveys. It is only because of the diligence of the Labor Party in the Estimates committees that those surveys are now becoming public. They would have been used for party political purposes. Of course, the Liberal Party uses staff, VIP aircraft and Commonwealth cars when it is campaigning. So public money is going into political campaigns-much to the disadvantage of the Labor Party or any Opposition party because the Government takes the lion's share of it. It is not right to say that this would be dipping into the public purse for the first time. It is happening at the moment. As well as those that have already been alluded to, various fund raising schemes, especially those used in New South Wales, use tax deductibility to get money into the Liberal Party. They run bodgy dinners that businessmen write off in their taxes and then the taxpayers pay.

Senator Walters raised points about the unions. What about the companies that kick in money to the Liberal Party? How do they pay for it? They put up their prices and the rest of the community pays. It is exactly the same as any union. The worst example of pillage of the public purse by government comes from Victoria. I do not know whether any senators here saw the new directions policy launched by the late Liberal Government in December 1980. It was the most blatant political campaign I have ever seen. It was only a political campaign. It cost $165,000 in about two weeks to promote the Liberal Party in that State. Then $2.1m was allocated to other peripheral advertising leading up to the State election. What did the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal think of that particular advertising campaign? It banned it during the election period so it must have been political. One cannot claim that the Government was trying to extol the virtues of government policy. It was political advertising and those advertisments were eliminated because of that.

The third major objection the Liberal Party has is that it likes the voluntary donation system. I ask everyone in the Senate: Why do people donate money to political parties? The answer from across the way was that they do so from a sense of altruism, of public mindedness. People donate money because they believe that political parties should have the right to operate in a free environment and all that sort of rubbish. If we ask some of those who donate money to political parties, like Ted Vibert, who has been in the news a lot recently, they will tell us why. They donate it as a bit of an arm twist, politically. From my point of view, as a poker machine person, it is a bit of a political arm twist to politicians. That is why they make the donations. Do donations influence the Liberal Party? In a copy of the Sydney Morning Herald last year, the following appeared:
The Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, has been warned by major manufacturing interests who are vital Liberal Party donors that their funds will be withdrawn if the Federal Government cuts tariffs.
One Liberal Party source told the Herald yesterday that the interests involved were 'six figure' donors to the party and came from the 'backbone' of the party' s financial base.
There were the donors warning the Government to take political action or they would withdraw their funds.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think that is right?

—I am sure that is right. What Senator Walters and others would say is that Liberal Ministers have nothing to do with fund raising. They do not see the dirty money; it comes in but they do not see it. I also read in the Sydney Morning Herald the following statement in a biography of the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon-one of those chummy articles:

SPEECH.PARA: A liberal minister who canvassed funds in Melbourne before the 1977 election found that Nixon had beaten him to most of the likely contributors. 'He didn't leave anything for the Liberal Party,' the minister laments.

Which Liberal Ministers went out chasing funds? Probably incompentent ones because Nixon beat them to it. Is the Government going to criticise the National Country Party for not having its ethics of having nothing to do with the money? Of course Liberal Ministers go out and chase money. If honourable senators want further proof of that, they should listen to Mr Leo Hawkins, the former State Secretary of the Liberal Party in Victoria. On Nationwide three years ago he said:

Now I think it's quite wrong for the Prime Minister, the Premier, other leaders to have to go through the sort of antics that are required to lever money out of people in the community who've got relatively large sums to give.
So Liberal Party Ministers do go out and collect money and therefore it does influence policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they don't tell Senator Walters.

—That is right, they do not tell Senator Walters. Why is the Liberal Party opposing public funding? It likes the status quo. The Liberal Party likes the status quo that allows it to outspend the Australian Labor Party by three to one in every election. It likes the status quo that allows it to outspend the Australian Democrats by at least 10 to one at every election. When the boot is on the other foot the Liberals squeal. When the National Party came up with $900,000 in the last State election in Queensland the then Director of the Liberal Party in Queensland, Stephen Litchfield, objected and said it was a terrible thing. Of course the National Party had its $900,000 because it is funded by the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation, the most shonky fund in this country through which political favours are done in return for money coming back in. The Liberal Party knows that is true. It knows there is no insulator there. What price is a knighthood in Queensland? I believe it is $100,000. That is the sort of fund raising scheme that operates in Queensland to bring in money to help support the conservative parties of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: When we come to the bottom line, the Liberal Party does not really oppose public funding; it opposes disclosure. That is where the action is; that is where the Liberal Party really takes a strong line. It opposes disclosure because it knows that once firms are named as having donated money to the Liberal Party a Liberal Party government will not be able to do them any more favours. We should not fall for the ridiculous argument of union retribution or anything else. That is the reason the Liberal Party opposes disclosure. If we had disclosure we would not have to find out from the courts that a Mr Gale, from the Gollin group, gave $25,000 to the Liberal Party and substantial aid to the Prime Minister when he was in Opposition. We know Mr Gale will not be around as a Liberal Party bagman because he has another 10 years to do, after being convicted of embezzlement.

The Australian Labor Party does not claim to be totally clean. I think the lowest point in Labor Party history was the Iraqi breakfast when the Labor Party tried to borrow overseas money to pay for its election debts. None of us in the Labor Party is proud of that. It is a consequence of not having public funding. The National Country Party is not particularly clean, though I note its bagman should be out just in time for the next Federal election if it is held next year . That will be a great relief to the members of that party. If we had public funding it would also be possible to avoid illegal activities, such as when Mr McDonald, the then leader of the Liberal Party in New South Wales, had to go to illegal gambling nights to raise money for the party. I urge all members of the Senate that it is time we had public funding. It will clean up election campaigns and will remove all suspicion that political parties are responsive to their donors. It will mean that, with the escalating costs of elections, political parties will not have to sell their souls in response to donations. That time has come in other countries, it has come in New South Wales and it is time it came in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a very valuable matter of public importance brought forward by Senator John Button, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for a system of public funding of election campaigns and full disclosure of donations, or other assistance, to political parties and candidates.

The Australian Democrats support every word in that statement and we have embodied almost those words in our policy documents. That was done by a vote of all members of the Australian Democrats, and I might say that it was a unanimous vote. The last weeks of political life in this country have been dominated by continuing revelations of tax frauds, from the report of the Costigan Royal Commission of Inquiry on the activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, the McCabe-Lafranchi report and other reports. It has been made abundantly clear that the tentacles of these fraudulent operators and promoters have reached and are reaching well into our political structure. We have read novels and seen documentaries about how organised crime has infiltrated the political mechanisms of the United States of America. We did not take that warning, and the Liberal Party and the National Country Party today are not taking that warning. They still oppose the public funding of political parties and elections and the full disclosure of donations. In other words, they are leaving the way totally open for the shonky operator, for the white collar criminal, for organised crime-without becoming too emotional, for the Mafia which is well established in Australia-to make substantial donations to political parties in this country. Since the formation of the Australian Democrats in 1977 we have had a firm written policy on this matter. It is:
1. A public electoral fund should be established to finance candidates, parties and elections.
2. The amount which candidates and parties spend on campaigns should be kept within strict limits set prior to each campaign.
3. All donations or assistance valued at more than $2,000 to any candidate or party should be capable of public disclosure.

That is our policy and we have stuck to it. I would be sympathetic to the view that, if persons because of altruism want to give $100, $200 or $500 or whatever to a political party, they should be protected, if they want to be protected, by not having their names associated with the particular political party. What we are saying is that people who make these non-insignificant donations to political parties should be allowed to remain anonymous. We say that any donation over $2,000, which we would regard as significant, should be capable of public disclosure. A political party may be asked at any time by the Press-and the Democrats are-whether it has received any donations over $2,000, and if so, whether it could provide details. We have a policy of open disclosure in regard to that.

We believe this position has been clearly vindicated by the scandals exposed by the Costigan Royal Commission. An examination of those revelations shows that the system does need protecting. Prominent Liberals, particularly those involved in fund raising for the Liberal Party, have been named in the Costigan and McCabe-Lafranchi reports. I am not suggesting that the entire Liberal Party is financed by ill-gotten gains coming from tax rorts or criminals. What I am saying, however, is that I am not prepared to believe that none of it came from people who might be involved in bottom-of-the-harbour tax avoidance schemes.

There is an old saying that not only must justice be done but also it must be seen to be done. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) is an honest man. If I asked him now to say 'I can guarantee that not one cent has been received by the Liberal Party over the last five years from any promoter of a tax fraud', he could not do it. Of course he could not do that. I would not expect him to. He might not even know; but he could not do it. I should have thought that that is not good enough for the people. They would want to know that the Liberal Party which presently governs this country did not receive one cent from white-collar criminals, from organised crime or from the Mafia. I should have thought that that knowledge is essential if people are to have confidence in their political parties.

The Sydney Technical College put out a report last week entitled 'Marketing and Political Parties, 1972-82'. In that report it is indicated that a minimum amount of $20m has been secretly given to the Liberal Party, the Country Party and the Australian Labor Party in the last 10 years. I need only to mention that figure to indicate the kind of muscle and influence that can be exerted by the donors of that $20m on those political parties. The New South Wales Liberal Party President, Mr John Valder, recently indicated that a $50,000 donation had been explicitly threatened by the Government's desire to pursue retrospective tax legislation. That gentleman raised $2m in three or four months. He must be a fantastic fund raiser. He is an honest man in that he has stated that he has been threatened by prospective donors that if the Government does something, $50 ,000 will not be forthcoming. He is also honest enough to make this shocking statement:
A lot of businesses make you get down on your knees for donations and sometimes . . . there is a high price for getting donations.

What does that statement-'There is a high price for getting donations'-mean? It was made by Mr John Valder, the present Liberal Party President in New South Wales. Of course, it means that if one takes the bag around and gets substantial donations from multinationals, from oil companies or wherever, they ask a price for those donations.

Let me give an indication of what I mean. Is the Minister for Veterans' Affairs now prepared to say: 'I can guarantee that the multinational oil companies operating in this country have not given one dollar to the Liberal Party over the past five years'? Of course he cannot do that. The fact is that they are notorious world wide for corrupting political parties. They even made fools of themselves in Italy a few years ago by denying that they gave any money to political parties. They were exposed by a congressional inquiry. It was found that, by a mistake in the computer, they had given $80m to the Communist Party of Italy.

In 1978, the then Minister for Industry and Commerce, Mr Fife, announced that there would be 100 per cent divorcement from oil companies owning service stations; in other words, legislation would be brought in, made retrospective to 30 October 1978, so that no oil company could own a petrol service station. It was a promise backed by Cabinet, backed by the whole Ministry and backed by every member of the Liberal Party and the Country Party in the party room.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you sure that that was the specific promise?
—It was made on 30 October 1978, by Mr Wal Fife, the then Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs.
—It was made with qualifications.

—It was made with absolutely no qualifications. In fact the Minister said that he would make the legislation retrospective to 30 October. When the legislation was introduced in 1980, there was only a 50 per cent divorcement, which was a laugh. I allege that the multinational oil companies in this country gave over $1m to the Liberal Party during that time. I have figures to suggest that that can be proven. Is there any connection between the two? I allege that the Liberal Party receives about $1m per year in secret donations. That can be easily worked out. Honourable senators should do their sums. They should multiply the membership fee by the number of members and figure out how much it costs the party to run its secretariat, to place advertisements in newspapers and whatever. There is at least-I am erring on the side of conservatism-$1m unaccounted for per year. In an election year it is about $3m.

SPEECH.PARA: Where does the $3m come from? What sort of pressure and muscle do the people making those secret donations exert on the Liberal Party? Does the Labor Party receive money from the trade union movement? Of course it does, and it admits that it does. I do not know what the figure is. The Labor Party receives about $ 750,000 or $1m per year from the trade union movement. It is courageous enough and honest enough, however, through its leaders and its present Federal president, to have said 'We do not want a bar of this. We can be a better party if we do not have to rely on support from an outside organisation such as a trade union'. At least Mr Neville Wran has put his legislation where his mouth is and has brought in public funding for political parties in New South Wales. What did the Liberal Party do then? It said that it would make the issue the biggest one in the campaign. It was not going to take a cent of this filthy money, this public funding. But what is it doing now? Does it have its hands out crawling after the Treasury in New South Wales asking for a handout? Of course it does. One wonders where the principle lies.

Like all decent Australians, I have been disgusted by the way in which the poker machine lobbies have been handing out thousands of dollars to political parties in Queensland and elsewhere. Are we not disgusted at the way in which the Nugan Hand organisation dispensed largesse among the political parties in this country? Are we not disgusted with the way in which the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation operates in a scandalous way in Queensland? Is this the way in which we are to get honest decent government in this country? The public funding of elections and candidates is common practice in many countries, such as West Germany, Sweden, Canada and Japan, among others. The United States subsidises the nominations and general election phases of its presidential campaigns. I compliment the Wran Government on its courage. The cost of funding election campaigns is 27c per voter per year-the cost of one postage stamp. Despite its easy acquiescence in taking the money, the Liberal Party is still keen to flout the law and avoid public disclosure of its donors.

How about this for hypocrisy on the part of the Liberal Party? I should like the Minister to answer if I misrepresent him. The Liberal Party advises its donors in New South Wales to send their money to a Canberra-based free enterprise foundation, which then forwards the money to the Liberal Party Federal Secretariat, which in turn passes it back to Sydney-thus avoiding all the New South Wales public disclosure provisions. All this is openly promoted and condoned by the Liberal Party. There is only one word for that-shonky. I should like the Minister at the table to deny that.

Some people object and say that they do not want to give money to any political party, particularly one that they oppose; they do not want parties to be publicly funded. I make three points. Such people are already subsidising political parties. As Leader of my party, I have been approached about substantial donations-$50,000 and $100,000. I have said 'Thank you very much, but you do know that we have under our constitution an obligation to disclose that donation if requested'. They then run for cover. They say 'We are sorry; we did not know that. The deal is off'. But then they return and say 'Can we not pay your printing costs, up to $50,000 or $100,000?' We say no, because if we take that sort of money or allow that to be done, we are in their debt.

Could not people, when putting in their income tax returns, state their option of to which political party they want a proportion of their taxes to be given? Or it could be done on a prescribed formula as per the votes at the last election. Something needs to be done to clean up the kind of corruption-I use that word advisedly-that exists in this country with the payment of money to political parties. Let us bring it out into the open; let us have public funding and let the public know where it comes from.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Country Party in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon the Senate is discussing the following matter of public importance:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for a system of public funding of election campaigns and full disclosure of donations, or other assistance, to political parties and candidates.

As might have been suspected-I think very regrettably-the debate has slipped down the line into a fairly emotional discussion in which all sorts of slush allegations and references to Mr Costigan and so forth have been bandied about across this chamber. It is a shame that it has developed into that sort of discussion because the matter generally under discussion is of great importance and it is an area to which Australians in this free country should devote a great deal of their attention and considered thought. I thought it was a pity in the very early stages of the debate that the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Button, who generally has a measure of humour and indeed sometimes a touch of logic in what he says, should have concentrated his performance on a heap of more or less slush allegations. Even Senator Button became somewhat emotional in this very interesting and important discussion. He certainly avoided reference to the fact that the Liberal Party decision in New South Wales was a pragmatic decision that seeks to abolish, when it has the power so to do, the sort of public funding that has been established by the Wran Government in that State.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it taking money in the meantime?

—Yes, and it is taking the money on what I described as a pragmatic decision. I think the honourable senator would agree. I think he would also agree that it is a pragmatic decision and probably from time to time the honourable senator is forced to take such a decision himself. Since Senator Chipp mentioned the matter I find that a poll, which was taken nationwide by the Age in April 1979, reported that 77 per cent of Australian Democrats opposed public funding. Maybe the honourable senator has changed his mind but that is the information I have before me today and it reminds me of the other matter that he mentioned which interested me a great deal. Senator Chipp mentioned that there should be a limit of perhaps $2,000 and beyond that amount or some sort of revelation should be made as to the source of the fund. I imagine that in that circumstance any number of donations-human beings being what they are-could be made at a figure slightly less than that amount. So there are great problems in trying to put guidelines and restrictions on this sort of legislation. Senator Gietzelt spent most of his time-I thought that today he did not read his speech as well as he usually does--
—That statement is contrary to Standing Orders.

—It is only an observation. Senator Gietzelt spent a great deal of his time on the Costigan report on the activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. He mentioned one being a political philanthropist if one gave money to a particular political organisation. Political organisations basically establish and promote a political philosophy. Surely it is in order in a free society that someone with a real and proper measure of secrecy, as applies to the ballot by which we elect governments, should be able to support financially those entities which seek to provide and promote the political philosophies and the socio-economic circumstances that they believe are best for their own country.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Robert Ray, when speaking on this matter today-I think Senator Chipp mentioned it too-said that Vice President Bush was the beneficiary of public funding in the United States. Of course that is so but it is slightly different from the public funding that we envisage where one takes X number of millions of dollars of taxpayers' funds. As I understand public funding in the American presidential situation it is public funding that comes from a tax credit fund which is purely voluntary and quite different from a deduction of funds from public revenue.
