Indeed, Senator Robert Ray referred also to the Government Information Unit and thought that $1m-that was the figure he cited-was too much money for it to be spending on whatever information it sought, and I believe quite properly sought, to extend to the Australian electorate. Yet in my State of New South Wales, from memory the amount spent largely in the field of information in the Premier's Department has increased, in five or six years or however long it is that Mr Wran has been the Premier, from between $4m and $5m to almost $40m. So I would hope that considerable Government information is being extended or else there is a large measure of inefficiency.

I return to the subject of the debate and briefly go over the propositions that we should be considering because the funding of political parties has always been and always will be a perennial problem. I believe that it is a perennial problem which we do not have any right to solve by asking taxpayers to bear the brunt. That is not the answer. Maybe socialists have little or no difficulty in moving the burden of cost to the shoulders of the taxpayer but it is certainly my belief-it is the belief of the Government-that it is not the taxpayers' responsibility to fund political entities to help them develop their policies or indeed, more importantly, to help them gain the Treasury benches in any State or the Commonwealth of Australia. That is the job for the political entity itself and for the people who belong to it.

Since this debate addresses itself to the question of whether funding should be public or whether it should be the concern of individuals and political entities , the question can be asked: What should funding do? Clearly, funding should enable the promotion with clarity of the issues and the solutions to various political problems and it should convey those matters to the electorate so that the electorate, having the determination and the capacity to analyse them, can come to sensible and responsible conclusions. That is what funding is all about, and that surely should be the responsibility of the people who decide on these problems as they affect the socio-economic climate, the people who seek to gain office in this country and therefore the capacity to implement those views.

A political party obviously seeks to implement its own political philosophy which it has sought to establish over a long period. Sometimes it has developed and evolved over decades or even longer. That party must promote and argue its own cause with the society that it seeks to establish and represent. The taxpayer, I suggest, has absolutely no responsibility to take part either in the establishment of that philosophy or indeed in its promotion. That is the basic circumstance which we are discussing this afternoon. Political parties are beholden to a view and, I believe, having become the holders of a specific view, they should then seek to regularise their capacity or the sources that they may have of funds to establish, develop and promote that view. It is not the province-

TALK.START.PARA: —Not like the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation, surely?

—I am talking about taxpayers as a whole. I do not believe that it is the province of the taxpayer to promote Senator Chipp's philosophy or mine. It is as simple as that, and I think it is fundamental to a discussion of the matter we have before us this afternoon.

SPEECH.PARA: Another interesting view with which I think we should concern ourselves is that if political philosophy or belief is to be effective, if it is to generate an enthusiasm, if it is to develop, then it will be much more likely to do so if it does it on its own feet and is concerned with the efficiency, the effectiveness, of its development and promotion. As Senator Walters indicated earlier today, the sort of funding suggested may run into a significant amount of money. If it runs into $6m in New South Wales it could, I suppose, run into $30m or $40m for Australia as a whole. So it is a significant amount of money and it should not be the responsibility of the Australian taxpayer to provide that sort of money and probably, by doing so, bring about the inefficiencies and ineffectiveness that could well be a corollary of that solution, if it were a solution at all.

A number of points have been made in regard to disclosure. It seems to me unnecessary and indeed quite wrong that it should be a necessary part of a gift or the giving of finance to a political party that the source should be disclosed. That is an interference with the concept of the secret ballot. It is an interference, indeed, with the civil liberties of this community. Surely there is no need to disclose a contribution which may or may not be accepted by a political entity to help it promote and develop the sorts of circumstances it seeks to develop and promote in the community in which it exists.

As time is moving by swiftly, I conclude my remarks by saying that I believe it is a great shame that this afternoon a measure of emotionalism and slush allegations have superseded what this discussion should have been about, that is , a responsible attitude to the funding of political parties, the method of their funding, and whether, and I believe this is absolutely fundamental, that funding is the responsibility of all taxpayers. Whether or not it is the philosophies of a communist party, of a fascist party, of all sorts of grey areas that are being promoted, or not, it is a question of whether the Australian taxpayer should be involved in that sort of promotion or whether those who establish and believe in such a philosophy should be the people who are responsible for promoting it. I move:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave- Earlier Senator Chipp made certain remarks about me. He has said on many occasions that he is somewhat thin skinned in politics. I suppose I am revealing myself as being so. As he was not present during my remarks, I want to restate the point that no Liberal member of parliament has access to the lists of donors of contributions to the Liberal Party. I have no personal knowledge whatsoever of the donors and the amounts they contribute for the benefit of the Liberal Party in South Australia or, for that matter, the Liberal Party federally. I want again to make that point absolutely clear. In no way, therefore, am I in a position to be able to give Senator Chipp the kinds of guarantees he was seeking .

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON SOUTH WEST TASMANIA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On behalf of the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania, I wish to draw to the attention of the Senate the unauthorised publication of some of the contents of a Committee document. An article appeared in the Canberra Times on Wednesday, 29 September 1982, entitled 'Senate Committee Report-Tasmanian power ''oversupply'' seen'. The first sentence of the article read:

SPEECH.PARA: A confidential report prepared for the Senate Committee inquiring into south- west Tasmania has told the Committee that the forecast demand for electricity use by the Tasmanian Hydro-Electric Commission is too high.

It was stated in the article that the report was 'prepared by the McLachlan Group', a firm of management consultants and covered 'electrical-energy demand'. The use of quotations from the report confirmed that the author of the article had access to the report of McLachlan Group Pty Ltd dated 9 June 1982 on electrical energy demand.

The McLachlan Group Pty Ltd was commissioned by the Committee to prepare, among other things, a report on the demand for electricity in Tasmania. Its report was received in June. Neither the Senate nor the Committee has authorised the disclosure or publication of any part of the McLachlan Group report of 9 June 1982. I have received assurances from the Secretary to the Committee that neither the staff of the Committee nor the consultants were responsible for the disclosure of the report to any other person. I am fully satisfied with those assurances. The Committee was concerned that the disclosure of a Committee document occurred, and it resolved that the matter should be drawn to the attention of the Senate by way of this statement rather than by proceeding in any more formal way or requesting the Senate to take any specific action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This statement which has been approved by the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania-I was not present when the Committee did this-contains this statement by the Chairman:

SPEECH.PARA: I have received assurances from the Secretary to the Committee that neither the staff of the Committee nor the consultants were responsible for the disclosure of the report to any other person. I am fully satisfied with those assurances.

The report, without going into any disclosure of what is contained in it, was made available, of course, to every member of the Committee. The consequence of the statement is that it is very much in the air as to whether it could have been a member of the Committee who made the disclosure to the Canberra Times or whether it was made by someone else so that it got into the Canberra Times. Having been out of the country for some considerable number of weeks but having checked with my staff carefully, I can certainly assure the Committee that there has been no disclosure from my office or from me to any person. Nobody has seen my copy of the report except myself. I think it is necessary, in view of the fact that this remark was made, to clear the air. As far as I am concerned, I am not aware of how the newspaper came by this information.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I reiterate exactly what Senator Missen said. I certainly made no disclosure to the Canberra Times. Other members of the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania who are in the chamber can speak for themselves. I can speak for Senator Coates who is not in the chamber at the moment. The honourable senator made the statement at a meeting of the Committee that under no circumstances did he have any part in making any disclosure. I am sure that other members of the Committee who are here can speak for themselves but I know that they felt the same way.
—by leave-I also simply wish to say that I have conferred with my staff and I give to the Senate assurances in similar terms to those given by Senator Missen.

—by leave-I think I can speak on behalf of members of the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania who are not in the chamber. I want to assure the Senate that I at no time made available to any person or persons any material that came to me. I guess we are all in a little bit of a fix in that the Committee received over 700 submissions on top of reports from consultants and other groups. A lot of paper has been floating about. A lot of paper has been in the mail, passing to and from members of the Committee and the Secretariat. How this person or persons got hold of the information is a mystery to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: -The Bill before the Senate seeks to appropriate and pay to the States $457m for general purpose capital grants. Those payments are not repayable. The Bill also seeks to authorise additional funds from the States' general loan funds to be allocated for housing should the States so request. Some $65m of the States' general loan funds was, by agreement at the Premiers Conference in June, allocated or earmarked for housing. The total payments, of both grants and concession interest rates, to the States and territories for this year, if I have interpreted the figures correctly, will be $333m, a figure which could conceivably be increased if the States request that additional general purpose loan funds be earmarked for housing and paid in accordance with the provision in this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The figure of $333m is considerably more than was paid last year. However, it should be noted that last year, and indeed in a couple of previous years, the figures were extraordinarily low by long term standards. Indeed, it is indicated on page 136 of current Budget Paper No. 7 that in current value dollars the absolute amount of money-perhaps this is the best way of putting it-has declined from $335m to $318m between 1978-79 and 1981-82. In real terms, of course, the decline has been in the vicinity of 40 per cent. Over the longer period the decline in funds made available to housing is even greater.

Perhaps more important than the payments to the States is the payments to the States less repayments from the States for loans previously advanced for housing -in other words, net payments to the States for the purposes of public housing. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a small table, previously incorporated in the House of Representatives Hansard by Mr Uren, which compares the figures for 1974-75 and 1982-83 in 1982-83 prices. The table shows that payments to the six States, which amounted to $652m in 1974-75, have fallen to $103m in 1982-83.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps one should acknowledge that the Opposition fully supports the Government decision to increase marginally in real terms the amount of money made available to the States for public housing this year as compared with last year. We believe, however, that it should go a great deal further and it should do so for these reasons: Firstly, because there is a growing need for welfare housing, associated with rising unemployment, among other things; secondly, because there is a real long term need for a higher level of housing construction than we have at the moment or than we have had for the last couple of years. The Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry estimates a continuing need into the late 1980s for 160,000 new units to be constructed each year. The most recent figures on both building commencements and building approvals-they are suprisingly close together-suggest that the current level of activity would provide only 110,000 units. The third reason why there should be greater expenditure on housing construction generally, and on public welfare housing in particular, is that this industry has a very great employment generating potential. It is labour intensified and its import requirement is extremely low. It therefore has a high domestic multiplier and, unlike some other measures of economic stimulation which could substantially leak into imports, exacerbating an already catastrophic deficit on current account, there would be little leakage of housing construction into imports.

SPEECH.PARA: I can give an example of one particuarly inept supposed method of stimulating the economy which has an extremely high leakage into imports. I refer to the decision which was announced, I believe in June, to allow farm machinery to be depreciated over three years instead of over five years as was previously the case. This will encourage farmers to purchase machines with an even greater degree of surplus capacity. They will be able to purchase larger and more expensive machines which are more likely to be imported. The propensity to import farm machinery is already in the vicinity of 40 per cent. That will not apply if additional funds are diverted into housing construction as an economic stimulus. That sort of leakage will not take place. Therefore, the domestic mulitplier will be higher and it will not exacerbate the very serious deficit on current account which we have this year and which we have had for the previous two years.

The need to stimulate housing construction is there. The means of stimulating housing construction is also there. The only obstacle to a greater stimulation of housing construction is the policies of this Government. It is most appropriate, for a number of reasons, that the primary attention to stimulating housing construction should go through the public sector. Firstly, it is more likely to be effective than indirect measures aimed at the private sector. Secondly, a greater number of people are either homeless or have inadequate accommodation because of rising poverty in the community. Thirdly, other arrangements, particularly the taxation system, discriminate heavily against those who rent as those who purchase and in particular those who purchase to rent to others. I will say more about that shortly.

It is correct that some publicly financed housing is not recorded as public housing and certainly is not public welfare housing. For example, the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) has a 45-year government loan on his second house in Canberra at a rate of interest of 4 3/4 per cent. He gave that to himself in 1964. That is not recorded as public housing. Eighty-four per cent of the original capital still has to be repaid. This raises the question as to whether it is fair for a loan at 4 3/4 per cent interest to be provided to the Deputy Prime Minister for his second house in Canberra. Given the recent declaration of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) that fairness to all Australians was to be the paramount principle guiding this Government in the future, I wonder how long it will take the Prime Minister to take some action to remove that anomaly.

It was revealed last week that in 1972 Sir Alan Westerman gave himself a 3 per cent loan from the Australian Industry Development Corporation on a house that he already owned. Sir Alan had a close association, as a senior bureaucrat over several decades, with senior National Country Party Ministers. The ethics of the National Country Party apparently rubbed off on to Sir Alan. In granting himself that 3 per cent loan from the AIDC, of which he was Chairman in 1972, he followed the moral lead provided by Mr Anthony with whom he had had associations as a senior bureaucrat in the first place and a senior Minister in the second place. As has been reported, Sir Alan repaid that loan in 1977 or thereabouts. It has been reported also that the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon, some months ago repaid a similar loan which he granted to himself in 1970. As a passing observation it could be said that of those three people only Mr Anthony has yet to repay the loan. He must be the only man in history with a thicker hide than Mr Nixon. It was also revealed yesterday that employees of the Reserve Bank of Australia, who do not have the sorts of incomes which most people would regard as making them welfare cases, receive loans from the Reserve Bank at an interest rate of 6 per cent. What we need is less publicly financed housing of this type for the more fortunate groups in society-indeed, I would say that we really need none at all-and more directed to the needy.

The case, on equity grounds, for directing greater public funds into housing for the needy is especially strong because the tax system operates in favour of landlords or lessors and against occupier-buyers and renters. In one case which has been brought to my attention a house with a $3m mortgage is owned by a company. The interest payment on the $3m mortgage, in round figures, is half a million dollars a year. The house is rented by the company to its managing director, who also owns the company, for $200 a week, or just over $10,000 a year. As a result of that arrangement the company claims as a deduction from taxable income an interest payment amounting to half a million dollars and declares as income $10,400, which is that which is paid by the managing director to the company for living in a house which is ostensibly a company house but which is, of course, owned by the individual.

In another case, a house at 18 Richardson Avenue, Claremont, in Western Australia, which was occupied by the owner until January 1981, had a mortgage of $300,000 taken out on it in February 1981. That was the first of three mortgages taken out on the house. A further quarter of a million dollars was taken out in April 1981 and a further quarter of a million dollars was taken out in April 1982. All the loans were obtained from the Perth Building Society, at commercial or, arguably, slightly above commercial rates of interest. By April 1982 the house had a total mortgage of $800,000 and an interest payment of $125,000 a year, all of which was deductible from the income tax of the owner because the house was let. I do not know at what figure the house was let. That figure-less costs associated with the letting and maintenance of the house-would be assessed as taxable income in the hands of the owner of the house. That letting figure, or rent, certainly would not be anywhere near $2,400 a week, which is what it would have to be for the taxable income received for the house to cancel out the taxable deduction gained from the interest payment. I have the mortgage documents for the house in question, which I will seek leave to table in a moment. I should mention that the house in question is owned by Sir Victor Garland, who occupied it until he went to London as Australian High Commissioner in January 1981, when it was rented by Mr Holmes a Court.

The third of these mortgage documents bears on the second last page the signatures of Sir Victor Garland and his wife Lynette, witnessed by the official secretary of the London High Commission, who appears to be a Mr G. Gibson, with the stamp of the Australian High Commission appended to it. At approximately the same time as those additional mortgages were being taken out, Sir Victor was buying other property, some of it directly adjacent to the 18 Richardson Avenue address, one unit in another part of Perth and some land at Toodyay in the Avon area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walsh, could I interrupt you for a minute. We are debating the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Bill 1982. I hope that you will soon show how these comments that you are making tie in with this Bill.

—I was putting an equity argument, Mr Acting Deputy President, and pointing out that the existing taxation laws can be used by landlords who rent in a way which gives them very significant advantages over either those who are renting-the tenants-or over those who are attempting to purchase the houses in which they live. The basis for that very significant advantage landlords have is that the interest payments are tax deductible even though a very large component of the interest paid is compensation for inflation. I could explain that in greater detail but I think that is sufficient to make the point. That because the taxation system discriminates very heavily in this way, the case for providing public assistance through public housing for the genuinely needy is to that extent strengthened. In the case I have just mentioned the mortgages were taken out on a property which was previously encumbered, to only an insignificant degree, immediately following the letting of the property to a tenant; in other words, immediately following the creation of the conditions under which the interest payments on the mortgage on the house would be deductible from taxable income. The house in question was sold last month for $ 850,000, an amount which, I might add, barely exceeded the mortgages registered against it, which totalled $800,000. I understand the sale was virtually mandatory because the previous owner had made a very large payment which he had not anticipated. I seek leave to table the mortgage documents to which I have referred.
—Is leave granted?
—I have not seen the documents. Perhaps I could have a look at them.
—Senator Walsh, continue with your speech. We will deal with this matter when you conclude your remarks.

—In summary, on both macro-economic grounds-that is, the grounds that further expenditure on public housing would be a highly effective means of stimulating growth at a time when growth is desperately needed-and on equity grounds, there is a compelling argument, indeed an overwhelming argument, for the allocation of greater funds to this area of expenditure. It is for those reasons that the Australian Labor Party has a firm policy which commits it to a substantial increase in the funds provided to the States, they being the bodies responsible for welfare housing construction, and of course other measures which would stimulate the private sector as well. Given that the Commonwealth Government, although not having direct control over housing expenditure by the States, has a higher degree of control over public housing expenditure than it does over private housing expenditure, we believe, leaving aside the absolute amounts between the public and the private sector, that it is in the area of public housing where the Commonwealth's degree of responsibility is greatest. We welcome the small increase in real terms compared with the previous year that the Bill before the Senate provides. We note and deplore that that amount, although slightly larger than the amount provided in the previous year, is well below the amounts which were provided eight or ten years ago.
—Has the Minister for Finance had an opportunity to view the documents that Senator Walsh wishes to table?

—I have looked at the documents. They appear to be as described by Senator Walsh. Whilst they have no relevance at all to the Bill before the Senate, I accept that the honourable senator would take another opportunity to table them. For that reason I do not object to their being tabled now.
—There being no objection, the documents will be tabled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The States (Works and Housing) Assistance Bill 1982 has, as the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) pointed out in the second reading speech, two main purposes. They are to authorise the payment in the coming year of general purpose capital grants to the State totalling in the order of half a billion dollars and to authorise the payment in the coming year of amounts that the States and the Northern Territory may choose to nominate from their current year Loan Council borrowing programs to be provided for welfare housing at concessional loan terms and conditions. It must also be noted, however, that firstly the States are free to apply those grants as they choose, a fact which the Minister did point out; and secondly, the conversion of part of the States and the Northern Territory Loan Council programs is left entirely to the discretion of the individual State governments, or the Northern Territory Government as the case may be, or, as the Minister put it, according to their wishes and priorities.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst I am sure that nobody in this chamber would disagree that State governments should always be given flexibility to spend the grants which come from the Federal Government in whatever way best suits them, since they presumably have a better idea of what the needs are, I believe we should also recognise that at least some State governments appear to be less concerned with the poor and the helpless in society than others. In recognising that we should take care at this level that we do not abrogate our own responsibility to people in the welfare area.

To claim, as this Government has done, that it has substantially assisted the States by providing increased funding for public or welfare housing is, I believe, nonsense. The much-vaunted 5 per cent increase on last year's figure is really a mirage. In real terms, the Government's commitment to welfare housing has hardly risen at all. If we look at the needs in the housing area we see that it has actually fallen. Not only has the so-called increase not even kept pace with inflation but also the amounts provided are considerably less than the provision made some years ago. In addition, they fail to take into account the increasing demands on public or welfare housing.

Last week I had the delightful opportunity, Mr Acting Deputy President, of visiting your State, particularly the northern areas, where I was looking at something quite outside the field of welfare housing.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a beautiful place, and they are lovely people up there.

—They are delightful people, although some, as honourable senators will see in a moment, are in straitened circumstances. While I was there my attention was drawn to an article in the Mackay Daily Mercury concerning a Mackay family which found itself, not quite overnight but it might just as well have been overnight, homeless. That article which appeared last Wednesday, was headed 'Mackay family without a home'. It made the following point:

SPEECH.PARA: A Mackay woman with six children, aged between seven months and 11 years, is one of the homeless families searching for accommodation in Mackay.
Mrs Narelle Young has been living with neighbours and in a caravan for three weeks.
I point out at this stage that Mrs Young is one of the quarter of a million people in Australia who are presently living in mobile homes. The article continues:

Despite assistance from neighbours, the St Vincent de Paul Society, Legal Aid, State Government Community Health Services, Mackay real estate agents, Housing Commission representatives and others the family is still living in a small folding caravan at Central Caravan Park.

I am not particularly addicted to travel by caravan or camping out, but the concept of a family comprising husband, wife and six children, whose ages range between seven months and 11 years, living in a folding caravan at Central Caravan Park does not seem to be particularly appealing. Mrs Young had been attempting, with some vigour, to find alternative accommodation after the home that she had been renting was sold out more or less from underneath her. The article continues:
She said that one of her main problems had been finding a house that would accommodate six children.
. . . She put her name down for a Housing Commission home in February this year.

A spokesman for the Minister for Works and Housing, Mr C. A. Wharton, said that even the priority list in Mackay was extensive. There was little that could be done, as Mrs Young's name was not on the priority list.
I do not know what one has to do in Queensland to get on the priority list but apparently Mrs Young did not qualify. The article continues:

Mrs Ruth Atkinson said the St Vincent de Paul Society had been trying to get a Housing Commission home for Mrs Young, but because she did not have an eviction notice she had to go onto the normal waiting list.
Presumably in Queensland an eviction notice is required before one gets on the priority list. The article continues:
The St Vincent de Paul Society had offered help of food and clothing.

Mackay Life Line and the Mackay branch of the St Vincent de Paul Society had obviously exhausted all of their resources as far as helping Mrs Young was concerned. Of course, such organisations should not in any instance be responsible entirely for solving the welfare and housing problems of people in Mr and Mrs Young's position. These people have been caught up in a low wage, high family cost, rental payment, deposit chasm, circle. As I have said before in debates in this place, the problem of the increasing demand for public housing is almost entirely due to Government policies in other areas, particularly its commitment to the deregulation of interest rates and the effect of this on young couples with or without children who aim to fulfil what is generally accepted as the great Australian dream of owning their own home. Not only are people forced into attempting to bridge an ever-increasing deposit gap but also constantly increasing interest rates mean constantly increasing repayment rates.

Whereas 10 years ago, when I first brought my home, one could be fairly assured that the interest rate with which one started would at least be maintained at the same level for a number of years, interest rates now seem to change almost on a month by month basis, so that people are not even in a position to budget accurately. Of course, this means that there is an increasing demand for rental accommodation. As rental accommodation declines-as it is absorbed by those who are not able to purchase or build their own homes-rental increases become inevitable, partly because of a demand-supply situation and partly because often landlords themselves are faced with increasing interest rates on their mortgages . This, in turn, leads to an increasing demand for welfare or public housing.

I direct the attention of honourable senators, and anybody else who may be listening to this debate and who is interested in the plight of people in Mrs Young's position, to a booklet published by the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace, entitled House and Home-A Christian Call for Housing Justice. The booklet is the result of a study conducted over a 12-month period by that Commission and contains not only case studies but also particularly interesting statistics.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was a distinguished member of that Commission.
—No doubt Senator Tate was a distinguished member of a distinguished body. At page 4 the booklet states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is estimated by welfare organisations that between 100,000 and 300,000 people are homeless, one or two in every 100 of the population. In Sydney, there are 3,000 homeless young people every night. In 1978 4,500 homeless women and their children were turned away from refuges.

This seems to be an astounding situation to be allowed to develop, when one considers exactly what the housing industry contributes to the economy of Australia. It is not a minor industry. The booklet goes on to point out that the housing system is enormous and complex. It includes, of course, people who need housing; the supplying of housing; the building industry; the financial institutions-banks, building societies and finance companies; developers and speculators. Naturally, the Federal and State governments are involved. Also involved are the taxation system; the legal system; various other institutions such as hospitals, nursing homes, prisons and youth hostels; the buyers and renters of housing; and mechanisms for distributing the costs and benefits of housing and the rights over housing.

Indisputably, housing is a major industry in Australia, one which requires large amounts of capital and employs hundreds of thousands of people nationwide. Housing construction is a significant indicator of economic activity and therefore, of the economic well-being of the society as a whole. That should not be news to anybody. It should not take somebody with a degree in economics to work out just how important is the building of housing to the community. The stocking of a house, once built, with carpets, curtains, various white goods and so on, is an integral part of the housing industry. It is no coincidence that in South Australia Kelvinator, one of the major suppliers of white goods in this country, has had to retrench large numbers of employees simply because the demand is not there-partly due to the fact that people are not building new homes into which they can put those commodities and partly due to the fact that they are not replacing such commodities as frequently as they would otherwise do , simply because the demands of mortgage repayments on their income are so severe.

In August 1980, the Australian Bureau of Statistics published a housing survey of the Sydney-Newcastle-Wollongong region. Amongst other things that survey indicated that over 70 per cent of renters who were interviewed in those areas wanted to own their own homes. In fact, according to that survey home ownership seems to be the aspiration of about 90 per cent of Australians. As the Catholic Commission points out, there are very good reasons why people should want to own their own homes. In Australia a number of benefits can come from home ownership- social and cultural benefits, individual benefits, personal and community development, and a sense of continuity and belonging, which is an integral part of any sort of national feeling in a country. Of course, these benefits do not come exclusively from home ownership, but the Commission asserts that they are best guaranteed to most Australians by home ownership. Nevertheless a great many people do not and cannot enjoy those benefits.

According to the Commission's study, the major sufferers are the poor. The housing situation is a serious problem for young people, especially in times of high unemployment; for most people who receive social security benefits, whose weekly income is below the poverty line; for the aged, particularly those living alone or needing home support services such as Meals on Wheels, home help and domiciliary nursing to be able to remain in their own homes; for most young families, especially those with children, who are at present renting because increasing costs are making it almost impossible for them to meet any deposit gap; and for Aborigines, many of whom live in conditions as inadequate as those found in any of the least economically developed countries.

The problem is most serious in inner metropolitan areas in the major cities, but it is spreading increasingly, as the Mackay situation indicates, into country areas. People find that they are unable to get the accommodation they require in city areas and therefore turn to country areas in the hope that more opportunities may be available to them. As Mrs Young discovered in Mackay, that is not always the case. This leaves people with a problem which would appear to be insurmountable in that they do not have a roof over their heads. They are unable to rent, are unable to bridge the deposit gap to build or to purchase a home, and are often unable to live with neighbours or relatives. They are forced , as the Youngs were, into a caravan, a mobile home-one of the homes which as I said earlier are occupied by something in the vicinity of a quarter of a million Australians. If they do not do that, they move into boarding houses. When the worst comes to the worst, they seek accommodation in public housing as this provides the least expensive accommodation with the greatest amount of security.

Public housing authorities cannot cope with the demands placed on them in the present crisis situation. The Commission notes that in recent years the waiting lists for public housing have grown at increasing rates so that now many applicants for public housing wait up to four or six years or even longer for their homes. In the case of Mr and Mrs Young, this could well mean that their youngest child, who is at present seven months old, will be attending school and still have no concept of what it is like to live in a permanent home. Those who cannot get high on the priority list for housing commission or housing trust homes are forced to remain as best they can in the private rental market. It has been estimated by the Commission that well over a quarter of a million pensioners are renting in the private market. In order to maintain their rental payments they are forced to cut back on other things-food and clothing being the two obvious ones.

It would seem to me that this is an appalling indictment of the Government's policies and its lack of action. The problem can only get worse if it continues to be ignored or to be band-aided by miserly increases in funding in the face of a situation which indicates that dramatic injections of funding are necessary if we are to get anywhere near to solving this problem. My party does not oppose this legislation; far from it. The Australian Democrats wish only that the alleged increase in funds for public and welfare housing provided through this piece of legislation was a meaningful one and sufficient to meet the needs of the growing number of people who through no fault of their own are forced into the welfare housing arena.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Bill 1982. I wish to respond to the debate on the second reading, and in particular to the remarks of Senator Haines because her remarks were addressed mainly to the provisions relating to housing, the welfare aspects of which come within my portfolio responsibilities. Earlier in the debate Senator Haines made some statements which I heard over the speaker in my room so I may have misheard her. She referred to the fact that in the current Budget there had been no real growth in the allocation for welfare housing. If that is indeed what she said, I wish to put on the record that that statement is not correct. In fact this year the cash provided to the States for welfare housing represents an increase of 27 per cent . The figure for last year was $262m and for this year it is just under $333m. So, as was announced at the time of the Premiers Conference, there has been a quite significant increase in the allocation for welfare housing.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government also announced at the Premiers Conference that it was prepared to permit the States to nominate additional funds from their general works and housing programs for additional expenditure on welfare housing. As an incentive to the States to do that, the Government indicated that it was prepared to make available those additional funds on the very concessional conditions that are allowed for under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. They involve a very long period of repayment-something over 50 years-and a very low rate of interest . I am delighted to say, now that we have before us the evidence of the State Budgets, that this has had precisely the effect the Commonwealth wished when it put forward that proposition. The figures are not yet final because the States are currently seeking the consent of the Commonwealth to bring funds within that provision. However, the State Budget figures brought down so far include $137.4m nominated by the States and the Northern Territory as additional funds for welfare housing in 1982-83 out of their works and housing programs.

So in fact there has been a very considerable increase in State allocations for welfare housing. The Commonwealth action at the time of the Premiers Conference has been an important contributor to giving the States flexibility in that area. A table which has been prepared by my Department details the funds for welfare housing, and I will seek leave to incorporate that table in Hansard. It shows expenditure by the Commonwealth and the States, including State internal funds, over the period 1973-74 through to 1982-83. It therefore addresses the sorts of concerns which were the concerns of the Catholic and other bishops who I think were referred to earlier in the debate, and it throws some light on the general provision which has been made. I think it would be fair to say that in general it shows a declining provision by the Commonwealth contemporaneously with a rapidly increasing commitment by the States. That is compatible with the general approach of this Government, which has been to concentrate on the general revenue grants to the States rather than on specific purpose payments.

The fact is that the volume of expenditure has held up because the States have increased their commitments while there has been a general reduction of the Commonwealth commitment. However, during the current year there was a reversal of that reducing Commonwealth commitment. That reversal, the increase of 27 per cent to which I have referred-the freeing up in works and housing funds-was a concession to the sort of factors that have been brought out in this debate. The Government wishes to respond to the concerns which exist and to the reality of a greater need for welfare housing under current circumstances. I seek leave to incorporate this table in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The table read as follows-

(b) Implicit Gross National Expenditure (GNE) deflator. The 1982-83 estimate is based on the Budget forecast of 11 per cent increase in the non-farm product deflator.
