In South Australia in 1982-83 (and 1981-82) an amount of State funds provided outside the CSHA has not been included as this is not yet available.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I also point out that the welfare housing side of things is but one aspect of the Government's approach to housing. A good deal of attention was given in the current Budget to the housing problems of Australians generally. We have had some discussion in the Senate, and some criticism, about the fact that the Government has not devoted its attention solely to welfare housing aspects but has looked also to the interests of all Australians who are seeking to purchase their own homes.

SPEECH.PARA: The outstanding new development in the current Budget is the new tax rebate available to all home buyers who are paying interest in excess of 10 per cent. That is a very valuable concession to people who, as Senator Elstob from the Opposition benches might well know, are feeling some strain because of the increases in interest costs. It is a very considerable cost to the Budget but it is a concession which I think will be widely welcomed in suburban Australia by Australian home purchasers. In addition, as part of the housing package introduced earlier this year we have increased the housing deposit assistance available. It has been made as near to contemporaneous as possible with the actual purchase of a house and we have therefore tried to provide real assistance to those who have the problem of making the original deposit. We have taken action with the banks to increase the flow of funds in that important area of the provision of housing finance. So a range of measures has been taken.

At the welfare end, not part of the works and housing budget but very relevant to the matters raised in this debate, we have instituted a $20m a year program with the State governments to provide mortgage and rent relief. We are in the process of finalising those arrangements with the States but it is important for those people concerned about the welfare aspects of housing to note that we will henceforth, in co-operation with the States, be providing relief both to people who have difficulties with their mortgage payments and to those having difficulty meeting rent payments. As that program is jointly funded it will involve expenditure this year of some $40m, which should be a significant welfare contribution.

This is not a debate on welfare but I understand the relevance of the points raised by honourable senators because the works and housing program does have a direct welfare impact, both in terms of the creation of employment and in the provision of accommodation. I mention in that vein the fact that in the general programs of the Government which touch upon the accommodation of disadvantaged Australians, the Budget does contain increased provisions. I refer to the categories about which this can be said. We have the Aged and Disabled Persons Housing Program in which additional capital funds have been made available for both this year and next year. We have the Handicapped Persons Assistance Program , part of which goes to the provision of accommodation services. Funds available for this year and next year have been increased. We have the Homeless Persons Assistance Act under which we have taken a further step in regard to the $10m program which we promised and which will be exceeded in capital expenditure during the life of the current Government. We have the Youth Services Scheme, to which we have made an additional allocation. That is an experimental program which provides accommodation for homeless youth. We have doubled the allocation under the Family Crisis Accommodation Program, which provides money to the States so they can provide accommodation for families in crisis. That has been increased from $2m to $4m. I have already referred to the Mortgage and Rent Relief Scheme.

Additional money for housing goes out to another disadvantaged group in the community-the Aboriginal population-through the Aboriginal Development Commission which has received a total of something like $50m for expenditure in this year. In other words, I respond to the debate by saying that yes, the Government does acknowledge that there is a difficulty in the welfare housing area. It has taken a series of steps which are aimed at reducing the pressures in that area. I respectfully agree with those who said in the debate that this will not solve the problem but I believe it is a significant contribution towards easing it. I point to the important multiplier effect which was present in the Federal Government's providing a concession to the States where they were prepared to allocate additional funds to works and housing. It is notable that the Victorian Government was able to increase its welfare housing expenditure by , I think, 82 per cent and is seeking the advantage of that concession. There was reference to an increase in my own State of Western Australia from $7m to $ 20. I must say I have not quite got to the bottom of that but again it is an indication of a very greatly increased emphasis on welfare housing. I acknowledge the difficulties but I point to a series of measures taken by the Government to reduce those difficulties and I commend the legislation to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security ( Senator Chaney) mentioned the Mortgage and Rental Relief Scheme in his contribution to the debate. Can he give us a rundown of how the Scheme is operating at present?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not give a State by State or Territory by Territory description of the Mortgage and Rental Relief Scheme because, quite frankly, I do not have all that material with me. I can advise the Committee that we have written to all State and Territory governments advising them of their allocation from that $20m. There have been extensive officer level negotiations in respect of the conditions which will apply. The Commonwealth has sought to give the States and Territories a fair amount of freedom in the administration of the Scheme but it has laid down broad guidelines which the States and Territories are required to follow. For example, it requires that not less than a quarter of the funds be devoted to mortgage or rent relief. In other words, we do not leave it open to the States or Territories to provide solely mortgage relief or solely rent relief. From a purely welfare point of view, it is my very strong view that it is essential to have an element of rental relief. There is great enthusiasm in some States for ensuring that there is a mortgage relief scheme for those who are really on the borderline between being able to own their own homes and not. Perhaps it is worth noting that in a number of States we are adding to schemes which already existed for some degree of mortgage relief and, in some cases, for rent relief. The present position is that negotiations are virtually complete I think in all States and Territories and I would expect to be in a position to make public announcements with the relevant Ministers in the very near future. With some States we are at the point of simply settling the terms of the announcement.

SPEECH.PARA: The States and Territories do carry the burden of administration. That is appropriate because they directly administer welfare housing. They have jurisdiction over such things as building societies, which are very important in some States. They have jurisdiction over the terminating building societies as well. There are other terms to describe those organisations but I am sure the Committee knows what I mean. We are well advanced on that. We have a three-year program for mortgage and rent relief which we hope will ensure that a lot of people who are on the border between managing on their own resources and not managing will be assisted over difficult periods by these funds.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do I understand that the Minister for Social Security will table some material when that public statement is made, giving us more information?
—There will be public announcements when the details are finalised. I would expect, in the main, that the announcement will be joint announcements by me and State and Territory Ministers.

—The Minister for Social Security, in his response to the second reading debate, referred to, among other initiatives by the Government, the arrangements that were made with the banks for an injection of funds into the housing area. I presume that he was referring to the $400m that the banks were expected to put into the housing area in exchange for a one per cent increase in interest rates.
—That is right.

—At some stage there were some knotty problems in getting that money out into the community. Would the Minister be able to provide any figures on how much of that $400m has been spent by the banks on the housing program on which the Government envisaged that it be spent?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have to seek up to date information on that matter. It is true, particularly I think in the first quarter following that announcement, that there was some concern, but the undertaking was to increase the amount of funds over the following 12 months, so it was always expected that that would be a gradual process. My understanding is that that is now well advanced, but I would have to get those figures and let the Senate have them. I do not think that there is any suggestion in the inquiry that we should delay the legislation pending that. I would be happy to pursue that information and to make it available to the Senate .

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Chaney) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: STUDENT ASSISTANCE (LOANS GUARANTEE AND SUBSIDY) BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 September, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Bill 1982, simply stated, is to provide a loans scheme for students. The scheme, as it is explained, is intended to be supplementary or in addition to availability of other means of finance for students-first of all, the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme; secondly, finance available to students from loans schemes available from existing institutions, such as univerisities and colleges of advanced education; and thirdly, post-graduate awards. In addition, the scheme is subject to certain income levels; that is to say, a means test is applied in circumstances in which students are not recipients of financial assistance from TEAS or other schemes already in existence.

SPEECH.PARA: I should say at the outset that this Bill is a little short on detail, and a considerable number of matters in the Bill are to be left to regulations made by the Minister at a later date. I think it can be said that the intention of this Bill is clear from the Budget Speech, in which the Treasurer (Mr Howard) said:
The foreshadowed Tertiary Student Loans Scheme will commence from the beginning of 1983.

Subject to a means test, loans of up to $1000 per year to a total of $8000 over the period of full time tertiary study will be available, with a generous interest rate subsidy and exemption from repayment for up to two years after completion of study.
Thereafter a repayment period of up to 10 years is provided for.
The Minister for Education will announce further details.

It is important in understanding this legislation to remember the background to it. Some senators will remember the Committee of Inquiry into Education and Training, the Williams Committee, which took two years to report. It was a very high level committee. During those two years this Parliament was continually told that no decisions could be made about education until the Williams Committee reported. When it finally reported, its pronouncements were described by certain Ministers as a blueprint for education to the year 2000. If that was the blueprint, very little has been done about it. Very few of the Williams Committee recommendations have been implemented in any significant way. But in relation to the Committee's references to student assistance, I remind the Senate of Professor Blandy's research paper which was appended to the report and which caused a lot of excitement in government circles. Professor Blandy was advocating a loans scheme in substitution for any other form of student assistance. At that stage of this Government's history, a loans scheme seemed to fit in with the current ideology which it had at that time, much of which has been abandoned since, and the enthusiasm for a loans scheme was, as I say, highly marked, to the point of causing excitement.

In a sense, this heady excitement of the post-Williams era was confirmed in part by the report of the so-called razor gang, the Review of Commonwealth Functions, which was tabled in April 1981. In that report this was said about student assistance:
From the beginning of 1982, however-
Note 1982, not 1983-

. . . a loans scheme will be introduced for tertiary students. This will enable them to supplement their current income by amounts which will be repayable after graduation. This is a form of assistance which recognises the substantial benefits flowing to individuals from a higher education and thus expresses a sound balance of community and individual interest. It reduces the burdens on taxpayers in an entirely appropriate way. The availability of this additional form of financial assistance will be taken into account in determining the level of benefits under the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme.

I want to make some comments about that passage from the Review of Commonwealth Functions, which was instituted by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). The first is that there is intrinsically or by implication in that statement a recognition-empty rhetoric, I would suspect-of the benefits flowing to individuals from higher education. Secondly, there is the commitment to reduce the burden on the taxpayer. Thirdly, there is that statement at the end that the loans scheme will be taken into account in determining the level of benefits available under the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme. I do not know that I am reading anything into that, but I think that the obvious conclusion that people would draw from that is that the level of benefits under the Scheme would not be increased or would, perhaps, be reduced once a loans scheme of the kind envisaged in the razor gang statement was in position.

One is entitled to be suspicious-and many people have been suspicious-that the Government wanted to replace TEAS with a loans schemes. That suspicion is fuelled by the reaction to the Williams Committee report and by the statement in the Review of Commonwealth Functions report. But the suspicion is absolutely confirmed; in our view, by the letter from the Treasurer to the banks when the details of the loans scheme were being discussed and were the subject of correspondence between this Government and the banks. In that letter of September last year, the Treasurer had this to say:

I am prepared to accept that a minimum loan of $500 per annum is reasonable, but I think it will be apparent that unless the annual lending is raised considerably there would be substantial problems for the Government in representing a loans scheme as a substitute for increases in the TEAS allowance.

There the Treasurer is saying, quite clearly in a letter to the banks-maybe by sleight of hand what is said to the banks is not said to the people-that the Government did not intend to increase the TEAS allowance and that it wishes to represent the loans scheme as a substitute for increases in the TEAS allowance. That was the intention; that was the plan. But like everything else which came out of the razor gang's recommendations, the bang was reduced to a whimper. The list of such examples is long. The Australian Wool Testing Authority, which was to be abolished, remains; the Bendigo Ordnance Factory which was to be sold remains in government hands; the size of the Public Service was to be reduced but it has increased. All of these things are examples of the empty rhetoric of the razor gang period and can be seen from day to day as the facts are revealed about what that much vaunted exercise has cost the Australian community. What we have had are little bits of token legislation bringing some benefits to some students but this present Scheme, after all the talk about it in earlier days, is essentially a Mickey Mouse scheme in pursuit of the empty rhetoric of earlier years.

The Opposition has some very major criticisms of this Bill and I will come to its attitude to it a little later. But the major criticisms of the Bill are simply these: It does not address real issues in education; it does nothing and it will do nothing to increase access to post-school education in Australia. It fails to address the real issues of conditions of living and study which are enjoyed by Australian students who have been able to obtain access to post- school education. The Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission indicates that full time enrolments in post-secondary education have fallen by 12,000 between 1977 and 1981. That is an indicator of how much this Government is concerned about access to post-secondary education. I make the point that in 1977 Australia's participation rate, as it is called-that is the number of students participating in post-school education-was abysmal compared with the standards in other countries which enjoy an equivalent degree of economic sophistication.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not exactly encouraged to participate, are they?

—That is the point I am trying to make. I am grateful for the honourable senator's help. If one goes back to 1977, participation rates in Australia were abysmal compared with the standards which applied in such countries as the United States of America, Canada, Japan and a number of European countries. Since then the number of students in Australia participating in post-secondary education, according to the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission, has fallen by 12,000. Since the Fraser Government came to power the comparative living standards of the Australian people have declined from No. 8 on the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development list to No. 15 and so have the standards of participation in post-secondary education. We are becoming comparatively a less affluent community and a less educated community in terms of post-secondary education. We started from a bad base in terms of the number of young people in this country who are going on to undertake post- secondary education.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was referring to the Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Bill 1982. I had been seeking to make the point that this Bill, in a sense, is a Mickey Mouse scheme, after the heady rhetoric of earlier days about the prospect in the minds of many members of this Government, including the Treasurer, of winding down the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme and replacing it with a loan scheme for all students-I nearly said a loan scheme for all seasons, which may have been equally appropriate. The point I was seeking to make was that a very major criticism of this Bill is that it does not address the major concerns of education in this country which were dealt with in part by reports such as the report of the Williams Committee of Inquiry into Education, Training and Employment and a variety of other reports, including Tertiary Education Commission reports over various years. I had just made the point that full time enrolments in post-secondary education has fallen by 12,000 between 1977 and 1981 and that in terms of this country the 1977 figures were nothing to be proud of, and that in fact very few or relatively few students in the post-secondary education age group were in tertiary education compared with other countries.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission has been pointing out in a number of its recent reports, as I said, that full time enrolments fell by 12, 000 in the relevant years and that simultaneously there was a fall of 25 per cent in the proportion of 17-year-old cohorts, as they are called, proceeding direct from school to higher education. If the proportion of 12-year school leavers proceeding to university or college had, for example, remained in Australia at the 1974 level, there would have been an extra 8,000 young people who would have enrolled in the year 1981 alone. Since the era of the much maligned Whitlam Government there has been a very significant decline in post- secondary enrolments. If we multiply that figure or project that figure of 8,000 young people who might have enrolled in 1981, it suggests that something like 25 ,000 young Australians who would have been enrolled in courses at universities and colleges in 1974 have been lost to post-secondary education, that is, they have gone missing. That is 25,000 young Australians who, if the program of the Labor Government had continued, might well have been in tertiary education or post-secondary education and who have been lost to it.

Of course, the reality of the situation is that there are now over 120,000 young Australians on the dole. Whatever the current economic circumstances are, there is universal agreement that they are pretty bad. If we are to come out of these current bad economic circumstances utilising the human skills of this country then there is one thing that one can say with certainty, and that is that this country will be better off both in economic terms and in its capacity to grow and to contribute to the region in which Australia is situated.

There is, of course, substantial evidence to suggest that the most important factor in the withdrawal of talent from education has been the gradual but persistent decline in the level of financial support available for tertiary students. The costs of that to this country are enormous in terms of lost opportunities and lost developments. Australia has often been described as a resource rich country. It is an extraordinary fact that one of the factors which have made significant export markets for Australia in the past has been its natural resources and not the product of the skills of this society. If we look at societies around the world, it is those societies which are skill based as distinct from resource based which have had by far the greatest success in export markets and in the general situation of their economies. Australia languishes in tragic loneliness almost in respect of its dependence on resource development exports as distinct from skill based exports. Not only are the costs enormous in terms of the national economy but also of course they are enormous in terms of the opportunities for the development of young Australians through the education system. That is not just my view. It is a view that is supported by the Tertiary Education Commission. The Commission, in volume 1 of its report, had this to say:

The Commission indicated its concern with the decline in the participation of the young in higher education. In the context of changes to the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme (TEAS) and the introduction of a loans scheme, the Commission believes that it should draw the matter again to the attention of the Government.
If I might interpolate, that is something that we have been doing for several years. The report continues:

Both the increasing pace of technological change and the fall in the number of full-time jobs for teenagers make it important that able young men and women avail themselves of educational or training opportunities. A decline of one- fifth in the participation of young people in higher education is surely a matter for community concern. It runs contrary to Government policies relating to technological change-
I interpolate again and congratulate the TEC in divining that there are such policies-
and to transition from school to adult life. It raises questions about Australia 's long-term capacity to meet the challenges ahead of it.

That is the crunch issue in many respects in relation to the development of skill and talent and the education system in this country, and it is ignored by this Government. The Commission goes on to say:

As pointed out in volume 1 (Part 1, paragraphs 2.30 and 2.31), the decline in the participation of young people in higher education appears to be related partly to their assessment of the benefits of higher education and partly to the availability of financial support for full-time study. The latter is a matter for Commonwealth Government policy. Since 1975 a major source of support for undergraduates, namely, the teacher training scholarships awarded by State education departments, has been virtually eliminated. Moreover, the real value of grants under TEAS has been eroded by inflation and the real severity of the means test increased. The reversal of the downward trend in the participation of the young, will, at the least, require improved financial assistance to students .

I note in passing that this Government and some sectors of the business community quite cynically and deliberately encouraged scepticism about the value of formal education. The business community has started to change its views on that matter. The Government does not seem to have caught up with that trend.

I return to the matter of the inadequacy of student assistance generally. In 1975 and 1977 the maximum tertiary education assistance benefit equalled or exceeded the level of the unemployment benefit for 18-year-olds and over. Following the increases in the recent Budget, the TEAS benefit is still at least $5 per week less than the unemployment benefit. What is the incentive, in financial terms, to embark on tertiary education when there are very limited assurances about future employment as a result and when the unemployment benefit is pitched at a higher rate?

Of greater importance, however, is the failure of the means test to keep pace with wage and salary increases. In 1975, the last year of the Labor Government, the maximum family income allowed before TEAS eligibility was affected was 100 per cent of average weekly earnings, which now equates to about $15,000. Yet even after this Budget, the means test now operates at $12,248 and fewer students are eligible because of the means test. Fewer students are attracted because of the declining relativity of tertiary assistance schemes to the unemployment benefit. In 1977 approximately 99,000 received TEAS. In 1983 approximately 88,000 will receive TEAS, a decline of approximately 11,000. That figure, though perhaps not connected, is not unrelated to the size of the decline in the number of students participating in tertiary education in Australia-12,000 in the same period.

A further opinion on this issue was expressed in a Commonwealth Department of Education study in 1981 entitled 'Validation of Study of the Costs of Full-time Tertiary Students'. That opinion was expressed in these terms:

In our view, this suggests that shift in the full time student population towards financing by parents-or by themselves-has led to a relative decrease in full time university and CAE students from less privileged backgrounds.

So not only are we discussing the general question of the decline in effective access to education which has been shown by students voting with their feet, but also we are talking again about a shift in socio-economic backgrounds of students, which by any standards has never been good in the country. That standard is going backwards in terms of the socio-economic background of students undertaking post-secondary education. A table published by the committee whose report I have just quoted showed that in 1974 some 21 per cent of students were not on any student assistance scheme. In 1979 some 41 per cent were not on any scheme at all. That is because of the relative movement in the availability of finance under the schemes to which I have referred.

I quote the figures merely to substantiate an argument I put that, as usual, this Government is not addressing the main issues in education, just as it is not addressing the main issues in taxation, in the distribution of wealth in Australia, in industry policy, or anywhere else. I refered to the participation rates in post-secondary education, but the question goes further than that. It goes to the future of this country and the use of the skills and talents of Australian people. It goes to the question of what sort of economic capacity we will have in the future and what sort of export capacity we will have in comparison with other countries. This Bill is almost irrelevant to these major issues in education. Again, I say it is a Mickey Mouse Bill. Maybe this Budget represents the last increase in TEAS by this Government if this loans scheme is in fact a sort of a foot-in-the-door job.

Let me refer briefly to the Bill. I said before that it will do nothing to increase access to education. Secondly, I say it tends to favour students from relatively wealthy backgrounds rather than those on the borderline. Those with more secure economic backgrounds will be much more likely to take out a loan than those with uncertain socio-economic backgrounds. I am prepared to concede, and the Opposition concedes, that it may be of benefit to some students at the margin. This scheme may be of some assistance to some students in middle income groups from relatively well-off socio-economic backgrounds.

TALK.START.PARA: —How would they satisfy the means test?
—I said: 'in the middle income'.
—How would they satisfy the means test?

—I am prepared to concede that that area may be one which will benefit from this Bill. We are not going to oppose this Bill, in spite of the dreadful shortcomings and the sort of stunt element in it which is just a hangover from by-gone days of heady rhetoric. It is not our task to oppose this Bill. However, I want to make it quite clear that, in the context of more adequate and better directed student assistance, an ALP government would abandon this scheme and repeal the legislation. We would give much greater attention to loan schemes already administered by existing institutions, which could be vastly improved.
—Does that mean you will let it through now?

—Just listen. I have only two minutes left and I would sooner not use that time talking to the honourable senator. Our main complaint, however, is that this Bill does not address the real issues. We should make a start in this Parliament on addressing the real issues immediately. Because the real issues ought to be addressed, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out all words after 'That', insert:
'(a) this Bill be referred to the Standing Committee on Education and the Arts for inquiry and report by 16 November 1982;

(b) the Committee take into account (i) the CTEC reference to the declining participation rate in tertiary education and the contribution which the inadequacy of TEAS makes to this alarming development, and (ii) the finding of the study on teritary student finances that the proportion of tertiary students of less privileged backgrounds is declining; and

(c) the Committee report on (i) the proposed agreements between the Government and certain banks, and (ii) the need to provide for regular and automatic adjustments to TEAS to prevent the proposed loans scheme from replacing TEAS as the basic form of student assistance'.

I have moved the amendment because the Opposition believes that this is inadequate legislation and that this Government has not been addressing itself to the important issues relating to the future of this country to which education departments can contribute.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are debating the motion for the second reading of the Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Bill 1982, to which my leader has just moved an amendment. We first noticed something about the student loans scheme when the Budget was introduced on 17 August. We were told by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) at that stage that a tertiary student loans scheme would commence from the beginning of 1983. We were not told much else in the Budget Speech. We were told this:

SPEECH.PARA: Subject to a means test, loans of up to $1,000 per year to a total of $8,000 over the period of full-time tertiary study will be available, with a generous interest rate subsidy and exemption from repayment for up to two years after completion of study.
Thereafter a repayment period of up to 10 years is provided for.
We were told that we would get further details at some later stage. We have received those details-we received them in the Bill that is under discussion tonight.

I had not been in this place very long when the Government decided to inquire into a student loans scheme. So it was no real surprise to find one in front of us when we came here for the Budget session. As I said, I had not been here long when the Government decided it would hold an inquiry into student loans, but it denied at that time that it had any intention of introducing a student loansscheme. I thought the Government had taken a most peculiar stance. At that stage it said it was not going to introduce a student loans scheme but would have an inquiry about one. In other words, it would have an inquiry about something it had no intention of introducing. I can remember during Question Time asking Senator Sir John Carrick, who was then the Minister for Education, why it was necesssary to have an inquiry when he said there was no intention of introducing a student loans scheme. His reply was to the effect that the Government was keeping its options open. It certainly was keeping its options open. It seems to me that ever since that time, which was probably about five years ago, the Government had intended to introduce a student loans scheme. The crunch came when what is popularly called the razor gang report was introduced into this place. I suppose it is more properly called the report on the Review of Commonwealth Functions but hardly anybody calls it that, including some people on the other side who lapse occasionally and call it the razor gang report. When the report was introduced on 30 April 1981 there was a direct indication in the report that a student loans scheme would be introduced. The report, under the heading 'Student Loans', said in part:
A loan scheme, administered by tertiary institutions, to be introduced from the beginning of 1982 as a supplement to TEAS.

Of course, such a scheme was not introduced from the beginning of 1982 because the Government ran into quite a few problems with it. As well as that, the scheme will not be administered by the tertiary institutions. Apparently the institutions have been as wary as the students about the reasons for introducing this loans scheme. I wish to quote from comments made by one university at about that time. The Adelaide Advertiser reported as follows:
The University of Adelaide Council has opposed the Federal Government's tertiary education funding decision.
Later on it said:
It will refuse to administer the ''Loans scheme'' as proposed by the Lynch Committee on the grounds that it will deter disadvantaged students from tertiary study and diminish equality of opportunity.

The universities apparently would not have a bar of administering this scheme. The Government has had to go to the banks to get someone to administer it. The razor gang report stated that the loans scheme would be a supplement to TEAS. What is meant by a 'supplement to TEAS'? Is it regarded as an extra amount that the students will be able to receive-something that they will require to have a living allowance-or will it be a loan to enable them to overcome some temporary but significant financial problem? Apparently it is not the latter. Later on in the Lynch Committee report the Government said:
Changes to TEAS rates to be considered in the light of this additional form of assistance.

This clearly indicates that in the future, if there is to be a student loans scheme, TEAS rates will not be increased as they would normally be increased if students need more assistance to carry on at universities or colleges of advanced education; instead the Government will take into account the student loans scheme as an additional form of assistance. On hearing that the Lynch Committee report stated that changes to TEAS rates would be considered in the light of the additional form of assistance-namely, student loans-most students were rightfully concerned that the loans scheme was the thin edge of the wedge. There was an indication that the emphasis would shift from direct assistance to loans. I believe students had every right to be concerned about this type of shift, from a reliance on TEAS to student loans. They had every right to be concerned if for no reason other than that over past years TEAS has been losing its value because it has not been adjusted in line with movements in the consumer price index.

I want to illustrate that point by quoting from a table which was prepared for me by the Parliamentary Library. The table sets out the TEAS rates in 1974 for at home and independent students. These rates were based on a percentage of average weekly earnings. The table cites figures from 1974 to 1982. In 1974 the at home rate was $850. As a percentage of average weekly earnings that represented 12.8 per cent. The percentage has steadily declined except for one aberration in 1979 when it went up to 13 per cent. Except for that the rate has steadily declined to $1,675 in 1982, which represents 10 per cent of average weekly earnings. There has been a decline in the at home rate from 12.8 per cent to 10 per cent. The independent rate shows a similar trend. In 1974 the maximum amount available was $1,400, which represented 21.1 per cent of average weekly earnings. Now, in 1982, the maximum amount available for an independent student is $2,583, which is 15.4 per cent of average weekly earnings. There has been a drop from 21.1 per cent to 15.4 per cent. I wish to show the table to the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume), who is at the table, and ask whether it can be incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The table read as follows-
MAXIMUM TEAS ALLOWANCES
Per- Inde- At centage pendent Per- home AWE* AWE* centage
* Average of March, June, September and December Quarters AWE.
* First six months only; yearly per cent will be lower due to wage increases.

TALK.START.PARA: —Other figures are available to which I draw the attention of the Senate. The figures were published in a journal so there is no need to incorporate them in Hansard. In the 'Social Security Journal' of 1982, table 4 on page 37 sets out quite clearly the same type of information but in a different manner. The table shows the amounts available for TEAS in constant 1966-67 dollar terms. The table shows that $850 in 1974 the at home rate at that time, was equal to $536 in 1966-67 dollar terms. The table only goes up to 1981 but it shows that in 1981 the amount had declined to $502 in 1966-67 dollar terms. The same sort of thing happened with the away from home or the independent rate. In 1974 the rate was $882 in 1966-67 terms. This had declined to $774 by 1981. The table I have incorporated shows that there has been a steady decline in the purchasing power of the TEAS allowance.

SPEECH.PARA: One could well ask the question: Has this loss of purchasing power had any effect on student numbers? It certainly seems to have done so. I took the opportunity of looking at the Tertiary Education Commission report of February 1981. Table 2.15 in Volume 1, Part 1 of the report contains quite a deal of interesting information. Among that interesting information is an indication that the proportion of year 12 students enrolling in universities or colleges of advanced education immediately after leaving high school has started to show a steady but significant decrease. In 1974 the proportion of year 12 students who went on to universities or CAEs was 54.3 per cent. In 1976 this declined to 51.1 per cent, in 1978 to 45.6 per cent and in 1980 to 42.3 per cent. So from 1974 to 1980 the number of students going on to universities or CAEs decreased from 54.3 per cent to 42.3 per cent. In the 17-year-old group a similar pattern is revealed. The proportion of 17-year-old students who proceeded direct from school to higher education in 1974 was 18 per cent. This decreased in 1980 to 14 .5 per cent, a decrease of 3.5 per cent, and there has been a steady decrease since then. What are the reasons for this? Before I gave those figures I suggested that one of the reasons was probably the fact there had been a loss of purchasing power in TEAS. The Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission states:
Several factors have contributed to the reduced demand from young people for higher education. An important one is the decline in the availability of financial support for full-time study.

So the Tertiary Education Commission clearly sets out that because there is less financial support fewer students are proceeding to higher education after they leave secondary school. The Tertiary Education Commission goes on and reports the fact that in 1975 there was available to people not only a means tested TEAS allowance but also certain State teacher education scholarships which are now no longer available. This, of course, is tied up with the financial aspects and this is one of the reasons that we have fewer students.

In addition to the fact that fewer students are going on to higher education it should be noted that there has been an absolute failure to attract potential tertiary education students from the lower socio-economic backgrounds. This is a problem which bedevils educationists throughout the world and it is very difficult to find a solution which will make sure that people from lower socio- economic groups will go on to higher education. There are many reasons for those problems. One of the problems, of course, is student finance. That may be one of the reasons why we are having some problems in this regard. Volume 2 of the report entitled 'Studies of Tertiary Student Finances'. talking about socio- economic standing of parents of students in universities and CAEs, states:

The 1974 study of income and expenditure patterns of tertiary students found that the parents of those students were heavily over-represented at the top end of the scale relative to the total population of persons age 45 to 54 for both occupation and income. The 1979 data again shows a substantial over- representation at the top end of each of these scales.

The scales the report mentioned were socio-economic scales. I am not saying that we are having problems getting people from those lower socio-economic groups to universities and CAEs only because of finances, but finances constitute a significant area. One may ask: Does all this matter? Should Australia be concerned at a shunning of educational opportunity in the way in which the figures seem to suggest? Should we be concerned at an inability to attract a reasonable proportion of disadvantaged groups to tertiary education? I believe that we should be concerned. If we-I am talking about the Australian people- continue to shun education in the way in which we seem to be shunning it, in particular higher education, the long term effect will be that Australia will slide back and become a Third World country. This slide is now occurring. In 1966 Australia ranked No. 5 in the world in per capita income. By 1973 we had slipped to No. 10 and by 1979 to No. 11. It is interesting to note that from 1970 to 1979 Australia's growth rate in per capita income was 1.7 per cent. Malaysia, in the same period, had a growth rate of 8.5 per cent. What are we to do to redress the trend that has occurred over recent years in all these areas I have been speaking about? Obviously we have to give encouragement to potential students, to those able people who can undertake tertiary education studies. What form of assistance should they get? I come down in favour of a sound tertiary allowance scheme, not a loans scheme. I agree with Professor David Caro , who is the Chairman of the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee. He said:
All of us feel the Tertiary Allowances Scheme should be supported and we are worried that this may not be so as a consequence of the Loans scheme.

Many people would agree with him and believe that we have to be careful and concerned that if we do have a loans scheme we will not have a decrease in the value of our tertiary allowances scheme. What will be some of the consequences if we do have a loans scheme? I believe fewer students will go on to universities, colleges of advanced education and perhaps even to technical and further education institutions. Many will not avail themselves of a scheme which will mortgage their future-and mortgage their future it will. even when they graduate they will not get any joy out of what the Federal Government will say to them when they are perhaps earning some money and ask whether the interest payments on the student loans they are paying off can be deducted from their taxable income. I asked the following question of the Treasurer about this:

In the event of the Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Bill being passed by this Parliament, will a student who repays a student loan after graduation be able to claim either loan repayments or interest payments as income tax deductions?
I have received an answer to that question. The short answer is no, but before I get to that short answer I would like to read the answer that was given to me. It states:

The Commissioner of Taxation has stated that, in the absence of the relevant legislation, it is not possible to express a firm opinion on this question. By way of general comment he stated that, where a student repays a loan after graduation, the question whether he or she will be entitled to an income tax deduction for repayments of principal and interest will be governed by the general deduction provisions of the income tax law. So far as is relevant they provide a deduction for losses and outgoings incurred in gaining or producing assessable income other than losses or outgoings of a capital, private or domestic nature.
The repayments of the loan would be of a capital nature and, consequently, precluded from deduction.
So there we have it. The repayment of the loan would not be an income tax deduction. The answer continues:

Interest on borrowed moneys qualifies for deduction when the moneys borrowed are used for the purposes of gaining or producing assessable income. Under the proposals relating to the Tertiary Student Loans Scheme, the loans are intended for the maintenance of the student and his or her dependants. In these circumstances the interest paid would not qualify for income tax deduction.

As I said, the short answer is no. Once the student graduates even the interest payments will not be regarded as deductible for income tax purposes. I have said that many students will not avail themselves of a scheme that will mortgage their future. In this respect, I agree with Ross Holmes, General Secretary of the Federation of College Academics, who says:
Loans are a further extension of the discredited user pays principle; it is knowledge on hire purchase, and a tax on human investment-our most important national asset.

Students from low income families are unlikely to opt for loans and the financial burden that will result from them. This will further add to the bias, which I mentioned earlier, against lower socio-economic groups at universities and colleges of advanced education.

As well, I am concerned that women are likely to be wary about accepting loans as a means of financing study. Women are likely to have employment problems after graduation and in some cases, unfortunately, earn less. Therefore, probably we will be seeing fewer women opting to take out loans and thus going to universities and colleges of advanced education. Les Wallis, General Secretary, Federation of Australian University Staff Associations, FAUSA, says:
FAUSA has expressed its total opposition to the student loans scheme. It would discriminate against women and minority groups and would inevitably undermine TEAS.

I am also concerned that students from rural areas are likely to be deterred from borrowing. Farm incomes are not sufficiently stable to enable one to look into the future and decide whether one can afford to keep borrowing to go to a university or college of advanced education. It seems to me that that should be a matter of concern, not only to people in rural areas but also to the National Country Party, which seems to be supporting this measure. Perhaps that party no longer really represents these people. If it did it would be concerned about what is proposed.

I recall my time at university. I believe that students at a university or college of education should not regard their place there as a sinecure. If they do, they will not get anything out of it, but there is no reason why their time there should not be in some ways pleasurable. However, all the pleasure will be gone for students if they are caught in default, especially when it is through no shortcoming of their own. The sensitivity of the defaulting student is quite understandable. It seems to me that in other countries students who default are pilloried. A heading to a U.S. News and World Report article of 18 July 1977 reads: 'Time of Reckoning for Student Deadbeats.' That is the way student loan defaulters overseas seem to be pilloried in the literature. I understand that in other countries private collection agencies are used in the pursuit of defaulters and that these agencies sometimes adopt quite unacceptable methods. I have heard of the dismissal of State employees who have not repaid their student loans. I have heard of the names and addresses of student defaulters being published in local newspapers and of ex-students opting for bankruptcy as a way out of their problems following the taking out of student loans.

My main concern about having student loans in Australia is that if such a scheme is introduced we are likely to have in this Parliament the idea that as such loans are available for students, tertiary education assistance need not be sustained at the level at which it would be sustained if such loans were not available. Certainly there is need for some temporary assistance for students who run into financial problems at universities and colleges of advanced education. Most of the students who have gone through a university or college of advanced education have found themselves at some time in a temporary but serious financial situation in which they needed a small loan to help them out. Such loans should be available, but we should not be providing loans to meet living expenses of students and get them through universities and CAEs in that way. If we do, it will give rise to the consequences of which I have spoken. I agree with Paul Carrick, the National President of the Australian Union of Students, when he says:
Students loans are notoriously inequitable and have been a disaster in many overseas countries.

I come down in favour of student allowances and support the amendment of my leader. In conclusion, I remind the Senate that Senator Button's amendment provides, amongst other things, that the Bill be referred to the Standing Committee on Education and the Arts for inquiry and report by 16 November 1982. That would still allow the Senate to consider the report of the Standing Committee and deal with the Bill before the Senate rose for the summer recess. I support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Bill, on which we have heard from two speakers already this evening , provides additional resources for students in higher education and technical and further education courses in Australia. At the moment the expenditure on the Tertairy Education Assistance Scheme, Commonwealth post-graduate awards, Aboriginal study grants and secondary adult assistance schemes totals about $ 200m. This Bill will provide, in the coming calendar year, for the expenditure of $50m-an increase of one-quarter. In the following year another $50m is to be loaned. When the money available to students for tertiary study is taken up and a steady situation has been reached, the provision under this Bill will represent an increase of more than 50 per cent in the moneys available to help students in higher education and technical and further education courses.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard from the Opposition dreary speeches, full of gloom, despite its support of the Bill. Opposition speakers have muddled about making gloomy statements about the proposed loans. It has to be admitted that if a student receives a benefit from the taxpayer, everyone would prefer to have it made by way of grant rather than loan. But that would cost considerably more. Nevertheless, we hear from the Opposition the gloomy statement: 'We support the Bill but why can you not make it all by way of grant.' The coffers of the Government are not bottomless. It is accountable and responsible to the taxpayer . The TEAS allowance has been increased by 20 per cent this year. The Commonwealth post-graduate award has been increased by 48 per cent. Aboriginal study grants and resources have been increased. Indeed, the provision made by way of grant to all student assistance schemes has been increased in order to overcome marginal needs identified in the student loan reports. Additionally, the sum would be available to students to permit them to complete their higher education or technical and further education. Also, the Government would subsidise the interest rate by 5 percentage points. A reduced interest rate will be charged, so there will be a degree of application of the userpays principle. I believe that that represents a fair supplement to the student assistance grants that have long been established in this country. The Menzies Government of 25 years ago introduced the Commonwealth scholarship scheme which transformed higher education in Australia. That was a Liberal Party initiative. It took the elitism out of higher education and enabled students of all backgrounds to compete for scholarships, subject to a means test. It permitted all of modest means to study engineering, politics, medicine, dentistry, economics and so on at universities and colleges.

Eight years ago the Commonwealth scholarship scheme was changed to become the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme but the old Commonwealth post-graduate award continues. During that period, particularly over the last 10 years, a number of needs were identified where students did not have full access to TEAS or Commonwealth post-graduate awards but still had needs of a certain dimension which a loans scheme would truly help them to solve. This is what this Bill does . It sets up a student loans scheme whereby there is a guarantee by the Commonwealth Government of those loans and whereby there is a 5 per cent interest subsidy to the benefit of those students. Any student can take up to $1 ,000 in any one year and $8,000 can accrue throughout the period of a student's studies. The period of repayment is 10 years after a two-year holiday in whch a graduate can establish himself in employment. At no stage does the scheme require the student or graduate to repay the loan at greater than 15 per cent of that person's income. There are constraints and subsidies. It is very carefully worked out to be a very realistic scheme. It borrowed somewhat from the student loans inquiry chaired by Mr M. W. J. Butcher who reported to the Commonwealth Government in May 1977. I quote from page 10 of that report where the Committee' s conclusions were guided by this statement:

The Government's policy that all qualified students should be able to undertake tertiary education without hardship is specially referred to in the Committee's terms of reference and the Committee accepted this as the starting point for its consideration of the subject and the touchstone on which all proposals should be tested.

Let us overcome those remaining areas of hardship and need by way of allowing a student loans scheme to which students can have access much more freely than they could through grants schemes such as TEAS and Commonwealth post-graduate awards. The report of the Williams Committee of Inquiry into Education, Training and Employment, to which Senator Button referred earlier, had appended to it a paper by Professor Blandy which was more radical than this. It took up the argument that many socialists put forward: Why should the taxpayer pay for the tertiary study of largely the children of higher income families? Why should the poorer people in the country through taxation pay for the education of the richer people in the country? That argument, put forward by many socialists, is also put forward by a number of Liberals who believe there should be fairness in the taxation arrangements of Australia. I happen not to subscribe to either of those poles. I believe that the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme is a good scheme as was the Commonwealth scholarship scheme. Certainly, the Commonwealth Post-graduate Awards Scheme, in its much increased and more valuable standing after the Budget, is of enormous importance to ensuring that we have professional graduates with post-graduate experience.

I believe these schemes are sound and must be retained. This loans scheme is truly a supplement to those grants schemes of student assistance. It has already been mentioned tonight that when the conclusions of the Review of Commonwealth Functions were announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in April last year reference was made to the investigation of a student loans scheme which would be supplementary to the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme. This is the burden of this scheme which was announced by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) in mid-August in the Budget.

The aim of the scheme is to give increased access to tertiary education. It is to meet student need and it has the rationale of having a fair balance between a burden on the taxpayers of Australia and a degree of user pays on those who make these borrowings. There could be a number of differently conceived student loans schemes. When I was employed at the University of Adelaide one of my responsibilities for six years was to administer the student loans scheme and I saw the experiences of some hundreds of students in my time. There was assistance directly to more than 1,000 students whereby they gained loans that got them out of particular difficulties, through their studies to the end of a year and ensured that they could keep on track in their course of study.

As many honourable senators know, part time students are not eligible for TEAS. Students from high income families are not eligible for TEAS. In fact less than half of Australia's full time tertiary students receive TEAS. But what if students prefer not to ask their wealthy parents for assistance during those years of study? What happens if parents deny their children some study? Governments cannot enforce obligations within families. It happens in our colleges and universities that there are students who do not receive assistance either from parents or from TEAS. If they are successful, they are some of the most resilient and hard-working students in Australia. Many of those of the older generation of graduate in Australia will say: 'That is how all of us did it. We came through before there were Commonwealth scholarships. We had to work part time and we had to work very hard during the summer in order to pay our way through university or college.' I am not using that as an argument to return to the old days. I am saying: Let us make sure that we have the kind of viable TEAS and Commonwealth Post-graduate Awards Scheme that have been achieved, particularly in the enhanced way following the Budget.

There are students who do not have access to these schemes and this loans scheme, with its wide-eligibility, will enable that increased access. Student loans schemes can be conceived in various ways. In the Butcher report there was a small loans scheme proposal and a large loans scheme proposal. He came up with a recommendation for two types of schemes. This proposal before us tonight in the Senate is a moderate middle way which is fair and balanced. It is not so small in its scope that it does not sufficiently help the student in need, nor is it so large that it is hard to handle or overbearing in terms of the repayments and the costs that may accrue either to the Government or to the student.

What are some of the features of the loans scheme? The loans scheme is not patronising. It does not make a student dependent on others. It requires students to undertake their own commitments, their own accountability for loans that they seek to take out. It is not dependent in any respect upon a parental guarantee and only for students under 21 is it dependent upon a parental means test. Otherwise there would be such an outcry because students of wealthy families would have the same access to a loans scheme as those of lower parental incomes. Individual students themselves undertake the terms of the loan and of repayment of the loan. The loans scheme does not discriminate unfairly. It does not discriminate at all between groups of students. It will be just as easy for a woman as for a man to gain a loan. It will be just as easy for a mature student as for a school leaver to undertake a loan.

The eligibility criteria are very simple. A student needs to be full time, an Australian citizen or permanent resident and to have a taxable income in the previous taxation year of less than $5,000. There are a few exceptions that widen the eligibility. Those who already receive TEAS or Commonwealth post- graduate awards are automatically eligible for a loan even if their income does exceed $5,000 a year. Those are the kinds of eligibility criteria that are determined for this loans scheme. It does not matter whether a student comes from the country or the city, whether the student is a man or a woman or is young or old. No eligibility criterion relates to the ability to repay the loan. The scheme, built upon a Government guarantee, assumes that any student undertaking a course at a college or university will be able in due course to meet the repayment and, if he cannot, the Government is the guarantor and pays out the loan. At no stage in those 10 years after the loan has been taken out does the scheme require greater than 15 per cent of income to meet the repayments.

The loans scheme is realistic. I do not believe it is burdensome. It has a 5 per cent subsidy, coming from the taxpayer, built into it. At the moment the interest rate for borrowings up to $100,000 from banks is 14.5 per cent. With the 5 percentage point subsidy from the Government, that interest rate to the borrower is reduced to 9.5 per cent. If the going interest rate for overdraft and similar borrowers in banks were 10 per cent, then students would be required to meet only 5 per cent of the interest on the loan. I think, too, that the loans scheme has a particular generosity for those most excellent students who gain Commonwealth post-graduate awards. They are competitive awards, as is well known, and those with first class degrees can go on to masters and Ph.D. studies or other higher diploma studies, and they compete with one another to gain those awards.

In this Budget the grant for a Commonwealth post-graduate scholar was increased by 48 per cent. In addition, whereas there was a limit of $500 that could be gained by a second award, say from a university or from a private scholarship, that has now been extended to $1000 extra from a second scholarship, if it is given by a university, and to $5,000 extra if it is given by way of a private scholarship. So a Commonwealth post-graduate award holder in certain circumstances may have $6,500 from the award itself, $5,000 through a private scholarship-that takes it up to $11,500-and, if there is some need, given family responsibilities or living needs, he could still automatically apply for a $1, 000 loan. I believe that that is indeed generous. It is the kind of generosity which a number of us on the Government side urged the Government to take on so that we could ensure that there were sufficient resources for post-graduate study in Australia. Of course, the number of Commonwealth post-graduate awards in this coming year, 1983, will be increased from 800 to 900 awards. Similarly, any person who holds a tertiary education allowance will be able to gain the loan.

Some objections have been expressed in regard to the loans scheme. Even some of those objections cited by the Opposition speakers tonight were raised months ago , when there was still speculation on what the loans scheme would be about. Because it was speculated that full interest would be paid by students and that it would be a burdensome loans scheme, it was understandable that some education commentators raised some objections to what they thought was going to happen. But, lo and behold, the Budget announcement was not what was put up as the Aunt Sally by student organisations and others. It was a moderate, balanced and fair loans scheme providing an additional quarter of resources from which tertiary students in Australia could draw.

When one asks those same early objectors to the loans scheme whether the funds will be taken up by students they say that of course they will, that the whole $ 50m will go in 1983, that students will jump at the additional resources in order to meet some of their current needs. In fact, they ask what barriers will be put in place to ensure that the money goes to those in greatest need and what will stop a student from getting his $1,000 and spending it on some frivolous thing, or at least on something which may be important to him but which is not directly involved in his tertiary study. I believe it is contemplatable for the Government to require some undertaking at the time a student takes out a loan that the money will be used for a bona fide education-related purpose, even if it is to provide a vehicle necessary to get to a university or college or to meet living costs. It would be most inappropriate for this loan to be taken out and immediately invested in some speculative scheme, earning 17 1/2 per cent interest. That would be a very irresponsible way for any student to act. I am sure that Australia will not be seeing much of that. That is the only area where there may be some objection because, if we trace the objections made in this debate, they were also made before the Budget announcement of the details of the scheme, which is a balanced, fair and reasonable scheme.

The first objection put up was that the loans scheme will displace TEAS and other student allowance programs. How can that be credible when this year's Budget, to have effect in 1983, provides a 20 per cent increase in the real value of TEAS, a substantial increase in the adjusted family income on which the means test is based, and half as much again for the Commonwealth post-graduate award? When there have been such substantial increases in the grants available for student allowances, I believe that this objection falls flat. The report of the Review of Commonwealth Functions said that the loans scheme would be supplementary to TEAS. Both the former Minister for Education, the Hon. Wal Fife , and the present Minister for Education, the Hon. Peter Baume, have always said that the Tertiary Student Loans Scheme is supplementary to TEAS, the Commonwealth post-graduate awards, the Aboriginal study grants and the adult secondary education grants. So, when we have seen that consistency of statements by Ministers and the enormous increases with regard to the grants schemes, particularly the Commonwealth post-graduate award, I believe that this objection indeed falls flat. The interest subsidy in the scheme is only $2 1/2m. If we calculate 5 per cent of $50m, it comes to a bill to the Government of $2 1/2m in any one year. The Government is already providing about $200m in grants schemes, so the actual cost to the Government of a one per cent increase is of very small consequence in terms of cost to the taxpayer. That is the advantage. It makes available a very substantial increase in student resources at a small, reasonable cost to the taxpayer.

A second objection put up is that the loans scheme will discriminate against some groups of students and so deny them the wider access that the scheme provides. I have already referred to this. Of course, it is an assumption of that objection that there will be wider access. Some Opposition speakers say that they want the wider access for women and for mature students; they want the wider access that the loans scheme will give. I believe that the Minister in his summing up-as he did in his second reading speech and as the operation of the Act will show-will be able to authoritatively affirm that there will not be discrimination between groups of students. I understand the regulations will be available by the end of November so that the scheme can operate from the beginning of next year.

A third objection is that there is no need for a student loans scheme. As I have said, 60 per cent of full time students do not receive TEAS grants, persons who are doing second degrees are not eligible for TEAS, and students who fail are not eligible for TEAS; they have to repeat using their own resources. Are we going to rule out the chance of someone completing his course of study because he has the misfortune to fail a year? Surely we ought to be able to make some resource available-not to repeat TEAS-to which people have access and which they can later repay from their earnings as graduates. Then there are unexpected crises that bring financial hardship to some students and a student loans scheme helps to meet that.

Another objection that has been raised by some is that the students will not participate in the loans scheme. But even on the testimony of those most opposed to this scheme the whole $50m would be subscribed during 1983. They admit that. If the $50m is taken up, with $1,000 as the full amount, by all those participating, it will help 50,000 students, whereas if the minimum amount of $ 500 is taken, it will help 100,000 students. Shall we deny this Bill to the students of Australia? The Senate should pass the Bill, and pass it quickly, so that those 50,000 to 100,000 students will have the additional resource.

In my old university I asked what the student loan take-up was this year. In 1981 there were 74 student loans at an average of $600. This year there have been more than that number, at an average of $700. Students do take up loans to meet the needs of their studies, but the trouble is that not all universities and colleges have established student loans schemes. This is a national program available in every part of Australia for all college and university students, and it should be directly of assistance to them. I believe that it will be taken up.

The other objection is that the student loans scheme will be administratively costly. I should like to seek leave, Mr Acting Deputy President, to incorporate in Hansard an extract from Estimates Committee B which gives the exact cost of the administration of this scheme, which is totalled for the first year of establishment at $1,070,000, for a $50m scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is for the first six months, Senator.

—It is indeed for the first six months, because it is the financial year, but it includes the establishment costs of the scheme, the computer facilities, the programs, the forms and so on. The annual cost thereafter will be less. I seek the leave of the Senate for this extract to be incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I conclude by briefly referring to the one group in Australia that has been totally opposed to anything that looks like a student loans scheme-the Australian Union of Students. I believe that the AUS started up earlier this year such a momentum of opposition to anything that was looking like a student loans scheme that it could not itself stop it. It was on a tiger of its own making, and eventually it could not get off. Such was its rhetoric in the earlier months that it went far in excess of reasonable argument . In relation to these proposals, the AUS is quite unrepresentative of the ordinary students of Australia's universities and colleges.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, it came to my attention today that the AUS executive does not meet in an open and representative way, according to the constitution, but that a smaller group of the executive meets beforehand and caucuses on the agenda of the executive meeting and then goes into that executive meeting with its pre- formed views. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing the Student Assistance ( Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Bill 1982. In itself, the Bill seeks merely to allow the Government to offer a guarantee to banks in relation to the granting by banks of loans to students. The Bill is presumably unexceptionable. After all , if there is to be a loans scheme, someone has to guarantee it. It is the principle itself that I wish to address-the notion of loans within the context of tertiary education in Australia. The Australian Democrats do not have an in- principle opposition to loans. Such an opposition would in itself be absurd. There are obvious positions, times and elements in which loans would be an exceptionally good idea. Indeed, we fully support the loans schemes to which Senator Teague has referred. We would add the fact that they are under-funded.

SPEECH.PARA: Those loans schemes have been extremely useful in supporting people in difficult positions, for one reason or another, to be able to continue their studies at an appropriate level. Here, for example, one might suggest that if a person had dependants and his family circumstances became difficult, this may be useful for him to continue through to the end of his studies so that he would have a degree which would make him a more eligible person in the job market. So I make it very clear that the Australian Democrats do not have an in-principle objection to loans. However, we object to the establishment of a loans scheme without the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme being set at a reasonable level , which it is not. We also believe that the TEAS ought to be indexed, which it is not. Because neither of those propositions is in legislative form, we do not propose to support this Bill.
The statement of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) to the banks in first mooting the idea and seeking from them their concurrence was quite plain. He said:
I am prepared to accept that a minimum loan of $500 per annum is reasonable, but I think it will be quite apparent that unless the annual lending is raised-
which the banks did-
considerably there would be substantial problems for the Government in representing a loans scheme as a substitute for increases in the TEAS allowances .

May I suggest a scenario for the Budget debate in Cabinet next year. The Minister for Education, goes to Cabinet, as is his wont, in defence of his ministry and suggests that there should be a rise in TEAS. The Cabinet has two alternatives; it can say yes or no. I believe that the question that could be asked is: 'Have the students taken up the loans that we legislated for last year ?' If the Minister says 'Yes they have' everybody, including Senator Teague, who tonight expressed it in very clear terms, would say: 'That piece of legislation has been a resounding success. We will therefore put more money into loans. I am sorry, Minister, you get no rise in your TEAS.' Or the Cabinet could say: 'Has the loan been taken up?' If the Minister is able to reply 'No, it has not' the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), being a great keeper of the purse, would say : 'If they have not taken up the loans they obviously do not need any more money . Therefore they do not need a rise in TEAS. On to the next subject'. It is a catch-22 situation. It is inevitable in the Budget considerations next year that if this scheme is in operation there will be no rise in TEAS. I believe there can be no dispute about that.

The situation in which this has occurred in other places is that the loans scheme is a replacement for student grants. This Bill is carefully conceived to enable that to happen. Apart from some of the clauses in the Bill to which I have circulated amendments because I believe they are offensive in terms of putting political stipulations on who might be able to receive loans, the people who are eligible are those who fall under current schemes. The only other group outside of that is such an extremely small group because the items are so closely defined, certainly as they are set out in the Treasurer's Budget Speech. In effect the group that we are talking about comprises those who already fall under the eligibility criteria of various schemes which are available at the current time. It is that that adds a weight to the idea that this is carefully sculptured as a substitute for the TEAS allowances.

There are other concerns in relation to loans that I would like to come back to shortly but I will look first at the wider prospect of why we, the Australian Democrats, differ fundamentally from the Government in our approach to education . We do not see education as a cost to the community. We prefer to talk about education as an investment and think of it in the same way. We are therefore seeking to treat education in the same way as we would investment allowances for industry, depreciation allowances for new plant, increased use of new technologies and other such areas. We would like the education debate to be centred on how much this country can afford to put into education this year, not on how much it is going to cost this country to run our education institutions and getting some of the users to pay for it. The users of education in this country are the people of this country. I do not know how many times one has to say that we do not erect education institutions for the delectation and delight of students. We have schools and tertiary institutions for this country's advancement and future. If it were not for that there would be no point at all in funding them. That is why we put money into them. Without them we would be a hill-billy backward country. That is why we put money into education. There is constant talk about the user paying. Yes, let the user pay. The country uses education; let it pay.

It is said that if someone goes to a tertiary institution he will get extra pay when he leaves. I would have thought that a free enterprise government would be happy about that.
