I would have thought that a free enterprise government would say: 'Good on them; let them work hard, get extra qualifications and because a person is worthy of his hire let him receive extra pay'. That is what free enterprise is about. If he gets extra pay he will pay extra tax. That is when we get the money back. He will pay extra tax on a graduated scale and that is what progressive taxation is about. That is the way in which we pay for education and that is the way in which we ought to pay for it. We are now stuck again in an education debate we have had before. I will detail some of the debates that we have had. We have the mindless amalgamation proposals, the surviving item out of the razor gang-everything else collapsed. The Government decided that it would stick with some, not all, of the rather absurd amalgamations. We have had the absurdity-the continuing absurdity-of the pseudo-abolition of the Curriculum Development Centre. We still do not know where it is; it is in some type of legislative limbo. We have had the serious diminution, as can be seen from reports, of the various commissions. I have talked on that matter on a number of occasions when the reports have come before the Senate. We have had the rather mindless attempt-certainly not from this Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume), thank goodness, but from the previous Minister-to shift the responsibilty for unemployment on to the schools. He even went on national television and spoke about it.

We have had the bludgeoning of States into reallocating funds into transition programs from other areas of high need because somebody suddenly got an idea that transition education was a good vote catcher. I suggest that those people who do not know about transition education read some of the more recent literature coming out of the Centre for Transition Education at the Australian National University and some of the critiques being made of the absurd schemes that float under that name. We have had a continual floating around by the Government of its transition program, as though that will help in some way to overcome unemployment. We have had the attempt to make second and higher degrees eligible for fees. That is one thing that Senator Teague managed to forget when he talked about eligibility. Now we have the ill-conceived loans scheme.

There are many ways in which a loans scheme could be introduced and we have constantly championed one of them. I must admit that on the last platform on which I spoke on this matter the Australian Labor Party spokesman for education, who also spoke, had a go at me because I said that I was not in principle objecting to loans. He was totally against loans. Tonight I discovered that the ALP will vote for the Bill.

Our position, as set out in our national policy, is that provided there is a reasonable TEAS and an indexed TEAS we will certainly look at loans. I believe it is a follow-on and that in that case we should talk about it as a supplement. At the moment we are talking about it and have to talk about it as an attempt to displace entirely the grants scheme. I am quite sure that the method used will be the method that was used in Sweden. The Government will not abolish TEAS allowances; it will simply fail to raise them, certainly in line with the consumer price index. Senator Teague who lauded the rises in the last Budget conveniently forgot the lack of rises in previous Budgets so we are still no further ahead.

I am also concerned that the literature about loans has raised some crucial points of educational concern which so far have not been discussed in this debate. I wish to raise some of those now. There is an indication from a Swedish study that was replicated in America with similar results-not indentical results -that loans encourage people to undertake courses which are short in duration and in which conceivably they believe that they have a higher than average chance of success. In other words, a certain amount of curriculum distortion is likely to take place with the imposition of a loans scheme in comparison to a grants scheme. This evidence is not conclusive but I believe that one needs to be careful when one is changing basic methods of funding in education. We need to know what will be the educational outcomes of those changes and we must seek to acquaint ourselves with what studies are available in relation to them. These judgments should not be made purely on economic grounds. They ought also to be made on educational grounds. I would be interested to hear the reply of the Minister for Education in relation to those studies which doubtless he has had brought to his attention.

I am concerned also, in the Australian context-in this respect, of course, we do not have any evidence simply because we have not had this situation occur before-with the vulnerability of the TAFE colleges in particular, because of the specific clientele that they have in the particular types of courses that they offer. It is well known, and I believe that the Government has not sought to disprove this or to suggest that it is not the case, the students from lower income families are certainly more discouraged to take on higher education when there is a loans scheme attached than they would otherwise be. The Government, I believe, has gone part way in this area, and it has endeavoured to seek at least a homogeneous group of students who may be available for loans. That is, by taking out only those students who are eligible for the assistance that is available at the moment, it has sought to suggest that this is a homogeneous group. Of course, it is nothing of the sort, for the particular reason that the criteria for those various grants differ quite considerably. Nevertheless, from all the studies that have been undertaken, the situation is evident that students who come from lower income families tend to be discouraged from going into debt and therefore would tend to be discouraged from undertaking courses to which there may be a debt attached. Because it seems that this Bill may very well pass the second reading stage, I have circulated an amendment which I believe would overcome the more deleterious effects of that situation. The amendment suggests a mode of repayment which would take away that fear from students who come from low income families.

There is also the fear of many people who undertake TAFE college courses with regard to employment opportunities. This fear has been showing up in recent studies undertaken across post-secondary institutions. As a whole, it indicates that students at TAFE colleges are more concerned about the possibility of employment than those from CAEs or universities. If that is the case, again those people would react negatively to a situation in which, after graduation in some particular course at a TAFE college, they find themselves unemployed. The Government, I believe, has sought in its Bill to meet this situation in terms of the two-year holiday from repayment. I believe that that goes some way to alleviating that concern. However, in the growing unemployment situation, I do not believe that that could possibly be a substitute for that very real fear of entering into an obligation of some considerable magnitude. I think that the possible magnitude of this obligation is interesting. Let us take the situation of a person taking out the $1,000 loan per year as suggested, even with the 5 per cent rebate that the Government is offering. By the way, the Government is only offering the rebate; it is not legislating for it; it is not in the Bill and I will be seeking to move an amendment to put it into the Bill. Presumably that is the Government's intention; so I suppose it will not mind having it in the Bill. At the end of the course that person would have a debt of $6,048 plus bank charges, the amount of which we are not sure about at the moment. I say, by way of an aside, that Senator Teague really got carried away when he suggested that the banks would look after absolutely any student who might wish to take out a loan. Banks have not been all that forthcoming in relation to housing, which was the subject of the Bill we discussed previously, and I cannot see them being terribly concerned about knocking back students, except possibly those following the profession that the Minister professed to follow before he came into this House. That profession is always regarded as a good risk and certainly I am sure that most banks would be happy to make loans available to those students. However, arts students-for example, history students-would find it very difficult even to become teachers nowadays. In a number of other faculties they would find it excessively dificult, I believe, to get a loan out of a bank.

TALK.START.PARA: —Lecturers in education.

—It may include lecturers in education, possibly, yes. If we consider a post-graduate student with a loan limit of $8,000 at the end of his studies he would have a debt of $14,744, plus bank charges. I do not know whether the Minister has had a look at the statistics but he might be interested to know that many tertiary students actually marry other tertiary students. I do not know whether he has thought about the consequences of that occurring. This would represent a combined debt of a staggering amount, presumably which again means, and I am sure Senator Harradine would be interested in this, a further attack on the family and the inability of that family to have children or to look forward to owning its own home, even without the problems mentioned by Senator Haines not so long ago.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that those types of considerations are pertinent when one is looking at the flow-on effects of the type of things that government undertakes. That is merely one example of the problems that may occur arising out of a debt and no employment, or a debt with employment but difficulty entering into any normal type of operation that one may want to enter into upon graduation. Of course, the whole nation is premised around the idea of the user paying. So I suppose really we are at a very basic level of loggerheads. The Australian Democrats hold very firmly to the notion that the country ought to invest in its tertiary education institutions, at this particular point of time, above all others. We believe that there are sufficient indications that unless we develop our human capital in this country, and I define human capital as the skills, the dexterity , the imagination, the knowledge, the insights of our citizens, as a country we do not have an economic future. I again remind the Senate that the Japanese Government, over eight years ago, made a deliberate policy decision to move very heavily into education funding. The reason for this decision was put down in its report on the development of Japan and the future of Japan to the year 2000. It was stated very clearly that Japan did not have the resources that many other countries had. It did not have basic minerals; it did not have a whole range of resources. But the Japanese knew that they had human resources, the knowledge, the intelligence, the understanding, the dexterity and the imagination of the citizens. We have those human resources also in Australia, to the same extent as Japan does. Yet in a resource rich country in terms of a whole range of other types of resources, we are saying we will rest on those other resources and neglect our human capital. The deliberate policies of Saudi Arabia are aimed at redirecting its funding away from the types of massive infrastructure development into education because it says that when the oil runs out it will need a basis for its future and its future will be in its people. That idea, that philosophy, would hold good at any time. But we believe it has particular relevance at this time in the 1980s.

One need only look at the growth areas in other economies. Where are the growth areas in the United States economy? They are in technology, bio-technology and computer industries. Where is growth taking place in Japan? It is taking place in the same industries. In Switzerland, West Germany and Sweden it is taking place in the same industries. But is such growth taking place in Australia? No. The extent of our involvement is conducting a conference and issuing a Press release from the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Thomson). We need to move heavily into this area and to invest up to the hilt in these types of industries. Therefore we have to invest in tertiary education. In the US economy there is a direct link between that element of growth, which after all is very small, and tertiary institutions. The United States believes that a dollar spent on education is a dollar well spent and better spent than anywhere else. That is the basic economic and philosophical notion that the Australian Democrats propound, and that is the basis for our objection to a loans scheme at this time .

We do not believe that we should be going around trying in some way to stop people taking up tertiary studies. Indeed, we are down by 12,000 tertiary students. We are not interested in running down our tertiary institutions and having fewer students in higher education. We are interested in spending more and more money and getting more and more students into those tertiary institutions. We wish to expand the number as rapidly as possible. We seek an expansion in particular vital areas. We believe that if these vital areas were injected into our economy both in terms of industrial development and the development of human capital to take up that advantage people would undertake those studies because they would see that on graduation there would be good prospects of employment. That is the type of general model into which we fit our objection to this scheme. We put forward the same reason in respect of our objection to fees. We object to all of the ad hockery that has gone on in place of a national education framework. That is the type of thing that we ought to be debating in this Senate but which we have not got around to yet.

We have had plenty of education debates in this place, but they have all been about this type of inane peripheral material. We are talking about $50m in this legislation when the economic future of this country is at stake. It is as serious as that. If education is not going to become a major element in the economic advance of this country then we really have blinkers on, we really are going backwards and we really cannot learn at all from these other economies which are picking themselves up and moving ahead. Education is the area we ought to be concerned about and it is the obligation which rests on the shoulders of the new Minister for Education. It is his responsibility to give his portfolio some life. The education portfolio has languished under his predecessors as though it was something that was needed because one has to have schools. I believe that many people in this country have placed their last hope in the new Minister for Education. They hope that he will give that type of leadership and display that type of foresight and will bring education back into focus, back into the centre of the arena and back where it should be discussed as the focal, crucial element in getting this country moving ahead. Why talk about $50m and the user pays principle and the other types of things raised by Senator Teague tonight? Such things pale into insignificance in terms of what education is about and the use to which it can be put if we really get down to the task. Let us have introduced some Bills which actually set out where we are going in that area. Let us stop the ad hockery and these inane debates about peripheral matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this debate to raise the matter of the scandalous state of student finance in general in Australia, to endorse substantially the remarks made by Senator Button and to a large extent to agree with the vehemence and the criticism made by Senator Macklin. The Australian Labor Party believes that the Government's very belated effort in this area of student financing indicates its inability to comprehend the need for the Parliament and the Government to have a proper input in investment for the future of our country. I found it rather distasteful to listen to the negative contribution made by the previous Government speaker, Senator Teague, who, in his rather pontificating way, struck a discordant note about the activities of a student association. He saw something sinister about people of a like mind coming together to form a common attitude in respect of education when he knows that that is the very way in which the Parliament itself operates. He sits as a mute in his party room and gets lectured to by his Ministers when the course of action that should be taken in the Parliament itself is being determined. I have not seen him in the years he has been here exercising any independence of attitude. He meekly follows in a slavish way whatever the party line might be in respect of the inadequate and completely inept policies being pursued by the Fraser Government.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government, of course, has shown no commitment to providing an adequate grant based student financing system for Australian students. It is no wonder that we on this side of the House are completely dissatisfied with this legislation. My party, when it is elected to office some time within the next year, will be seeking to recast this proposal and to repeal the legislation. We will establish a decent and equitable system of student financing so far as young people are concerned. I can remember in my early days that it was considered adequate for the average person to have a primary school education. Then it became essential to have a secondary school education. Of course, in today's world it is absolutely essential to have a tertiary education to meet the sorts of challenges that clearly are facing all of the industrialised countries. The national government has a responsibility to play its part in this respect. Of course, this Government has neglected to provide proper student financing. It has attempted to fill the gap with stop-gap legislation. It has not recognised the need to take the steps that ought to be taken if we understand the role of education in the future development of our nation.

Of course, it ought to be pointed out to the Government that on several occasions the Senate has had to reject attempts by this Government to introduce fees for second degree students and that, of course, indicated the philosophical position of the Government. Fortunately, the Senate in its wisdom refused to go along with that piece of legislation because it recognised the vital role that tertiary education has in the future of our country if we are to compete with international trends and the developments that are taking place in the whole area of technology, as has been referred to previously by my party's speakers and by speakers on behalf of the Australian Democrats.

The role of this Government is clear: It believes that education should remain something of a privilege for the well off. It is true that we have a fairly large middle class grouping in the Australian community, and the Government is prepared to take whatever steps are necessary to allow that grouping to be well represented in the tertiary education area. No real attempt is being made to provide the equality of opportunity which the Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, and other Government spokesmen suggest from time to time that the Liberal Party is about. There is certainly no equality of opportunity indicated in this legislation, which will perpetuate the class differentiation that is so obvious in our universities today. We get this picture-I stress that it is just a picture-of the Government's inability to understand the hardship faced by those who choose to undertake full time study under the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme. A survey conducted in 1979 under the auspices of the Department of Education showed, in the words of the report, that 'total expenditure exceeded total income in the majority of cases'.

My comments on the Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Bill revolve around two main points': First, the indecent lack of consideration with which the Government has brought in the loans scheme which this Bill proposes, and second, the need for a proper and wide-ranging look at student financing. The volume of representations and the numbers of letters from student bodies, academic organisations and university staff organisations over the last year or so indicate how much this Government is out of step, how much it is out of touch with the thinking that exists in these institutions. The Government, of course, has ignored all of those views and the feelings that have been expressed over the last year or two. It has presented this form of assistance to students as the answer to the expressions of concern and protest about the attitude taken by the Government.

The Government claims that student loans will help students to meet the gap between their expenditure and their currently meagre incomes. It refuses, however, to acknowledge the paucity of the grants it provides through the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme. As Senator Macklin has suggested, one would hope that the Minister for Education, Senator Peter Baume, who on occasions has certainly shown a little more understanding on these matters than some of his fellow Ministers, will argue, I hope successfully, for some improvements in these areas. The Government claims that because students will take out the loans provided by this scheme this indicates their acceptance. In fact, they have no alternative. The Government fails to see that students inevitably will find themselves forced to take out loans because of the complete and total inadequacy of TEAS. The Government refuses to acknowledge that a decent student financing system, one that offers access to post-secondary education for people from a broad range of socio-economic backgrounds, depends upon an adequate grants scheme. Student financing schemes that are based upon loans will create tremendous problems for the students. Of course, the Government does this because it fails to understand the valuable human resources which exist in this area. It fails to understand the technological challenge that is about us and the need to have an independent position in this country, arising out of a better education system, so that we can compete with the assistance that is so freely given in many other countries.

The loans scheme has been put forward by the Government but it convinces nobody in the university field that it is adequate. It is five years since the considerations of the Butcher Committee on Student Loans. It is accepted that that Committee recommended that a loans scheme be set up. However, its report was accompanied by a dissenting minority report, and it convinced very few in the education or finance fields that loans were a good idea. Of course, the Government, acting as it invariably does in an ad hoc way, accepted the majority report. Both of the factors that were associated with the minority report are still true today. The Government has had five years since the report was first put down in which to convince students, administrators, bankers and financiers that loans are a good idea. It has failed dismally to get an acceptance of that concept. Let us look at what some of these people-the ones who should know about how a loan scheme will affect post-secondary education-have to say. I refer specifically to David Caro, the Chairman of the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, who said:
All of us feel that the tertiary allowances scheme should be supported and we are worried that this may not be so as a consequence of the loans scheme.

He should know. He is involved in that area of education. The Chairman of the Australian Bankers Association has expressed doubts about the scheme. He wants the scheme to replace the TEAS allowance. He believes there will be substantial problems with this scheme if it is to be a supplement to the TEAS payments. Yet this is what the Government claims the proposed scheme should be. So we have some reluctance on behalf of the banking institutions, which after all are not even responding to the Government's requests to provide adequate funds for housing out of their invested funds. One cannot see any marked enthusiasm for their investment in this area. Here we have both confusion and dissatisfaction. In some respects there is even opposition to the scheme proposed in this Bill. I doubt whether that is any way to introduce a scheme that is supposed to help students. We can express considerable doubt, therefore, about whether this scheme will be satisfactory and will be accepted by students generally.

When one reads the views of the students one can see that there is a reluctance on their part to show any particular enthusiasm for the legislation that we are asked to approve tonight. The Opposition has taken the step of moving an amendment that the matter should go before the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts for inquiry and report by 16 November so that it can be examined in a little more detail. We do not believe the Government can justify rejecting that amendment when it has had five years in which to put into effect the recommendations of the Butcher inquiry. We suggest that the Parliament should exercise some jurisdiction in this matter. The Government has taken five years to convince itself of the correctness or otherwise of student loans. There is no evidence available that this is an acceptable scheme. I think it is proper that the Senate should exercise its right and have the matter considered by its own committee. It seems to the Australian Labor Party that the least it can do is to send this matter to its Senate Committee for further investigation. It is not only the question of confusion arising over student loans that warrants further study but the whole parlous state of student financing. This underlines and strengthens our view that a Senate inquiry into the legislation should be held.

I remind the Senate that in 1975, not long after the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme was introduced by the Whitlam Government-one cannot argue that it was not a progressive and a very desirable step to create that so-called freedom of choice which we hear echoed time and time again in this place by Liberal Party spokesmen-a committee of inquiry was set up under the chairmanship of Doctor H. S. Williams. That Committee recommended a number of things regarding allowance levels-indexation, means testing and the like-but none of them have been accepted or followed up by this Government. We have had years of inactivity. We know that Government speakers will say that the Opposition is attempting to delay consideration of the Bill by having it sent to the Senate Committee for examination. This inaction, this failure to give proper consideration to the Williams Committee report, is one of the reasons why student financing is in the mess it is today. I think it is proper that the Government should take into condsideration the view of the students organisation . I know we have been regaled from time to time with all sorts of wild and outlandish criticism of the Australian Union of Students, but whether we like it or not the fact is that that body represents the considered view of student organisations in Australia. If this Government believes at all in listening to the views of people who represent the organisation of students, their views ought to be taken into consideration.

The Williams Committee also recommended that regular reviews of student financing take place. Since that recommendation was made in 1975 not one proper review has occurred. So the Government stands indicted for years of inactivity. Of course we have seen how it was inactive not only in this area but also in the areas of tax evasion. It was pointed out before Senate Estimates Committee C, which met on Monday night, that on 14 different occasions the Commissioner of Taxation pointed out to the Treasurer (Mr Howard) the wholesale evasion of tax that was taking place. It is pretty clear now, from the way that the debate on tax evasion has developed, that there was no conviction in the Government's own ranks, in the Cabinet. Whilst the Government set up interdepartmental committees to look at Mr O'Reilly's recommendations for legislation to tighten up tax evasion, there was no will on the part of the Cabinet to do so. There was no determination to take advantage of the advice from the Commissioner of Taxation to avoid the sort of mess that the Government is now in in respect of taxation. That is just another indication of the indecision of this Government. It cannot agree on how to handle tax evasion; it cannot agree on student financing; and it cannot agree on the time of day. It is a government that is divided. It is a government that does not know where it is going. It is a government that ought to be thrown out of office at the first opportunity.

I come back to the legislation. There has been only one survey of any kind taken by a government instrumentality, and that was the 1979 Department of Education survey that I referred to earlier. What did that survey show? It was recognised by all who took part in it as being limited and partial. It worked with inadequate funds, inadequate resources and inadequate facilities. It was rushed in its consideration. It was merely a survey and it could not make any recommendations. The fact that the survey does provide us with useful information is a tribute to the organisations that assisted it, but in no way is it a proper review of student financing.

I believe the proper function and role of the Senate is to review legislation. We have a government that is not able properly to carry out its role of governing for all of the people. That is the sort of government we have today. It cannot understand its role of intervention in society in order to create equality of opportunity. In this area the Government, as in so many other areas, has lurched from year to year with ad hoc and unplanned policies generally. In this case it has unplanned student financing policies. It is in the parlous state it is today because it has not got a clear and coherent position. I am talking generally. This year it has given some extra handouts in the way of allowances and proposed schemes, but that is all part of the stop-gap, ad hockery and confusion that is symptomatic of the Fraser Government. The Opposition's proposal is pretty simple. It is this: Before we go ahead and sow more confusion and create more hardship, let us stop and consider what we are doing. It is, of course, therefore essential that the Senate exercise its proper role, the review of legislation, and send this Bill to its Committee for consideration.

The Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme has been with us since 1974. Today no one believes that it is an adequate scheme, but also no one is convinced that this Bill provides a proper alternative or supplement to the way in which the original scheme operated. We should therefore now consider the whole range of student financing properly and logically. This legislation fails to do that. The committee of inquiry suggested by the Opposition is a good place to start. We reiterate that education is a right and a necessity. Education is an investment in Australia's future. It ought to be considered as one of the most important investments for the future survival of our country because we are involved in a more competitive way than we have ever been. In view of this the Government must surely review its attitude to education and place it in a proper perspective. We should be in a position to provide that equality of opportunity which we believe is the right of all of those who want to have a tertiary education.

I compliment the Australian Union of Students on its representative capacity in this matter. I compliment it on its diligence and its submission. I believe it was a genuine attempt to place before the Parliament and the Government the genuine views of the students in our universities. I believe that the best way we can pay tribute to that submission is to adopt the amendment moved by Senator Button.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be worth pointing out to anyone who is taking any interest in this debate that the purpose of the Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Bill 1982 is to provide for a subsidy on interest charged by banks on approved loans for the students and for the Commonwealth to give guarantees to banks that it will repay outstanding debts. I thought it might be worth stating at the beginning because the debate, so far as the Opposition speakers have been concerned tonight, has ranged over just about everything else. For some reason honourable senators from the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats have been reluctant to address themselves properly to what the Bill really is about.

SPEECH.PARA: To Senator Gietzelt I can only suggest that the next time he gets someone to write his speech for him he gets someone with a higher level of education. The speech he just read to us in the Senate had precious little to do with this Bill , if anything. It could have been a speech on anything at all. In fact it reminded me of those cards one can buy where one crosses out certain words and leaves an appropriate word to go in the gap that is left in something that purports to be a message on something or other. That is about all that Senator Gietzelt's speech was. It was, of course, an exercise in propaganda. It was, as Senator Button clearly said in relation to his own speech, an exercise in relation to an election campaign, but did not claim to address itself to the Bill. This much I will say for the Democrat and Labor contribution to the debate : The representatives of both parties have been consistent. The Democrats have been consistent in their intellectual confusion in approaching Government Bills on education. The Labor Party has been consistent in its intellectual dishonesty in presenting its case in opposition to Government Bills. In the last 18 months the Senate has had before it a number of education Bills in which that has been the hallmark of the contribution by Opposition senators.

Typically, the Democrats have raised substantial objections to the Bill, based not on what it contains but on what might be in some subsequent Bill. I recall two debates in the Senate when a proposal that fees be introduced at the tertiary level for a very limited number of students was opposed by the Democrats on the grounds that it could mean that, at some time in the future, the Government would charge all tertiary students fees. It was said: 'Never mind what is in the Bill. Let us vote against a Bill that does not yet exist, if in fact it will ever exist'.

Tonight Senator Macklin followed this typical line. He said that in other countries the purpose of introducing a loans scheme had been to replace other student support schemes. The Government, through the Minister for Education ( Senator Peter Baume) and through its announcements, has made very clear from the beginning in regard to its policies on the loans scheme, on the implementation of student support schemes, and on this particular loans scheme for tertiary students, that the loans are meant to supplement other student support schemes.

I remind the Senate that the 1982 Budget effected substantial increases in student support. Grants under the Commonwealth Post-graduate Award Scheme have gone up by 48 per cent. The Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme level has gone up by 20 per cent. At no stage have Labor or Democrat senators addressed themselves to those facts. The loans scheme gives to students of limited other means access to additional finance if they choose to seek it. If, on top of the increases in student allowances, they want additional finance, this represents one of a number of possibilities available to them. I reiterate, this Bill provides for the subsidisation of the interest rate charged by banks. That is a feature of the loans scheme that again Democrat and Labor senators have ignored.

The second aspect is the guarantee to banks that the Government will repay outstanding debts on approved loans within prescribed limits. That is fundamental to the banks being involved, fundamental to the success of the scheme. In that form, given that the tertiary allowances, both under TEAS and the Commonwealth Post-graduate Awards Scheme, have been substantially increased, by 20 per cent and 48 per cent respectively, the loans scheme does what the Government said over 12 months ago it would do. It gives students of limited means access to cheap finance. It also gives them a choice. We have heard from a number of Opposition senators the implication that somehow or other this is designed to inhibit, to put down, tertiary education. Indeed, Senator Macklin said that the policy of the Government was to try to stop people from taking up tertiary studies. Given the framework of this Bill, that is a little difficult to follow. With all due respect to Senator Macklin, who is a very worthy student , he was himself a little difficult to follow tonight. He ranged far and wide. He began by saying that because of what had happened in other countries the Democrats would vote against the Bill. It was not a question of what the Bill did or of what the Government had been saying consistently since 1981 as to the purpose of the loans scheme. Nor was it a matter of what this Bill, combined with other policy decisions of the Government as announced in the Budget, proved was the policy on the funding of tertiary education. Apparently none of those things was felt to be important. It was rather a matter of what had happened under other governments in other countries.

I reiterate that in that respect at least the Democrats have been consistent. That has been the basis of their objection to other government legislation but it really does not wash. The Democrats have to provide a better reason than that . They certainly have to do a little better than having Senator Macklin come here tonight whipping himself into a lather over how worthy is tertiary education. Judging by the outraged indignation in the tone of his voice, one must assume that he thought he was criticising the Fraser Government's policy on education. Of course, what he said actually had no relevance to this Government' s policies.

I do not intend to repeat all that Senator Macklin said. I will assert that that is a fair statement of what he said and will merely pick up some of the points that he made. Time does not permit me to cover all of them. Indeed, it would be straining the patience of the Senate to expose it to the same drivel twice. The honourable senator made a very worthy statement but one that was nevertheless strange. He said: 'Education is an investment, not a cost.' I think it was a slip of the tongue. On the basis of what followed it would have been more appropriate had he said: 'Education is an investment, not a waste.' Even an investment represents a cost. Investing in something costs something. We agree that education is an investment, not a waste. We also agree that it costs money, so we have no dispute with Senator Macklin on his statement in that regard.

It has always been the policy of the Liberal Party and of the Fraser Government that a substantial investment in education should be made at all levels. It was the Liberal Government of Sir Robert Menzies that initiated the policies which led to the great expansion of universities and colleges of advanced education in this country, making tertiary education truly accessible to more than just the very wealthy. I will admit that in saying that I am going back some way. I do so just to show that Liberal governments have been consistent in placing a very high priority on education and, specific to this debate, on tertiary education. I really expected Senator Macklin to bring up motherhood by the end of his speech, but perhaps he was a little too distressed. He observed that tertiary institutions are for the benefit of the country. I am pleased to announce that the Fraser Government agrees with that assertion. In fact it has consistently acted in that light. It did not always find it necessary to say so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very good for the people.

—Yes, very good for the people-probably very good for the citizens of the country was what he meant. That is certainly what we think. There is no dispute about that. The dispute is as to the conclusion reached by the honourable senator, after the making of many worthy statements, that the Government is trying to stop people from taking up tertiary studies. Why on earth would the Fraser Government be doing that? Senator Macklin should look at the experience of other countries where presumably governments have set out to stop people from taking up tertiary studies. He could draw upon their reasons to state what were the reasons of the Fraser Government. It would represent the same kind of twaddle and would be no more germane to the argument; it would be absolutely irrelevant.

SPEECH.PARA: The Fraser Government devotes enormous resources to tertiary studies and other levels of education. As I said in the beginning, the Democrats are consistent in their approach to this legislation. They do not like talking about it so they raise a different objection. Indeed, Senator Macklin said towards the end of his speech, by way of a summary of the Democrats' view of the Bill, that they had the same objection to it as they had to the Bill on fees. It was also fairly typical of Senator Macklin's approach that he did not specify what fees. During the debate on the earlier Bill he referred to fees generally, not fees for what- fees for students who already had academic qualifications or for a certain limited category of post-graduate students. Rather the Democrats raised the bogy of the imposition of fees generally, as something that might occur under some government at some time in the future. There was nothing on which to base that argument. The Bill did something else. The same objection was raised tonight. It was typical in that it was not worth trying to sell to the Australian people. I am sure that there are many students, as well as parents, guardians and supporters of students, who are aware that, through the Budget and this legislation, the Fraser Government is proposing that in addition to the granting of substantial increases in tertiary allowances for students, money will be made available cheaply to students, with preference being given to those most in need , in order to provide a source of financial support additional to what is available now.

On the other hand, the Labor Party, in its basic argument which was really stated by Senator Button and was briefly alluded to in about the last two or three pages of Senator Gietzelt's speech, has said that this Bill should be sent to a Senate committee. It is a strange reference-strange in a number of ways. It is not strange that a Bill should be sent off to a Senate committee but strange in the manner of sending it off. As I said, this has been Government policy since April 1981. Senator Button has taken an active interest in education in his time in the Senate. For a substantial length of time he was a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, the Committee to which he now seeks to send this Bill.

Senator Button's interest in education did not arise since the introduction of this Bill into the Senate in September this year. He had a fairly lively interest in it back in April last year when the Government announced its loans scheme policy and, indeed, prior to that. However, it did not occur to Senator Button, either before or since April 1981, to suggest that the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts might look at the value of a loans scheme to tertiary students. As a concept, it is not new. As has been pointed out by other Opposition senators, other countries have introduced it. It has been a matter of debate in education journals and elsewhere for years in this country-a debate to which Senator Button would not have been oblivious. But tonight he thinks it would be a good idea that the Committee look at the subject. It is a belated interest in those terms. He has known that the Government was going to legislate on the matter and he made no move. If he ever thought that the Government might legislate on it before the Government announced that intention, he made no move.

But now in October 1982 he makes the move and gives the Committee five weeks in which to carry out its investigation and present its report. All of us who have been members of Senate standing committees know how long an investigation, whether it is a general reference or a reference on a Bill, takes. A proper investigation takes months. If all the people who have an interest in it, including the Australian Union of Students, make a submission, give evidence and bring their learned opinion to bear, it cannot be done in a little more than five weeks. Five weeks will only give an opportunity for senators of a declared political view to express their view through another forum. They can do it here in the Senate tonight. They can declare themselves on the principle. Senator Button, with all his experience in education and on Senate standing committees, gives the Committee five weeks to investigate a Bill and report to the Senate. That is bad enough. But in the second section of the reference Senator Button directs the Committee on what are to be its priorities in considering this Bill. The motion states:

(b) the Committee take into account (i) the CTEC reference to the declining participation rate in tertiary education and the contribution which the inadequacy of TEAS makes to this alarming development . . .

That struck me as a little strange. I was not aware that there was a Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission report that drew any such conclusion that the declining participation rate in tertiary education was in any way attributable to the inadequacy of TEAS. I was not aware that there was a report of CTEC on that subject. When I read the motion a little closer, I realised that it did not say that. It states that there is a CTEC reference to the declining participation rate in tertiary education. In the same sentence and without any special punctuation it is stated:
and the contribution which the inadequacy of TEAS makes to this alarming development.

That second allegation, that TEAS has something to do with participation rates, comes from Senator Button, not from CTEC. I am reliably informed that the report on this reference on the subject of participation rates in tertiary education which does not prejudge the reasons which could be many and varied is not expected before December. But on 16 November, Senator Button wants to have a report which takes these things into account. By then we will not know the finding of CTEC.
The second part of the amendment states:
the finding of the study on tertiary student finances that the proportion of tertiary students of less privileged backgrounds is declining;

I am not saying that there is not a study that states that the proportion of tertiary students of less privileged backgrounds is declining. I am just wondering which study it is. Is it a study by the Australian Labor Party? Is it a study by the Australian Union of Students? What study is it? Whatever it is, it is quite improper that a Senate standing committee, being asked to look at a Bill, should be told the two things that should be of primary account. Senator Button's motion relating to the Senate Standing Committee goes on to state that it wants the Committee to report on the proposed agreement between the Government and certain banks. I suppose that is something it could investigate and report on. According to Senator Button, the second thing that it ought to report on is the need to provide for regular and automatic adjustments to TEAS to prevent the proposed loans scheme replacing TEAS as the basic form of student assistance. There is nothing in this Bill that leads to the loans scheme replacing TEAS as the basic form of student assistance. I repeat-the Government has repeated this also-that the loans scheme will not replace TEAS as the basic form of assistance. The Government has increased TEAS by 20 per cent. The loans are a supplement to TEAS.

Some reference was made by Senator Gietzelt to Whitlam Government policies on education. If regular and automatic adjustments-one takes it that means some form of indexation of TEAS-are a good idea, and indexation is not a new idea; it has been around a long time, it would have been a very appropriate time for the Labor Government to carry out that policy in 1975 when the inflation rate of Australia was 16 per cent plus. The Labor Government was in charge of TEAS then, having introduced it in 1974. It decided not to index it. That is not an argument against indexation but if that is the Labor Party's policy-it was not its policy when it was in charge of TEAS-it is not for the Labor Party to direct a Senate committee in the context of examining a Bill that gives loan guarantees in relation to banks what ought to be in the Bill on another subject.

TEAS is provided for elsewhere. It does not need to be provided for in the Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Bill. It is quite inappropriate for an Opposition senator or any senator to suggest that legislation, when sent to a Senate standing committee for investigation and report, should seek to make recommendations which could so change that legislation. Firstly, there is the possibility-not a certainty but a possibility-that in principle some aspect of Government policy might be changed to Opposition policy. Secondly, there is the possibility of introducing into the Bill an element which does not belong in this Bill but belongs elsewhere. I shall give Senator Button credit where credit is due. He made the statement that this is the Labor Party's policy for the next election campaign and, therefore, he did at least make it clear that the purpose of his contribution was somehow or other directed to the next election campaign. I prefer that.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have got wax in your ears, senator. I did not say anything of the sort. I said that we would repeal this Bill.

—That was the message that came through. I was referring to Senator Button's statement of Labor Party policy and how he would like to put what he claimed to be Labor Party policy into other legislation which is not Labor legislation but which is the present Government's legislation. At least Senator Button was clearer on that than was Senator Gietzelt. Senator Gietzelt ought to be a little more careful in education debates that he does his own homework more thoroughly. The rhetoric was there; the substance was not. When Senator Gietzelt was measuring so strong on Australian Labor Party and Whitlam policies on tertiary education, he completely ignored a point that honourable senators on this side tried to draw to his attention at that time. We would have been interested in his comment, in the context of what he was saying, on the subject of the Whitlam Government policies on tertiary funding in 1975, when it abolished triennial funding for universities and went on to annual funding. The Hayden Budget of 1975 threw university and tertiary funding into chaos.

SPEECH.PARA: Those in the Labor Party in 1975 who knew about education and its needs knew that that would be the effect. That would have been a good time for Senator Gietzelt to have shown his interest in tertiary education. I would like him to remember that because if he has any hand in Labor Party policies, alternative policies, in regard to how tertiary education should be funded then he ought to have full knowledge of the mess Labor made of tertiary funding in 1975. Senator Gietzelt told us that this Bill would perpetuate class differentiation. He was talking about middle class preferences. I reiterate that the Bill is for the benefit of those on lower incomes, who come from lower income families, who have to qualify under means tests which presently apply in the tertiary sector. It is a reinforcement for those on lower incomes, not that class to which Senator Gietzelt referred which has some privilege, according to him, in terms of money and access to money. The essence of all that is that Senator Gietzelt's speech was rhetoric and not substance.

In conclusion, I pay tribute to the Minister for Education, Senator Peter Baume , for his education policies. Senator Gietzelt made slighting reference to Senator Baume. He damned him with faint praise. He said he believed him to be a good Minister and that it is unfortunate that the Minister is in the position he is in. Senator Baume is indeed a good Minister for Education, as witnessed by this Bill and other policies announced in the context of the Budget that he has achieved for education in Australia. He has shown that he is a Minister who has fundamentally sound motivation in the field of education and specifically in the context of this debate in the tertiary education sector. I, along with others on the Governmnent side and outside this Parliament, welcomed and congratulated him for that 48 per cent increase in the Commonwealth Post-graduate Awards Scheme, an area in which there was clear need for an increase. I and others congratulated him and congratulate him now on the 20 per cent increase in the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme and in the reinforcing of the basic thrust of Government policy as exemplified in this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is discussing the Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Bill 1982. It ought to be said at the outset that the Australian Labor Party is not utterly opposed in every circumstance to students in tertiary education institutions being assisted by way of loans of a particular type or administered by particular authorities. But we are adamantly opposed to the Tertiary Student Loans Scheme. We are not at all pacified by Senator Martin and other Government spokesmen reiterating time and again that the loans scheme is meant to be supplementary to and is not intended to replace the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme as the better mechanism for providing financial assistance to those Australian students who require that assistance in order to undertake those essential tertiary studies-essential for their own development, for the growth of the wealth of this country and indeed for the bettering of society as a whole. As I have said, we are assured time and again that this loans scheme is supplementary to the funds that will be provided by this Government through TEAS and other schemes of assistance. But when one notes the key commitment of government moneys outlined in clause 5 of the Bill, one finds a very strange clause indeed. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Guarantees in respect of loans made in any year shall not guarantee the repayment of principle moneys exceeding in the aggregate $50,000,000, or such greater amount as is prescribed in respect of that year.

In other words, whereas at the moment the Government by that clause is committing itself to the payment of some $2m-being the 5 per cent interest subsidy on the $50m principal moneys there mentioned, as a maximum-the Government can at any time by regulation increase the amount of principal moneys in respect of which it can give an interest subsidy. So if this Government decides that rather than increase TEAS in accordance with the cost of living adjustments, by which it ought to be increased, it will make available somehow to Australian students $250m by way of assistance, then all the Government has to do is commit itself to repayment of 5 per cent by way of interest subsidy of $250m-that is, raise its commitment under this Bill, by regulation and not by coming to the Parliament, to an amount of $10m. That $250m will be available from the banking system by Government edict for these student loans.

In other words, there within the key committal of Government moneys to this scheme lie the seeds of the replacement of TEAS and other forms of assistance to students. It will be done not by coming back to this Parliament, by way of a Bill seeking extra funds, but by way of regulation. Hence we are not at all pacified by the constant reiteration of the claim that this scheme is not meant to replace TEAS. That is why the Labor Party is opposed in principle to this scheme of loans but finds itself, in the absence of a better TEAS scheme, compelled perhaps by the end of the day to support this Scheme at least for the 1983 academic year. Then, when we are in government, whilst retaining all the commitments made under this Bill we will not continue this particular method of providing finance to students.

As I say, loans schemes can operate on behalf of students in tertiary institutions in quite reasonable ways. In fact, many campuses and colleges of advanced education do operate such schemes. For example, at the University of Tasmania-my own university-the university administered schemes into which Kim Beazley put sums of money, beginning in 1973, are well administered and well regarded by the students and by the institutions of learning in which they operate. They are administered by people who by their close proximity to students and knowledge of the lifestyle of students, know correctly and definitely what difficulties a student might be facing in coping with a rental problem or the general maintenance of a reasonable lifestyle while undertaking studies. In fact, I have information from Mr Andrew Wilson, the current President of the Students Representative Council at the University of Tasmania, that the loans scheme operating at that University provides loans to students generally up to about $500. The loans are interest free for the first six months , 3 per cent is paid for the duration of studies and then normal rates of interest apply once the course has been completed.

That sort of system operating within the institution itself has proved extremely effective in ameliorating some difficulties which students face in the course of their studies. Students, understanding the nature of the lending authority, give an undertaking to repay according to the terms of the loan. I do not know of many, if any, cases of bad debt in this situation but the very structure of this Bill indicates that the Government expects that there will be bad debts. The banking system has obviously insisted that the Government guarantee the loans scheme being put forward by the Government tonight. In other words, the Labor Party would like to see further funds put into university or college of advanced education administered schemes as an aspect of that student counselling, that student assistance, which any education institution which takes a comprehensive interest in its students' wellbeing ought to attempt to undertake.

So, our real objection is that there lies in the Bill the very kernel of destruction of the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme as the preferred system of providing assistance. We also have extreme misgivings about the banking system's role in relation to students making application. Clause 3 says that an approved loan 'means a loan made . . . for the purpose of contributing to the maintenance and educational expenses of the student'. Whilst the people concerned with counselling services, welfare services and loan services administered within the university or college of advanced education, people who are close to students and to their lecturers and to the whole system of learning going on at that place, may well understand and be able to check and verify that the loan is for the purpose of contributing to the maintenance and educational expenses of a student, I doubt very much whether the ordinary bank manager or lesser person within his bank establishment will be able to verify that in fact the loan will be used for that purpose. So long as the student approaching the bank fulfils the criteria set out in clause 3 (2), I think that the bank would be required to make the moneys available without, as I say, verifying that the moneys are really needed for the maintenance and educational expenses of the student.

However, our major objection to the banking system being used for the purpose of making loans available to students is that whilst indeed there is a Government guarantee, Government spokesmen have indicated that banks will be expected to pursue the student for repayments of the principal and interest due by every means at the banks' disposal, including, obviously, tracing the student if the student should move-interstate, perhaps, or even overseas-and taking such judicial remedies, court remedies, as may be available. In other words, the guarantee comes in as an absolute last resort as far as the Government is concerned. The banks will be required to make a proper assessment as to whether the student is likely to be able to repay the loan. In making that assessment, surely the bank would have to take into account such factors as the possibility of the student not only successfully completing the studies but also moving fairly rapidly into a sphere of employment which will enable repayment to be made within the stated contractual period.

There are many students emerging from various faculties, other than, say, medicine or engineering, in respect of whom it will be very difficult indeed for a bank to say that a particular person, at the end of his studies, will emerge into a situation of full employment and will thereby be able to undertake repayment of loans. In other words, the banks are still required to make their own judgment, bankers' judgments.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, they are not.

—Senator Teague says no. He is saying that the banks will just open their doors and rely absolutely on the Government guarantee, which I find an incredible proposition. That is not in harmony with the statement of the Minister in the second reading speech, where it is stated, that the banks have to pursue all remedies open to them before the Government guarantee comes into effect.
—That is different.

—The banks have to make their own assessment. As Senator Macklin probably pointed out in his speech, student teachers in particular will find it extremely difficult in the next few years to persuade any banker that they are likely to move into employment of a full time character for some time after their graduation. In my home State of Tasmania it has recently been announced by the Liberal Government, led by Mr Gray, that the holders of teacher studentships who were guaranteed positions in the Government's teaching service will not now be able to fill those positions in 1983. In fact they have been encouraged to go to the Northern Territory and then perhaps to return to Tasmania after they have had some experience in the Norther Territory. Of course that has increased the sense of uncertainty in relation to employment and, therefore, the ability to repay loans of that body of students. I believe that experience will be multiplied in many other instances as we live in an economy which does not provide the employment opportunities which ought to be available.

SPEECH.PARA: The banks have been asked by the Government to take on this role. The reason why they have been asked to take on this role is that the university councils right around Australia have refused to be involved. My colleague, Senator Colston recalled, as I recall, the University of Adelaide Council which stated, I think in Feburary or March of 1981, that it would not co-operate in administering a loan scheme of the type proposed by the Government, on the grounds that it would deter disadvantaged students and diminish equality of opportunity. That was the statement of the University of Adelaide Council-not a body of academics, not the professorial board but a council-

TALK.START.PARA: —Was it asked? I mean: 'Nobody asked me, sir', she said.

—It was asked by the razor gang which the Minister for Education has conveniently forgotten. The razor gang said that the loan scheme would be administered by the education institutions, the universities and the colleges of advanced education. The University of Adelaide Council responded to that part of the report of the razor gang which I recall very well indeed. That was the report of a body composed, as I have said, not only of academics but also of people from the general community. They could see the way in which this loan scheme would operate to the disadvantage of Australian students.

SPEECH.PARA: Another reason for grave misgivings concerning this Bill is that when one reads what an approved loan means it is defined as:
. . . a loan made-
Amongst other things-
for the purpose of contributing to the maintenance and educational expenses of the student . . .

One wonders what is embraced in the term 'educational expenses'. One can legitimately raise in this chamber the question whether fees come within the definition of educational expenses and whether indeed we are faced with what has been a steady progression in the legislation brought before this chamber by this Government over the last three or four years since I have been a member of parliament whereby it has placed a requirement on students to pay fees in our tertiary education institutions. First it was the overseas students. Then it was post-graduate students. All this was done, of course, without a mandate from the electorate; it was never mentioned in election campaigns.

One can legitimately ask whether an 'approved loan' has been defined in a way which now permits the Government to introduce a contribution-a partial contribution admittedly-on the form of some sort of fee to be paid by first degree students within our tertiary education institutions. The loan, of course, as defined would be available to cover that fee requirement. In other words, there is a very grave fear in the education community that this legislation is preparing the way as a prelude to the setting up of machinery to enable the banking system to provide the money by executive fiat, as I have outlined, in order to enable students then to borrow money in order to pay their fees. In fact it is interesting to note that the maximum amount which it is said that a student can borrow in any one year is $1,000 which would be about the amount that would be expected to be paid in any system of fees introduced for first degree students within our universities or colleges of advanced education. So, one can see reasons why not only the student bodies themselves but also the councils of the universities and colleges of advanced education have opposed the concept of a loan scheme.

There is no doubt that the improvement of the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme remains the single, most effective way of removing the barriers which contribute to frustrate access to tertiary education by those on low and middle incomes or families with low and middle incomes. Particularly is this the case where the young adult needs to travel away from home to a centre of tertiary education. I have had very explicit experience of that on the north-west coast of Tasmania where students seeking further tertiary studies have to go either to Hobart or Launceston in order to pursue those studies. Their families find it extremely difficult to support them away from their homes. I recall bringing to the notice of the Senate last year the fact that participation rates by north- west and west coast students in Tasmanian tertiary education institutions were way below those of students from comparable suburbs and comparable income brackets in Hobart and Launceston. Parents are finding it extremely difficult to support them in the three or four years they are away from home, especially whilst their siblings are still at home or perhaps undertaking secondary education and all the expenses that are associated with it.

As Senator Macklin quite rightly pointed out, the money that might be invested by the community in further support for and expansion of TEAS is repaid as the students who benefit from those tertiary studies eventually move into employment . By earning money appropriate to their qualifications and by paying tax on a progressive tax scale they put money back into revenue year after year. If there is a fair, equitable and progressive taxation system the moneys which ought to be paid in support of students in tertiary education do come back to the community. Of course it not only comes back from those who are immediately conerned; those who have, by achieving tertiary qualifications, been able to move into the higher income bracket. As Senator Macklin also quite rightly pointed out, there is a correlation generally between the numbers of those participating successfully in such tertiary education and the general wealth produced in the community. It is that general increase in the gross wealth of Australia, and indeed in the social well-being of Australia which is brought about by greater participation in tertiary education, that will once again generate the moneys which are needed to support those undertaking such studies. There is no doubt that the future of Australian society lies in developing a highly educated people. We need skilled minds to create wealth from high technology applied to our national resourcees and also to enable those who are not in paid employment to fulfil themselves as human beings with a capacity to creatively use their time.

Whilst not wishing to prolong the debate I think it is essential to reply to some of the charges which were made by Senator Martin against my colleague Senator Button. She claimed that not only in the course of his remarks but also in the wording of the amendment which he moved on behalf of the Labor Party he failed to substantiate, by footnote on the amendment, the source of the remarks involved. I have in my hand now 'Studies of Tertiary Student Finances Volume 3' which was undertaken by Gruen, McMaster and Webb. It is a validation study of the costs of full time tertiary students. On page 15 of Volume 3, in most explicit terms, this is stated:

The predominant reason why students are not on any assistance scheme is that their parents' incomes are too high (i.e., 78 per cent of TEAS non-recipients' reasons according to the 1979 survey). In our view, this suggests that the shift in the full-time student population towards financing by parents-or by themselves-has led to a relative decrease in full-time university and CAE students from less privileged backgrounds.

In other words it is the conclusion of that report that there has been a relative decrease in full time university and CAE students, if they come from less privileged backgrounds, participating in those studies. It suggests that the reasons for that is the inadequacies of TEAS as revealed by the analysis in the report. One finds an absolute validation in that report for the amendment moved by Senator Button insofar as it speaks of the declining participation rate in tertiary education and the contribution which the inadequacy of TEAS makes to this alarming development. I think it ought to be put on record that nothing in the proposals put forward by the Labor Party, and on its behalf by Senator Button, cannot be substantiated, but they do need and would benefit from a fuller analysis within a Senate committee. It is for that reason that I support the amendment.
Debate (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Chaney) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

I would have liked to read this rather long second reading speech detailing the advances in social security but, in light of the late hour and the fact that we are near the time for the adjournment of the Senate, I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1982 is an omnibus Bill, gathering together those social security and welfare initiatives of the 1982-83 Budget that require legislation.

Part VI of the Bill contains the major initiatives it deals with in the form of amendments to the Social Security Act 1947. Part II amends the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954, and Part V the Delivered Meals Subsidy Act 1970.

The Bill also deals, in Parts III and IV, with consequential amendments to the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971 and the Defence (Re- establishment) Act 1965, and makes minor amendments to the Social Services Amendment Act 1979 (in Part VII) and Social Services Amendment Act 1981 (in Part V111). There are further minor amendments to the main Acts in the other parts of the Bill. Since these minor amendments have no policy significance and do not involve expenditure, I do not propose to discuss them in detail.

The major initiatives embodied in this Bill consolidate and extend the steps taken by the Government in last year's Budget to direct available increases in welfare expenditure to those in the greatest need.

In 1981-82 we identified three groups as being in need of particular help. These were families with three or more children, pensioners who pay private rents, and those single unemployment beneficiaries over 18 whose benefits are not automatically indexed.

Our assistance to them, through increased rates of family allowance for third and subsequent children, increased supplementary assistance and an increased single rate of unemployment benefit, represented, in our view, the best use of the increases in expenditure we were able to make at that time over and above the increases to which we were committed by the regular twice-yearly CPI-linked increases in most standard pension and benefit rates.

In the 1982-83 Budget we have again introduced measures that will assist all three of these groups, as well as taking further steps to alleviate some of the pressure points in the system-particularly those that result from inflation. We have also enhanced the incentives for recipients of social security payments to improve their own positions, and so become less dependent on the government.

This year's Budget provides for an increase in social security and welfare expenditure by my department from the $9997 million in 1981-82 to $11,471 million. After allowing for the additional payday last year this is an effective increase of 18 per cent. This is a somewhat larger increase than we have seen in this area in recent years.

A large part of the 1982-83 increase-some 75 per cent-is accounted for by the guaranteed indexation provisions I have already mentioned, increases in the estimated number of pensioners and beneficiaries my department will assist during the coming year, and other cost increases that are unavoidably built into the system.
This Bill embodies most of the major initiatives, apart from some increases in overall funds available for certain subsidy programs, that account for the remainder of this year's increase.
I now turn to explaining the main initiatives contained in the Bill. I have had circulated, a detailed explanatory memorandum for the information of honourable senators.
Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954
Clause 6 of this Bill amends the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954 to increase the rate of personal care subsidy for frail aged people.

This subsidy helps organisations providing accommodation for elderly people to meet the cost of employing staff to provide additional services for frail aged residents, such as assistance with bathing or dressing, room cleaning, personal laundry, supervision of medicine, or for a staff member to be available at all times.
At the end of June 1982 a total of 780 hostels were receiving the subsidy, helping to meet the cost of additional services for approximately 21,700 frail aged residents.
This Bill increases the subsidy from $80 to $120 for each eligible person for a four-week period (or from $20 to $30 a week) with effect from 6 July 1982.

This rise represents an increase of 100 per cent in the subsidy since October 1980, when the rate was last increased (from $15 to $20 a week), and will help to ensure that a high standard of care continues to be provided for our frail aged citizens.
The estimated expenditure on this subsidy for 1982-83 is $35 million-an increase of 57 per cent over last year's outlay.
Delivered Meals Subsidy Act
The subsidy for meals-on-wheels services is increased by an amendment to the Delivered Meals Subsidy Act 1970.

Clause 22 of the Bill will increase the subsidy available from October 1982 from 45 to 55 cents for a meal where a Vitamin C supplement (in the form of fresh fruit or fruit juice) is provided, and from 40 to 50 cents for other meals . This is an increase of 22 and 25 per cent respectively.

At the end of June 1982, 738 organisations were receiving a Commonwealth subsidy for the provision of meals-on-wheels and some 9,650,000 meals were delivered in 1981-82. This compares with 8,947,000 meals delivered in 1980-81.

Since the Commonwealth began providing subsidies for meals-on-wheels in 1970 it has spent nearly $23 million on this important from of help for elderly people at home, and our increased assistance this year demonstrates the value we place on the effective operation of meals-on-wheels services.
Social Security Act 1947
The other main Budget initiatives requiring legislation all involve amendments to the Social Security Act 1947 and are dealt with by Part VI of this Bill.

These amendments make a number of important adjustments to the system of social security pensions and benefits, and family allowances. They also introduce several significant new initiatives in the social security field.
I propose to deal with these measures as they affect the major client groups of my Department, rather than following the strict sequence of clauses in this part of the Bill.
Initiatives for the Unemployed
The single rate of unemployment benefit for people aged 18 years and over who have no dependants will be increased by $6.30 a week, bringing that rate to $64. 40 a week (Clause 77).

This rate will be equal to half the married rate of unemployment benefit, taking into account the automatic CPI-linked increases that will come into effect in November, which will increase the standard rates of benefit to $77.25 for a single person over 18 with dependants and $128.80 for a married couple.
The rate of benefit for single unemployment people and sickness beneficiaries aged 16 and 17 years will also be increased by $4, giving them a total of $40 a week.
The new rates will take effect from each individual's first payday in November 1982 (Clause 105).

At the same time, to encourage unemployed people to take advantage of opportunities to earn extra income and gain job experience by casual work, they will be allowed to earn more without losing their entitlement to benefit.
