The more generous income test that will apply from November 1982 is given effect by clause 83 of this Bill. It will mean that everyone who receives unemployment or sickness benefit will be able to have $10 a week of private income without affecting their rate of benefit at all. The amount currently allowed is $3 a week for single people under 18 and $6 for everyone else.

At the same time the partial taper introduced by the Government in 1980 will be extended so that beneficiaries who have more than $10 a week private income will retain 50 cents a week for every dollar of extra income up to an income limit of $60.
The effect of this is that the maximum rate of benefit will be reduced by only half the amount of income the person has between $10 and $60.

This will represent a substantial increase in the amount that can be earned before benefit is reduced by a full $1 for every $1 of income. At present the upper limit is only $40 for single people under 18 and $50 for others.
Pensioners

Most pensioners will benefit from the automatic CPI-linked increases in the rates of pension that will come into effect in November and will increase the single rate of pension by $3.10 to $77.25 a week and the married rate by $5.20 to $128.80 a week.

In addition the Government has recognised that many pensioners who have a small amount of income apart from their pension have been hard hit by inflation, and that some adjustment in the amounts of private income pensioners can have without affecting their entitlement to a full pension should now be made.

From November 1982, single pensioners will be able to have $30 of private income a week and couples $50 a week before their pension is affected. This change is embodied in clause 36 of the Bill for age and invalid pensions. It will also apply to widow pensioners and supporting parent beneficiaries. This is the first adjustment in these income limits for several years and will increase them from their current levels of $20 a week for single people and $34.50 for couples.

The effect of these changes will be that some 430,700 pensioners with private incomes above the existing free areas will receive higher pensions. About 70 per cent of these will receive an increase of $5 a week (single) or $7.75 a week for a married couple. Some 16,000 people who are not now entitled to a pension will become eligible for a small part pension of up to $5 a week.

This initiative will result in an increase in the disposable incomes of these pensioners, who will be further assisted in this regard by the new pensioner tax rebate which is being introduced to protect pensioners with a modest income from being taxed.

Clause 59 of the Bill increases the income limit for pensioner health benefits. These benefits are available to social security pensioners, including supporting parent beneficiaries, and to sickness beneficiaries, and repatriation service pensioners.

We are proposing to increase the limits for these benefits, which were last adjusted in 1979, because we are concerned that a number of pensioners may have lost entitlement to fringe benefits, because their private incomes have risen above the existing limits through no action of their own. We are also concerned that some pensioners may be placing themselves at a disadvantage by arranging their financial affairs so as to keep their incomes below the current limits and qualify for a card. The increase in the income limits should help people in both these categories, and should encourage pensioners to enjoy the full advantage of any private assets they may have.

People who qualify for pensioner health benefit cards are entitled to a range of Commonwealth concessions, the most important being free medical and hospital treatment, free pharmaceuticals and telephone rental concessions.

The income limits at which entitlement to pensioner health benefits ceases will rise from November 1982 to $54 a week for a single person and $90 a week for a married couple, compared with the current limits of $40 and $68. A new uniform increased limit of $20 for each dependent child in a family on top of the base limits is also to apply. The additional income limits for children currently vary between $11 and $17 a week.

The effect of the changes will be that the new limit for a single person with one dependent child will be $74 a week, and for a couple with one child $110 a week. For each extra child the limit will rise uniformly by $20 a week.
Clause 59 also provides that the higher limits will apply to eligibility for pensioner funeral benefits.

People who receive sheltered employment allowance have special income limits for pensioner fringe benefits. For a married couple with no children, this will be increased to $90 a week, the same as for other married pensioner couples. For single people receiving sheltered employment allowance, the limit will remain at its current level of $68 a week, still $14 higher than for other penioners and beneficiaries. However, the increase to $20 a week in the additional limit for each child will apply to both these groups.
In addition to these measures, the supplementary assistance or allowance payable to pensioners and beneficiaries who pay private rent is increased by Clauses 39, 50 and 80 of the Bill.

Supplementary assistance or allowance is available for pensioners, supporting parent beneficiaries, and long-term sickness beneficiaries (that is those of 6 or more weeks standing) who have little or no income apart from the pension or benefit and pay private rent or board and lodging. Last year the maximum rate of payment was increased by $5 to $8 a week. This year it will be further increased by $2 to $10 a week.

Clause 89 of the Bill increases the incentive allowance paid to recipients of sheltered employment allowance in lieu of supplementary assistance to the same level of $10 a week. For these people the allowance is free of any income test and does not take into account whether rent is paid or not.

As I said at the beginning of this statement pensioners who rent private housing are recognised by the Government as having a particular need for assistance-hence our further effort to help them in this year's Budget. This new increase will particularly benefit pensioners with less than $16 a week in private income who pay more than $26 a week in rent.

Some State housing authorities also pay rental subsidies to private tenants. To recognise these State initiatives in the housing area and to ensure that private tenants receive the full benefit of them, clauses 29 and 74 of this Bill exempt such rent subsidies from counting as income for the pension and benefit income tests. This exemption will apply, to give one example, to people receiving rent relief subsidised under the Commonwealth's Mortgage and Rent Relief Scheme through State and Territory Governments.

A further small but important change is made by clause 47 of the Bill. From November 1982 women living overseas who qualify for wives' pension may, when their husbands die, qualify for a widows pension without having to return to Australia. The position of women in these circumstances has been of concern for some time and has been raised on a number of occasions by the Opposition Spokesman on welfare matters, Senator Grimes. I am pleased that we have been able to take steps to resolve this problem in this Bill.
Disabled People

The Bill reflects the special needs of disabled people in several ways apart from the increases in general income limits for pensions and income limits for pensioner health benefits that I have already referred to.
In particular it introduces a series of measures that will be of special assistance to disabled people who are in the workforce or who want to work.

Clause 90 of the Bill adds a new Part to the Social Security Act 1947, establishing a 'mobility allowance' of $10 a week for severely handicapped people who are in employment or undertaking vocational training, and who are unable to use public transport because of their disability.

This benefit, which will be available from April 1983, will cost an estimated $ 18m in a full year. It will be free of any income test or income tax. The benefit will not be available to those receiving the benefit of sales tax exemptions on new motor vehicles, or who receive the benefit of a car under the repatriation ''gift car'' scheme.

It has been designed specifically to recognise the additional travel costs incurred by disabled people who undertake employment or vocational training and the fact that such people are often unable to take advantage of the sales tax exemptions on new motor vehicles. The scheme also recognises that participation in the workforce by such people is often precarious, by providing a three month period of grace during which they will continue to receive the allowance even though they have lost their employment or ceased training.
The Government has decided to introduce such a scheme as quickly as possible to meet pressing needs in this area, but it will be kept under close review to make sure it is effective in its operation.

From 10 March 1983, a new form of income maintenance payment will be introduced for people who undertake Commonwealth rehabilitation program and who otherwise would be eligible for another social security pension or benefit.

The new 'rehabilitation allowance' established by clauses 97 and 98 of the Bill will be at the same rates as the person's social security pension or benefit, unless they are receiving a sickness or unemployment or special benefit which is less than the invalid pension rate. In that case, the person will be treated as an invalid pensioner in setting the rate of the rehabilitation allowance.

The rehabilitation allowance will be provided under the same conditions as invalid pension-that is, income tested, but income tax free-and will attract the same fringe benefits. It may be paid during the rehabilitation program and for up to 6 months afterwards.

The current rehabilitation training allowance will be re-structured to reflect this initiative, requiring consequential amendments to the Compensation ( Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971 and the Defence (Re-establishment) Act 1965. The training allowance will be paid as an additional benefit to people undertaking rehabilitation training who receive the rehabilitation allowance.

It is expected that some 4,500 people out of the 6,000 accepted annually by the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service will be eligible for rehabilitation allowance, which will involve a net cost of about $1m in a full year.
It is obvious that single or young unemployment beneficiaries and young sickness beneficiaries undertaking rehabilitation programs will be particularly assisted by this benefit.

There are also a number of measures in the Bill designed to remove the anomalies previously existing in the treatment of handicapped people attending different categories of special therapy and training services. For example, the incentive allowance paid to people in sheltered employment, which I have already mentioned will be increased from $8 to $10 from November, will also be extended, by Clause 33, to invalid pensioners undertaking activity therapy and adult training programs in centres financed under the Handicapped Persons Welfare Program. This allowance will be paid under the same terms as to recipients of sheltered employment allowance.

Further, to improve incentives for invalid pensioners to participate in activity therapy and adult training centres, the higher income limit of $68 a week for fringe benefits that applies to single sheltered employment allowances will also apply, from November 1982, to single invalid pensioners participating in the programs of such centres (Clause 60).
Families

I turn now to the very important measures contained in this Bill for the assistance of families. Our initiatives in this area have been designed bearing in mind the extra costs that all parents undertake in bringing up children, and the particular difficulties faced in this area by families with low incomes.

To help in meeting these extra costs, clause 65 of the Bill will increase the rate of family allowance by 50 per cent for the first and second children in a family from the endowment period commencing in October 1982. This will bring family allowance for the first child to $22.80 a month, and for the second child to $32.55 a month.

The increase, which is one plank of the Government's general tax relief measures in the 1982-83 Budget, will cost some $375m in a full year and will consolidate the increases for third and subsequent children introduced in the last year's Budget. While it will be of particular benefit to the 1.6 million families in Australia who have one or two children, all 2.1 million families with children will gain.

In addition to this general assistance for families, the Bill will introduce, from 1 May 1983, a tax-free family income supplement for low income families apart from pensioners and beneficiaries, of up to $10 a week for each dependent child, who does not already attract an education allowance or similar payment. This not only reflects our recognition of the particular cost burden borne by low income families who are bringing up children, but it also helps to alleviate the unfair and clearly undesirable situation in which an unemployment beneficiary can be better off financially than a person in similar family circumstances who is in employment, but earning low wages.
Clause 62 of this Bill inserts a new Part V in the Social Security Act 1947 setting out the conditions under which this benefit will be payable.
Briefly, the main features are:
The scheme will be closely aligned with the Disadvantaged Persons Health Scheme for low income earners.
The maximum rate of allowance of $10.00 per week for each eligible child, is equal to the additional pension or benefit paid for the child of a pensioner or beneficiary.
The allowance will be income tested on the joint income of parents, and will be paid to the main breadwinner.

People with an income less than the amount of the 'threshold' will be eligible for the maximum rate of allowance for each child. The threshold is the amount of income which a married couple with no children may have before they cease to be eligible for a health care card. If the scheme were operating from November, the threshold would be $184 a week; but, because the threshold will increase as a result of CPI-linked increases in the benefit rate which affects the eligibility level for health care cards, it will be higher when the scheme comes into effect .

In detemining eligibility, the maximum rate of assistance will be reduced by half of any income in excess of the threshold. To illustrate how benefit will be calculated, using the November threshold of $184, a family with three children and income of $200 per week would be eligible for a maximum payment of $30.00 less half the difference between their income ($200) and the threshold ($184)- that family would therefore receive a payment of $22 a week.

Entitlement will generally be determined for a 6 month period. Like the Disadvantaged Persons Health Scheme there will generally be no decrease in the rate of payment throughout that period if income during any 4 week period is less than 25 per cent higher than the income on which the original assessment is made.
Entitlement will be re-determined at the end of the 6 month period on the basis of the basic threshold.
Of course a person may seek an increase at any time if his income falls.

The legislation allows a three month period of grace in which claims for the supplement can be made. Thus, if a person is initially unaware of the availability of the new benefit, he may get full payment from the date of its introduction provided that he claims by 1 August 1983.

Because the family income supplement is a completely new benefit aimed at assisting low income families who are mainly in employment, the Government will monitor it closely to ensure that it meets its objective of relieving hardship among low-income families who are not pensioners or beneficiaries.

Families with a severely handicapped child who is cared for at home will also be assisted by an increase in handicapped child's allowance by $12 a month to $ 85 a month from November 1982 (Clause 72).
Finally, we have taken the opportunity to remove two unintended anomalies in the treatment of sole parent pensioners and beneficiaries.

Currently where a widow pensioner receives maintenance of more than $6 a week for a child the excess is treated as the pensioner's own income for income test purposes. While it is clear that the same principle should apply to supporting parent beneficiaries, there is doubt that the legislation as drafted achieves this intention.

The amendment contained in Clause 54 of this Bill will clarify this situation and ensures that maintenance payments received by all sole parent pensioners and beneficiaries will be treated in a consistent manner. This provision will take effect from February 1983.

The other anomaly relates to the payment of supporting parents benefit to some individuals who are themselves counted as dependants of another person for the purpose of the payment of a pension, benefit or allowance. From November 1982 it will no longer be possible for a supporting parent beneficiary to count as a dependant in this way (Clause 27). However, there is a savings provision which exempts existing recipients of pensions, benefits and allowances from the effect of this change.

Mr President, this Bill provides for important new developments in our social security and welfare programs and gives help in direct and realistic ways to those groups in the community whom we recognise as being in particular need of assistance, including disabled people, aged people and families with low incomes .
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Chaney for Senator Messner) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That that Bill be now read a second time.
Mr President, I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill provides for amendment of the repatriation and Associated Acts to give effect to the Government's Budget decisions; to formalise the basis for certain 'Act of Grace' payments; to extend the liability provision 'arisen out of or attributable to' to members of the Forces who do not have the benefit of this liability; and to make certain machinery amendments.

These amendments provide evidence of the Government's positive consideration to veterans. The Budget decisions which I will now outline have been given firm support by the community and ex-service organisations: Repatriation benefits are to be extended to members of peacekeeping forces who served prior to 2 November 1981; service pension eligibility is to be extended to merchant mariners of Commonwealth and allied countries; disability pension at the 100 per cent General Rate is to be restored to veterans who received a pension for pulmonary tuberculosis prior to 2 November 1978; increases are to be made in the amount of income permitted for determination of eligibility for service pension and fringe benefits; disability pension is to be discounted totally in determining a veteran's eligibility for service pension and fringe benefits; and certain decisions relating to Social Security beneficiaries are also to apply to Repatriation pensioners.

Eligibility for double orphan's pension is to be extended. The present eligibility criteria for a double orphan's pension provide that it can be paid only if a parent veteran's death was due to an accepted war-caused disability or the veteran was at the time of death in receipt of a Special Rate or pension as a double amputee. The amendment in the Bill will mean that the Department of Veterans' Affairs will be able to assist the children of veterans who served in a theatre of war but who died from causes not accepted as due to service, by making available to them the double orphan's pension. They will also be eligible for benefits already provided to other orphans such as free treatment and education benefits.

In addition, Mr President, the pensions payable for amputations or loss of vision and the levels of the amounts payable for many other benefits including Supplementary Assistance, also known as Rent Allowance, are to be increased. The legislation will also be amended to incorporate provision for certain types of payments that have been made on an 'Act of Grace' basis.

As announced in the Budget, eligibility for Repatriation benefits is to be extended to members of peacekeeping forces who served as representatives of Australia prior to 2 November 1981. Honourable senators will recall that the Repatriation Act was amended following the 1981-82 Budget to provide benefits to representatives of this country who served overseas after 2 November 1981 with peacekeeping, observation and monitoring forces raised or organised by the United Nations or other international bodies. These provisions were further extended earlier this year to cover Australian members of the Multi-national Force now serving in Sinai.

The amendment proposed by the Bill will provide eligibility for Repatriation benefits to Defence Force personnel who have, since 1948, been involved overseas in peacekeeping and monitoring roles and for the Australian police contingents on Cyprus which have been carrying out a similar role since 1964.

The Repatriation legislation contains differing liability provisions which reflect the perceived needs of providing benefits for veterans and their dependants at the respective dates when they were introduced.

These differences in liability provisions have led to criticism that veterans of various conflicts are being treated differently and that there is no real need for this apparent discrimination to continue.

The existing liability provisions under the Repatriation legislation were adopted along the lines of early compensation legislation. These provisions, however, do not reflect current thinking on liability. The Government accepts the need for uniform liability throughout the Repatriation legislation, except where there is good reason to depart from this general principle, and has decided that, in the first instance, the legislation should be amended to apply the ''arisen out of or is attributable to'' provisions to all members of the Forces.

The effect of this decision will be that veterans of the First World War, the Korean War, the Malayan Emergency and the Vietnam War and all other conflicts involving Australians will have the same liability cover as veterans of the Second World War. This is a very proper step for the Government to take and I hope that its significance will be quickly realised within the veteran community .

The Government considers that the same principles of eligibility should apply to all veterans for all conflicts unless there is good reason to introduce specific principles and provisions for particular conflicts or for particular groups of veterans.

It is intended to undertake a review of these provisions as part of the thorough review of all Repatriation legislation. This review which will be concerned with a wide range of complex provisions and will take some time, will apply the principles I have mentioned and be undertaken on the basis that there will be no watering down of existing standards of eligibility.

The Government has also decided to extend eligibility for service pension to Commonwealth and allied mariners who served in a theatre-of-war during World War II. The basis of eligibility is similar to that applied under the Repatriation Act to Australian mariners and members of the armed forces of Commonwealth and allied countries.

Last year eligibility for service pension was extended to include Australian mariners. The proposed amendment extends service pension to those living in Australia who served against the enemy or assisted the allied cause during World War II. I am sure all Honourable Senators are aware of the great hardships suffered by merchant mariners during the war and of the important role they played in the war effort. The Bill includes provisions which exclude any mariner who in any way assisted the enemy.

Another provision gives effect to the decision of the Government to restore to veterans who were in receipt of a pension prior to November 1978 in respect of pulmonary tuberculosis (T.B.), the 100 per cent General Rate, irrespective of the actual assessment of their condition. This will restore them to the position prevailing prior to 2 November 1978 at which time pensions were frozen and reassessed according to actual incapacity. Restoration of the pension will be to a minimum of 100 per cent of the General Rate from 6 January 1983. These arrangements which do not include retrospective payments have been agreed to by the Federated T.B. Sailors, Soldiers and Airmen's Association of Australia.

The Government also proposes that, from 11 November 1982, any disability pension received by a veteran or dependant will be totally disregarded as income when assessing levels of service pension and fringe benefits. This initiative which has been described as ''historic'' by the R.S.L. will, I am sure, be welcomed by all Honourable Senators. The proportion of disability pension disregarded for this purpose at present is 60 per cent.

In line with Social Security amendments, the income level used to determine a veteran's eligibility to receive the maximum rate of service pension will be raised from $20 to $30 a week for a single pensioner and from $34.50 to $50 a week for married pensioners. In addition, the fringe benefits limits will be raised from $40 a week to $54 a week for a single pensioner and from $68 to $90 a week for a married couple. These changes which will apply from 11 November this year will assist veterans who receive small increases in their income to retain their benefits.
The Bill provides for an increase in the maximum amount of Supplementary Allowance, that is, Rent Allowance, payable to a service pensioner from $8 to $ 10 a week from 11 November 1982.

Provision has been made in the Bill for increases in many other Repatriation benefits to severely disabled veterans and in pensions paid to orphans. They are intended to have effect from 11 November 1982. The increases in benefits are in line with movements in the Consumer Price Index in the twelve month period since the previous increase.
I come now to the amendment in the Bill which relates to ''Act of Grace'' payments.

Since 1942, special arrangements have existed for the payment of pension and benefits to certain persons who were exposed to the risk of injury or death through their employment in connection with World War II or later conflicts or war-like operations. These arrangements have covered persons with part-time service during World War II, representatives of various philanthropic organisations who were attached to the Forces and accredited by the relevant Service Department and certain Commonwealth employees.

I am sure that Honourable Senators will agree that this group of pensioners who provided such valuable service in war should have their rights formally perpetuated by being incorporated into Repatriation legislation.

Mr President, this Bill demonstrates in a formal way the Government's continuing concern to ensure that those who have served Australia, our Commonwealth partners, and allies, in war or war-like conflicts can be certain of being adequately compensated for the losses which they have suffered and the sacrifices they have made.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 19 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Ministers with responsibility for human rights meet to discuss the ratification of the 1966 international Covenant on Civil and Political Rights in Sydney on 4 May 1979, in Brisbane on 13 October 1979 and in Hobart on 14 February 1980.
(2) Did the Ministers at these meetings identify the areas where Australian law did not conform with the Convenant.
(3) Will the Attorney-general state, in respect of each State, which laws and practices did not conform with the Convenant.
(4) Which of the laws and practices referred to in (3) are still in force.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acting Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) to (4) Meetings of Ministers on human rights are conducted on a confidential basis and I am not therefore in a position to comment on the discussions. The honourable senator will however be aware that as a result of Ministers' deliberations it was felt that some of the provisions of the Covenant were not altogether appropriate to Australian conditions and therefore a number of reservations and declarations were made upon ratification. Australia has submitted its first report under Article 40 of the Covenant, reporting on measures which have been adopted that give effect to the rights recognished in the Covenant and on progress made in the enjoyment of those rights. A copy of this report is in the Parliamentary Library.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Statutory Rules and Regulations of the Territories

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 19 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: What progress has been made in computerising the Statutory Rules and Regulations of the Australian Capital Territory and the Ordinances, Statutory Rules and Regulations of the other Territories?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acting Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: In respect of the Australian Capital Territory legislation, priority has been given to the establishment of databases of the recently published reprints of the Australian Capital Territory Ordinances and Regulations. These reprints contain all Australian Capital Territory Ordinances and Regulations in force up to the end of 1978, including some subsequent amendments. As at 31 August 1982, all but 24 of these reprints had been included in the SCALE legal information retrieval system operated by my Department. It is expected that within the next two months the debabase will include all the reprints which have been issued, and thereafter will be maintained up to date as further reprints are produced.
Preliminary work is in hand on later amendments not included in the reprints, and on new Ordinances and Regulations. These will be added to the SCALE databases in the near future.
All of this material is able to be made available for inclusion in any publicly accessible computerised legal information retrieval system, when established.

No database has as yet been built of the legislation of other territories. Machine readable copies of this material from the start of 1982 are being obtained from the Government Printer with a view to its incorporation into a database at a future date. The legislation of the Northern Territory is no longer printed by the Commonwealth Government Printer, and there are no current plans to include Northern Territory material in the SCALE databases.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 19 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: When will Australia ratify the Convention on the Means of Prohibiting and Preventing the Illicit Imports, Export and Transfer of Ownership of Cultural Property which entered into force on 24 April 1972. Why has it not been ratified to date?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has the question of ratification of the convention, by Australia , under consideration. It is one of the matters which an Interdepartmental Working Group on Measures to Preserve and Protect Australia's Cultural Property has under examination. This body is expected to report to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment shortly.

There have been several attempts to resolve the question of ratification of the convention but due to legal and policy considerations the matter has not been decided. As a result of this the matter was included in the terms of reference of the working group.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Have Department of Defence files on the spraying of herbicides and insecticides in Vietnam been destroyed this year; if so, why?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Two documents on the subject of pesticides in Vietnam have been destroyed.

A copy of an Army minute dated 12 March 1982, entitled 'Herbicides', was destroyed on 27 May 1982. This document was destroyed because other copies of it are held on file and it was regarded as surplus.

One copy of an Army document entitled 'Report on the Use of Herbicides, Insecticides and Other Chemicals by the Australian Army in South Vietnam' has been destroyed. Of the 10 copies of this report initially circulated all are to be recalled and replaced by a revised report. The original report has been revised to:
Add information where a more detailed description of events was felt necessary;
make minor corrections of factual detail;
make editorial corrections such as spelling and typographical corrections; and
make other editorial changes to improve the flow of the report.
It is intended to retain only one copy of the original version of the report. No information will be lost as a result of the destruction of these documents.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are strawberries being imported from the U.S.A. with calyx and stems attached; if so, does this not contravene our quarantine laws which state that no green matter shall be imported into Australia.
(2) Are the calyx and stem capable of carrying virus and harbouring the eggs of the Mediterranean Fruit Fly and other mites.

(3) If it can take up to two months to detect and identify virus under laboratory conditions, is it possible to detect visually any virus being carried by the calyx and stems of strawberries as they come into the country.
(4) Does the importation of these strawberries, with calyx and stem still attached, constitute a threat to our horticultural industry.
(5) Do the imported strawberries also have substantial amounts of soil in their packaging; if so, does this increase the risk of foot and mount disease, which can be carried in soil.
(6) What steps does the Minister intend to stop the importation of these strawberries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Strawberries have been imported recently from the United States of America in accordance with conditions provided for under the Quarantine Act. Calyxes and stems are integral parts of the fruits and are not prohibited. However, plant debris, including foliage, is not permitted.

(2) The strawberries are from areas in California free from Mediterranean fruit fly. They are inspected on arrival for insects, mites, diseases and contaminants and treated if necessary. Quarantine officers have not had cause to reject them. Although viruses may be present in calyxes and stem, they do not constitute a quarantine risk as strawberry plants are not propagated from these parts of the fruits.
(3) Viruses are not detectable in calyxes and stems by visual examination but, as they are not a quarantine risk, detailed laboratory testing is not necessary.
(5) Soil contamination has not been found in imported strawberries.

(6) I am satisfied that existing quarantine procedures are adequate to permit the safe importation of strawberries from the United States of America and I do not propose to impose additional restrictions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs , upon notice, on 24 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Government refuse to issue visas to two distinguished biochemists due to attend an International Biochemistry Congress in Perth this week, because they were coming from the Soviet Union.
(2) Did this result in the whole delegation of 27 withdrawing from the Congress .

(3) Had the Government assured the organisers when Australia was selected to host the first such congress in the southern hemisphere, that there would be freedom of travel to the scientists concerned.
(4) How do such actions by the Government help to promote international scientific understanding and communication.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.
(3) No. The then Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Macphee, wrote to Professor Ada, Foreign Secretary of the Australian Academy of Science, in June 1980. In my letter he states:

It was at my request that a senior officer of my Department contacted you to discuss the matters raised in your correspondence. I have read the reports on the discussion and noted that agreement has been reached on the following form of words which may be quoted to the International Council of Scientific Unions:

'Bona fide scientists from all countries will be admitted to Australia to attend the conference subject to the application of normal rules and requirements for visitor entry to Australia in operation at the time. Every effort will be made to facilitate the issue of visas to such scientists.

I should stress that if this form of words is used it must be understood by the Academy that the normal rules in operation at the time of any conference might well exclude a particular scientist, a group of scientists or scientists of a particular nationality.
In response, Professor Ada wrote, on 2 July 1980:

I am most glad to have your agreement to the use of the form of words that I discussed with a senior officer of your Department and I have noted your proviso that 'normal rules' may vary from time to time.

(4) The unacceptability of the Soviet Unions international behaviour, as exemplified by its invasion of Afghanistan and its support for the suppression of the aspirations of the Polish people, undermines the stability and confidence essential to the promotion of international scientific understanding and communication. By firmly opposing such behaviour, Australia hopes to contribute to more stable circumstances in which international cooperation may flourish.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 25 August 1982:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 24 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1)When was the film Pirate Movie issued with a provisional certificate of eligibility for the tax incentives provided by section 10B of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

(2) Did the film Pirate Movie have two American actors in major roles, that is Kristy McNicol and Chris Atkins, plus an American director, art director and executive producer, and if so, how did the film qualify in terms of Australian content, for the certificate of eligibility for tax concessions.

(3) Was the $2m of the film's budget invested by the producers, Josephs and Hamilton, not really 'at risk' capital because it was acquired as a loan from American sources and because the film was the subject of completion insurance security.
(4) Will this expenditure be ineligible for any tax concessions if $2m invested in Pirate Movie by the producers was not 'at risk' capital.
(5) Was the film's certification under threat by the Department of Home Affairs at any times.
(6) Was the withdrawal of Pirate Movie's certification prevented by the intervention of a senior Minister in the Government, if so, who was the Minister .
(7) How much will this film cost the taxpayer in revenue foregone if final certification is grated to Pirate Movie.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Consistent with the secrecy provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act, I am unable to divulge any information in relation to specific applications for certification of films received under the taxation incentives for films scheme.

(3), (4) and (7) Questions on taxation aspects of the taxation incentives for films scheme fall within the responsibility of the Treasurer. In this regard, I note that Senate Question No. 2780 to the Minister representing the Treasurer asks identical questions to this Senate question.

(5) and (6) The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, is solely responsible for the issue and revocation of certificates stating that a film will be, or is, a qualifying Australian film under the Income Tax Assessment Act .

Under the scheme, the applicant is required to advise the Minister of relevant changes made to the film in the course of production to enable the Minister to determine whether the film remains a qualifying Australian film under the Act. In making that determination, the Minister has to have regard to specific requirements set out in the Act. The legislation does not extend this authority to any other person.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I am not aware that Aboriginal people have suffered detriment as a result of the atomic tests. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 23 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware of a report in the Weekend Australian of 12 and 13 June 1982 that the Queensland Premier said in Japan-'I am here to say that we are not Australians-we are Queenslanders'.
(2) Were Australian Embassy officials in Japan given prior warning of the Queensland Premier's intention to make such an announcement.
(3) Have Australian Embassy officials noted any confusion among Japanese businessmen and journalists about the actual geographical location of Queensland as a result of the Premier's statement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The report arose from a Press conference which the Premier gave in Tokyo on 9 June to promote the concept of 'Enterprise Queensland'. I am providing the full text of the journalist's question and the Premier's answer for the sake of accuracy and so that the remark can be seen in proper context. You will see that the remark was misreported.

Question: 'For the past one or two months, various states of Australia have been sending similar missions to Japan, and all of them claim that they are the centre of economic activity within Australia and they say they receive the highest priority from the Commonwealth Government. Now, why such rush of missions to Japan from Australia? What are the recent developments in this regard? Of course we do realise the importance of fostering industrial activity in various parts of Australia, but if there is any particular reason for sending so many missions to Japan I would like to know.'

Answer: 'Well, we have only this one, of course, but the point is that Australia has been getting rather a bad name for industrial problems, high prices and the rest of it, and we are over here saying that we are not Australia we're Queensland. And when you think of the high costs and high prices and industrial problems, don't think of Queensland, because it does not add up to us , particularly as it adds up to New South Wales. And that is why we are here: to tell you that point. That we are different to the rest of Australia-particularly in this coal area-from the other states. Anybody with two eyes and two ears, if you came out there you would soon find out why we are different and why the high costs and problems generate in New South Wales, particularly.'

(2) The Australian Embassy in Tokyo helped to arrange the Premier's Press conference as it usually does for visiting State Premiers. Embassy officials did not know in advance what the Premier would say at the Press conference.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1352) Senator Siddons asked me , as Minister representing the Minister for Transport, the following as part of a question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Will the Government consider diverting a small proportion of its oil levy-say 1 cent a litre-to a highway trust fund for maintenance and construction of the nation's road system?

I undertook to refer this part of Senator Siddons's question to the Minister for Transport. The Minister for Transport and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Government has consistently maintained that it is not prepared to consider earmarking a proportion of the crude oil production levy for road building purposes. This levy is not a tax on consumers, but rather a tax on oil production. As such, it recovers for the community a substantial part of the windfall profits which would otherwise have accrued to domestic oil producers as a result of the Government's decision that all domestically produced oil be priced at full import parity levels.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 May 1982 (Hansard, page 2379) Senator Kilgariff asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning human tissue transplants.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

The statement by Mr Justice Kirby relates to research involving genetic manipulation and it is assumed that it is to this aspect that the honourable senator's question is addressed. Tissue transplantation does not involve alteration to genetic material and as such is not generally considered to involve genetic manipulation.

The issues raised by Mr Justice Kirby were also referred to in Question on Notice No. 3654 asked by Mr B. O. Jones of my colleague, the Minister for Science and Technology. The Minister's reply of 16 February 1982 (Hansard, pages 215/6) sets out the Government's position in this regard.

The National Health and Medical Research Council (NH and MRC), which advises Federal and State Governments on medical research matters, does not offer grants until the proposed research has been cleared by the ethics committee of the institution in which the research is to be conducted. Ethical guidelines for medical research are kept up to date through the NH and MRC Working party on Ethics in Medical Research. The Working party comprises a lawyer, a theologian, two lay persons, three physicians and three medical researchers and its primary task is to revise the NH and MRC's 'Statement on Human Experimentation'. This is the basic guideline used by ethics committees in determining the acceptability of research applications.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Constitutional Convention: Qualifications of Members of Parliament

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 May 1982 (Hansard page 1912) Senator Evans asked the Attorney-General three questions as follows, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Firstly, when is the Government's response expected to the Report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs on the constitutional qualifications of members of parliament tabled on 2 June last year? Secondly, does the Attorney-General regard the subject matter of that report as appropriate for consideration by a further session of the Australian Constitutional Convention? Thirdly, is the Federal Government supporting a further session of the Constitutional Convention and is it likely to be held and, if so, when?
The Acting Attorney-General has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

I expect that the Government's response to the report on the constitutional qualifications of members of parliament to be made during the Budget sittings. The subject matter of the qualifications of members of parliament could be appropriate for consideration by a further session of the Australian Constitutional Convention, provided there is sufficiently wide agreement on the aspects to be considered and on the kinds of changes that might need to be made in the Constitution. At the Premiers Conference held on 24 and 25 June last, the Commonwealth and the States agreed on the holding of a further session of the Australian Constitutional Convention to be held in Adelaide in the first half of 1983.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Proposed Visit to Australia by Mr Horta

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 August 1982 (Hansard page 1381) Senator Sibraa asked the Attorney-General (Senator Durack), as the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, without notice, the following question:

ANSWER.PARA: Is it a fact that Mr Jose Ramos Horta, the representative of Fretilin at the United Nations, has applied for a visa to enter Australia to give evidence before the Senate Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee which is currently inquiring into the East Timor question, this evidence to be given by Mr Horta as a private citizen, not as a representative of any organisation? Is it also a fact that the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has recommended that the visa application be refused, despite an invitation from the Senate Committee to Mr Horta? If this is correct, will the Government reconsider the application for a visa-a request already granted by the United States and New Zealand-in order that the Senate Committee may have access to all possible information on its reference?
The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I can confirm that Mr Ramos Horta applied for a visitor's visa at the Australian Consulate-General in New York. The stated purpose of his visit was to give oral evidence before the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence concerning its inquiry into East Timor. Mr Ramos Horta has already provided a written submission.

Mr Ramos Horta is a representative of Fretilin and his visit would have been identified as one by a prominent Fretilin personality. The Government does not recognise Fretilin. It recognises East Timor as an integral part of Indonesia.

The Government decided therefore that, in accordance with its long-standing policy on the entry of Fretilin representatives, a visa for Mr Ramos Horta should be denied. He has been refused entry on two previous occasions.
The Government is not prepared to reconsider this matter.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 August 1982 (Hansard, page 19) Senator Hill asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce. The Minister will recall that I asked him a question on 18 March 1982 regarding the call by the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia for a full inquiry into small business in Australia. Has the Minister seen the August edition of Small Business Review, which again calls for such an inquiry into small business, particularly on such questions as alleged discriminatory taxation policy, inequitable financial treatment, and the impact of high level tariffs on small business? In view of the major importance of small business to the Australian economic and social well-being, will the Government reconsider its earlier refusal to institute such an inquiry?
The Acting Minister for Industry and Commerce has supplied the following additional information in answer to the honourable senator's question:
I am aware of the requests by the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia (COSBOA) for a formal inquiry to be held into small business in Australia.

Specific problems and needs of small business have been subjected to formal inquiry on a number of occasions including the Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System, the Committee of Inquiry into Management Education and the Trade Practices Consultative Committee. In addition there have been improvements in the range and quality of information on small businesses from both official and privately funded research. Consultative procedures, particularly the formation of the Small Business Advisory Council, have also been developed to alert Government to matters of concern to small business.
For these reasons I have indicated to COSBOA's Chairman and to parliamentary colleagues that I am not convinced of the need for a formal inquiry at this stage.

However, the question of the need for an inquiry will be considered at the next meeting of the Small Business Advisory Council. The views of the Council on this subject will of course receive my close attention.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 August 1982 (Hansard, page 14) Senator Thomas asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning the implications for tax sharing in Western Australia of the 1981 census question about usual place of residence, and in particular:

ANSWER.PARA: Will the Minister request the Bureau to produce adjusted population figures which will give more accurately guidance to the States Grants Commission.
Mr Howard has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
No.
The census question to which the senator refers-question 8, 'Where does each person usually live'-was accompanied by the following definition:
' ''Usual'' residence is that address at which a person has lived or intends to live for any period of 6 months or more in 1981.'
The Statistician advises that there is no evidence to suggest that the question has been misinterpreted in the manner the senator suggested.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 August 1982 (Hansard, page 450) Senator Mason asked me a question without notice relating to the costs of the new Parliament House. I undertook to refer the question to the appropriate Minister to obtain information for a more specific response.

ANSWER.PARA: The Honourable Michael Hodgman, MP, has now supplied the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

In essence, the original costing, for the new Parliament House, of $151m was prepared at May 1978 prices for a notional building of 58,000 square metres of usable area. At that stage, prior to the architectural competition, there was no design for the building and only a statement of the Parliament's accomodation requirements.

The costing provided by the winning architect for his successful design concept was $156.4m also at May 1978 prices. Following the design competition, an intensive examination was undertaken by the Parliament House Construction Authority and its consultants which indicated that a more realistic building cost estimate was $220m at May 1978 prices. The Authority's report to Parliament, tabled in the Senate on 21 August 1980, detailed the items where the winner's design exceeded those facilities included in the notional building cost estimate.
The major items which accounted for the variation between the notional costing and the Authority's considered estimate are outlined below:
$m $m Pre-competition budget 151 Increased usable area 29 Underground car parking 18 Site works and landscaping 13 Energy saving devices 4 Standard of finishes 5 Total Variation 69
Building Budget 220

Both Houses of the Parliament subsequently approved the winner's design and the building budget as estimated by the Construction Authority. That costing of $220m at May 1978 prices forms the basis of the Authority's cost plan and is subject to stringent and continuous cost control measures.

The Authority has advised the Government and the Parliament that it intends to construct the new building within the building budget of $220m with adjustment made only to cover inflation and additional requirements approved by Parliament . The most recent update of the building budget is $370.4m at March 1982, is made up of the original $220m, plus $141.5m for inflation based on an approved index, plus $8.9m for additional requirements approved by the Parliament. The budget is therefore being maintained in real terms.

The authority has rejected claims that the building will cost in the order of $1,322m as stated by Senator Mason in a recent letter to the Canberra Times. The Executive Officer of the Authority in his reply indicated that, such a ' calculation of the final cost of the building does not appear to take account of the fact that as work is completed its value no longer attracts the inflationary effect of rises in costs. To put the figures into a proper perspective, the inflation rate in the construction industry would need to exceed 40 per cent per annum and be sustained at that level through to the building completion date in 1988, in order to reach the cost figures quoted by Senator Mason.'

The Parliament House project receives regular and on-going scrutiny by both Houses through the Joint Standing Committee on the new Parliament House. I am fully satisfied that proper cost control measures are being sucessfully applied to all aspects of the project, and it is regrettable that the ill-informed statements of Senator Mason are so misleading to the Parliament and the public.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 August 1981 (Hansard, page 316) Senator Mason addressed a question without notice to the Leader of the Government in the Senate concerning the 1981-82 Budget decision to impose sales tax, at the rate of 2 1/2 per cent, on building materials with effect from 1 January 1982. One part of the question relating to the impact of the tax which had been proposed in the cost of housing was referred to the Treasurer for reply.

ANSWER.PARA: The Treasurer has supplied the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:
It is not possible to say with any precision what the effect would have been. The effect would vary with factors such as location and type of materials used.

However, the matter is no longer relevant. The legislation concerned was not passed by the Senate, and building materials are not among the goods to be subjected to tax under the 1982-83 Budget proposals.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 September 1982 (Hansard page 765) Senator Mulvihill asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, without notice, the following question:

ANSWER.PARA: Will the Minister for Foreign Affairs, and the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs inquire of both Departments, how long it will take to finalise the selection of Uruguayan immigrants from a refugee camp in Brazil, which was originally undertaken under the Humanitarian program?
The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Australian Embassy in Buenos Aires, which oversights migration matters in Brazil, has advised that neither they, nor the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees in Brazil have any knowledge of such a separate and identifiable group of Uruguayans in Brazil. Were the members of such a group brought to the notice of one of our Embassies, they would of course be processed in the normal way, including assessment for entry under the Latin American Refugee Program.

The Special Humanitarian Program is intended to provide resettlement in Australia for people in temporary asylum who would not qualify for existing migrant or refugee programs, and who have close relatives or a sponsoring organisation here or a close association with Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 September 1982 (Hansard, page 926) Senator Macklin asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Over two years ago the Government removed the limits on electoral spending. At the same time it promised that it would inquire into what the limits should be. Could the Minister indicate where the inquiry has got and when the Senate is likely to have a report on the inquiry as promised?
The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In his second reading speech to the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill on 15 May 1980 (House of Representatives Hansard, pages 2848-2850) the then Minister for Administrative Services clearly stated the Government's position regarding those provisions of Part XVI of the Commonwealth Electoral Act which were repealed by the passage of the Bill, including section 145 which set limits on candidates' electoral expenditure. At the same time he announced the Government's intention to establish an inquiry into what provisions should be included in the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 to require the public disclosure of electoral expenditure and the proposed terms of reference of that inquiry. No other inquiry into electoral expenditure was, or has been, announced.
The inquiry was conducted by Sir Clarrie Harders. The Government is still considering his report.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 16 September 1982 (Hansard, page 1003) Senator Chipp asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice, whether the Government would take steps to correct an erroneous report in the United States Nuclear Proliferation Handbook of September 1980 stating that in 1968 HMAS Hobart carried a missile with a nuclear warhead.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I have asked Defence officials in our embassy in Washington to draw the error to the attention of the relevant United States officials so that it may be removed from subsequent issues of the Factbook.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 September 1982 (Hansard, page 1193) Senator Mason asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the Minister seen reports from United States naval authorities that the FFG7 Frigates in service or being built for the Australian and United States navies are fitted with a fire control system, Mark 92 system, which is not capable of fighting a contemporary naval war, especially against modern air attacks such as by Cruise missiles and supersonic aircraft, particularly in bad weather?
Have the ships' builders also admitted this deficiency?
Are reports also accurate that Australian Defence officials have stated an opposite view, saying that the system is adequate in our own ships?

Will the Government see that this matter is fully investigated so that we can be assured that the most modern ships in our Navy, the FFG7 frigates HMAS Adelaide and HMAS Canberra, can fight a contemporary naval war?
The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
Press reports have been seen and reports have been given by relevant United States naval authorities to keep the Royal Australian Navy informed of problems in the Mark 92 Fire Control System.

The Mark 92 fire control system is a United States Government Furnished Equipment and therefore not the responsibility of the Royal Australian Navy FFG shipbuilder. The Mark 92 fire control system reported poor performance has been investigated by the United States Navy.

The investigations determined that the major problem was that operator expectations exceeded system specification and therefore many criticisms were not supported. However, the investigation also determined that equipment did not meet specification in the following aspects:
poor performance in bad weather;
reduced performance at target low elevation;
some unreliable components;
poor self check performance monitoring;
poor performance in an electronic counter-measurer environment.
The Mark 92 fire control system fitted in Royal Australian Navies FFG's performs to the same standards as the equipments fitted in the USN FFG's. The same problems exist.

Problem rectification proposals have been developed for implementation in three phases-near, mid and long term. The near and mid term proposals have been aproved for development and production by the USN. The long term proposal which comprised a new design phased array radar was not approved by the USN on the grounds of too little performance gain and high cost.

The near term proposals overcame all of the above deficiencies except the poor performance in the electronic counter-measures environment. This deficiency is overcome with the mid term improvement which also introduces considerable technology improvements.

The first two Royal Australian Navy FFG Frigates, (Adelaide and Canberra) have already incorporated some early parts of the near term improvements, the remainder approved at $300,000 for each ship are on order and scheduled for installation at the first refits late 1983/early 1984. Mid term improvements will not be available until about 1985. The two remaining FFGs (Sydney and Darwin) will have their Mark 92 Fire Control Systems modified to include the near term improvements before delivery.
